Susquehanna Flats — 200 yards west of a line from Junction Buoy "A" Fl. (2+1) 6 § to R "2" Fl. R 4 §

Except as provided in §B of this regulation, a person may not possess, transport, or pack a female crab from which the egg pouch or bunion has been removed, or an egg-bearing female crab known as the sponge crab.

A female crab from which the egg pouch or bunion has been removed, or an egg-bearing female crab known as the sponge crab may be imported into Maryland from another state by a dealer or crab processing plant:
If accompanied by a bill of sale or bill of lading from the jurisdiction of origin; and
Only during the time period specified in the public notice issued in accordance with §C of this regulation.
Public Notice.

In consultation with blue crab industry advisory groups, the Department shall issue a public notice to establish a time period of 71 consecutive days when a female crab from which the egg pouch or bunion has been removed, or an egg-bearing female crab known as the sponge crab may be imported into Maryland from another state.
The import time period may not begin prior to April 10 or end after July 20.
The public notice shall be published on the Department's website by April 1 of each year.

The Secretary shall make a reasonable effort to disseminate a public notice issued under this section through various other media so that an affected individual has a reasonable opportunity to be informed.
A violation of the restrictions set by the Secretary in accordance with section is a violation of this regulation.

section.heading: Recreational Crabbing Licenses Chesapeake Bay and Its Tidal Tributaries.

para.text: Recreational Crabbing License.

Except as provided in §E of this regulation, an individual who catches or attempts to catch crabs for recreational purposes in the waters of the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries shall pay the fee and obtain a recreational crabbing license in order to use the following gear to catch crabs:
Trotline;
Collapsible traps or net rings;
Up to ten eel pots for catching the individual's own bait, which are:
Clearly labeled with the individual's name;
Not placed in a buoy free channel as listed in Regulation .07H of this chapter or COMAR 08.02.05.08F; and
Used only for catching eels; and
Seines.

The annual fee for a recreational crabbing license to catch or attempt to catch crabs for recreational purposes from the waters of the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries with the gear specified in §A(1) of this regulation is:
For a Maryland resident $5;
For a Maryland resident, in possession of a Maryland Chesapeake Bay and coastal sport fishing license or a resident consolidated senior sport fishing license $2;
For a nonresident $10.
An individual who has purchased a recreational crabbing license shall have the license in possession when:
Engaged in crabbing for recreational purposes with the gear listed under §A(1) of this regulation; or

In possession of more crabs than provided for in the daily catch limits set forth in Regulation .10A(2)(a), A(3)(a) and (b), and A(4)(a) of this chapter and not on a boat that has been licensed as a recreational crab boat.
Recreational Crabbing Boat License.
A recreational crabbing boat license authorizes an individual to use the following gear to catch or attempt to catch crabs in the licensed boat in the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries:
Trotline; and
Collapsible traps or net rings.

The annual fee for a recreational crabbing boat license to catch or attempt to catch crabs for recreational purposes from the waters of the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries with the gear specified in §B(1) of this regulation is $15.
To the recreational crabbing boat licensee, the Department shall issue:
A recreational crabbing boat decal; and
A complimentary recreational crabbing license.
Except as provided in §B(5) of this regulation, the recreational crabbing boat decal:
Shall be permanently affixed and displayed on either side of the forward half of the vessel for which issued;
Is not transferable; and
Shall, when displayed, exempt all persons aboard from the requirement of possessing an individual license to crab recreationally.

Exemption for Crabbing Boat Decals. If the crabbing boat decal is not permanently affixed to the vessel, all persons aboard are exempt from the requirement of possessing an individual license to crab recreationally only if:
The individual who purchased the crabbing boat decal is present on the vessel;
The individual who purchased the crabbing boat decal is in possession of the proof of purchase issued by the Department; and
The crabbing boat decal was purchased within the previous 10 calendar days.
Complimentary Recreational Crabbing License.
The Department shall issue a complimentary recreational crabbing license to an individual who purchases a:
Recreational crabbing boat license; or
Chesapeake Bay and coastal sport fishing boat license in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-745(d)(2), Annotated Code of Maryland.
The individual issued the complimentary recreational crabbing license has the same restrictions as an individual with a recreational crabbing license.
The recreational crabbing boat license and the complimentary recreational crabbing license count as a single license for the individual who purchases the recreational crabbing boat license.
Private Waterfront Property Crab Pot Registration.
Only a person who owns or leases private property along the shore of the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries may obtain a private waterfront property crab pot registration.

A person who owns or leases private property along the shore of the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries shall obtain a private waterfront property crab pot registration in order to use a crab pot from the person's property.
There is no fee for a private waterfront property crab pot registration.

Exceptions. An individual who catches or attempts to catch crabs for recreational purposes in the waters of the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries is not required to have a recreational crabbing license if the individual:
Uses any of the following gear:
A dipnet;
A handline; or
Up to two crab pots, if qualified to use crab pots as set forth in Regulation .07D of this chapter;
Is assisting an individual who has a recreational crabbing license; or
Is crabbing for recreational purposes from a boat that has been licensed by the Department as a recreational crabbing boat.
General.
A recreational crabbing license, recreational crabbing boat license, or private waterfront property crab pot registration is valid for 365 days following the date of issuance.
A recreational crabbing license, recreational crabbing boat license, or private waterfront property crab pot registration may be obtained from any authorized agent of the Department.

The Department may designate a person engaged in a commercial enterprise as an agent to sell recreational crabbing licenses, recreational crabbing boat licenses, or issue private waterfront property crab pot registrations.
An agent may retain:
50 cents for each recreational crabbing license issued by the agent; and
$1.50 for each recreational crabbing boat license issued by the agent.

section.heading: Recreational Crabbing Catch and Possession Limits — Chesapeake Bay and its Tidal Tributaries.

para.text: Daily Catch and Possession Limits.

An individual exempt from the licensing requirements of Regulation .09 of this chapter is considered an unlicensed individual and may not exceed the catch and possession limits for an unlicensed individual.
Daily catch and possession limits for individuals harvesting crabs from shore or from crab pots.

tr.td: 1 dozen soft crabs,1 dozen male peeler crabs, or a combination of 1 dozen soft crabs and male peeler crabs

td.p: 1 bushel male hard crabs if storing crabs in a bushel
6 dozen male hard crabs if storing crabs in any container other than a bushel

tr.td: 2 dozen soft crabs, 2 dozen male peeler crabs, or a combination of 2 dozen soft crabs and male peeler crabs

para.text: Daily catch and possession boat limits for a vessel without a recreational crabbing boat license.

tr.td: (a) One unlicensed individual on board an unlicensed vessel
1 dozen soft crabs,1 dozen male peeler crabs, or a combination of 1 dozen soft crabs and male peeler crabs
(b) Two or more unlicensed individuals on board an unlicensed vessel
1 dozen soft crabs, 1 dozen male peeler crabs, or a combination of 1 dozen soft crabs and male peeler crabs
(c) One licensed individual or one licensed individual accompanied by any number of unlicensed individuals on board an unlicensed vessel

td.p: 1 bushel male hard crabs if storing crabs in a bushel
6 dozen male hard crabs if storing crabs in any container other than a bushel

tr.td: 2 dozen soft crabs, 2 dozen male peeler crabs, or a combination of 2 dozen soft crabs and male peeler crabs
(d) Two or more licensed individuals or two or more licensed individuals accompanied by any number of unlicensed individuals on board an unlicensed vessel

td.p: 2 bushels male hard crabs if storing crabs in bushels
12 dozen male hard crabs if storing crabs in any container other than a bushel

tr.td: 2 dozen soft crabs, 2 dozen male peeler crabs, or a combination of 2 dozen soft crabs and male peeler crabs

para.text: Daily catch and possession boat limits for a vessel with a recreational crabbing boat license.

tr.td: (a) One or more unlicensed individuals on board a licensed vessel

td.p: 1 bushel male hard crabs if storing crabs in a bushel
6 dozen male hard crabs if storing crabs in any container other than a bushel

tr.td: 2 dozen soft crabs,2 dozen male peeler crabs, or a combination of 2 dozen soft crabs and male peeler crabs
(b) One licensed individual on board a licensed vessel

td.p: 1 bushel male hard crabs if storing crabs in a bushel
6 dozen male hard crabs if storing crabs in any container other than a bushel

tr.td: 2 dozen soft crabs, 2 dozen male peeler crabs, or a combination of 2 dozen soft crabs and male peeler crabs
(c) An individual who purchased a recreational crabbing boat license accompanied by any number of unlicensed individuals on board a licensed vessel

td.p: 1 bushel male hard crabs if storing crabs in a bushel
6 dozen male hard crabs if storing crabs in any container other than a bushel

tr.td: 2 dozen soft crabs, 2 dozen male peeler crabs, or a combination of 2 dozen soft crabs and male peeler crabs
(d) Two or more licensed individuals accompanied by any number of unlicensed individuals on board a licensed vessel

td.p: 2 bushels male hard crabs if storing crabs in bushels
12 dozen male hard crabs if storing crabs in any container other than a bushel
2 dozen soft crabs, 2 dozen male peeler crabs, or a combination of 2 dozen soft crabs and male peeler crabs
The catch limit is a bushel per licensed individual when using a bushel to hold male crabs. When not using a bushel the catch limit is 6 dozen male hard crabs per licensed individual.

tr.td: (e) One licensed individual, who is not the owner of the licensed vessel, accompanied by any number of unlicensed individuals on board a licensed vessel

td.p: 2 bushels male hard crabs if storing crabs in bushels
12 dozen male hard crabs if storing crabs in any container other than a bushel
2 dozen soft crabs, 2 dozen male peeler crabs, or a combination of 2 dozen soft crabs and male peeler crabs
The catch limit is a bushel per licensed individual when using a bushel to hold male crabs. When not using a bushel the catch limit is 6 dozen male hard crabs per licensed individual.

para.text: Female Hard Crabs and Female Peelers.
Except as provided in §B(2) of this regulation, an individual may not catch or possess female hard crabs or female peelers.
Exception.
Female crabs are accompanied by a bill of sale; and
Individual is not catching or attempting to catch crabs.

section.heading: Season and Time for Catching Crabs.

para.text: Commercial.
An individual licensed to catch crabs for sale may remove crabs from commercial gear in the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries only during the following time periods:
Trotlines:
Except as provided in §A(1)(a)(iii) of this regulation, between 1 hour before sunrise to 9 hours after sunrise during the period May through September;
Between 1/2 hour before sunrise and 9-1/2 hours after sunrise during April, October, November, and December; and
Between 2 hours before sunrise to 9 hours after sunrise on Memorial Day, Juneteenth National Independence Day, July 4, Labor Day, and the day immediately preceding each of those holidays; and
Crab Scrapes:
Except as provided in §A(1)(b)(iii) of this regulation, between 1 hour before sunrise to 9 hours after sunrise during the period May through September;
Between sunrise and 10 hours after sunrise during April and October; and
Between 2 hours before sunrise to 9 hours after sunrise on Memorial Day, Juneteenth National Independence Day, July 4, Labor Day, and the day immediately preceding each of those holidays; and
Crab pots, bank traps, channel pounds, collapsible traps, net rings, handlines, dip nets, and pound nets:
Except as provided in §A(1)(c)(ii) of this regulation, between 1/2 hour before sunrise to 7-1/2 hours after sunrise; and
Between 1-1/2 hours before sunrise to 7-1/2 hours after sunrise on Memorial Day, Juneteenth National Independence Day, July 4, Labor Day, and the day immediately preceding each of those holidays.
A person may not catch crabs using a crab scrape from October 31 to April 14, inclusive.
An individual licensed to catch crabs for sale may set or place overboard scrapes only during the following time periods:
Except as provided in §A(3)(c) of this regulation, between 1 hour before sunrise to 9 hours after sunrise during the period May through September;
Between sunrise and 10 hours after sunrise during April and October; and
Between 2 hours before sunrise to 9 hours after sunrise on Memorial Day, Juneteenth National Independence Day, July 4, Labor Day, and the day immediately preceding each of those holidays.
Crab Pot Set Times. Crab pots may only be set:
During the time periods established in §A(1)(c) of this regulation; or
If already onboard a boat at the end of the time periods established in §A(1)(c) of this regulation, for 1 hour after the end of the time periods established in §A(1)(c) of this regulation.
Time limits specified in this regulation are not applicable to the fishing of bank traps before May 1.
Recreational.
Except as provided in §B(2) of this regulation, a person may not set any recreational crabbing gear or catch crabs for recreational purposes during:
May through September between:
5 p.m. and 1/2 hour before sunrise in the main Chesapeake Bay; and
Sunset and 1/2 hour before sunrise in tidal tributaries of the Chesapeake Bay; and
April, October, November, and December between:
5 p.m. and 1/2 hour after sunrise in the main Chesapeake Bay; and
Sunset and 1/2 hour after sunrise in tidal tributaries of the Chesapeake Bay.
Crab pots, dip nets, and handlines. At all times during the recreational season for crabbing, a person may use:
Crab pots on private property that have been registered in accordance with Regulation .09 of this chapter;
Dip nets; or
Handlines.
A person may not catch blue crabs in the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries from December 16 through March 31, inclusive.

section.heading: Special Regulations for Crabbing in Worcester County.

para.text: Structural Requirements of Crab Pots. Notwithstanding Regulation .07A and B of this chapter, a crab pot set in the coastal bays of the Atlantic Ocean and their tidal tributaries shall have one unobstructed 2-5/16 inch cull ring on a side panel of the upper compartment and one 2-5/16 inch cull ring on a panel at the lower compartment of the crab pot. The cull ring is not required in a crab pot constructed with unstretched mesh measuring less than 1-1/2 inches or at least 2 inches on each side.
Daily Catch Limits.
Commercial. The daily catch limit in the coastal bays of the Atlantic Ocean and their tidal tributaries is 25 bushels, 16 lugs, or 10 barrels per commercial boat.
Recreational. The daily catch limit in the waters of the coastal bays of the Atlantic Ocean and their tidal tributaries is:
1 bushel per individual if storing crabs in a bushel;
6 dozen crabs per individual if storing crabs in any container other than a bushel;
2 bushels per boat if two or more individuals are on the boat and storing crabs in bushels; and
12 dozen crabs per boat if two or more individuals are on the boat and storing crabs in any container other than bushels.
Seasons for Catching Crabs.
Commercial. A person licensed to catch crabs for sale may not catch crabs in the coastal bays of the Atlantic Ocean and their tidal tributaries between October 31 and April 1.
Recreational. A person may not catch crabs for recreational purposes in the coastal bays of the Atlantic Ocean and their tidal tributaries between December 31 and April 1.

Commercial Daily Time Restrictions. A person licensed to catch crabs for sale may remove crabs from commercial gear and set or retrieve crab pots in the coastal bays of the Atlantic Ocean and their tidal tributaries only during the following time periods:
Between sunrise and 8-1/2 hours after sunrise during April and October;
Except as provided in §D(3) of this regulation, between 1/2 hour before sunrise to 8 hours after sunrise during the period May through September; and
Between 1-1/2 hours before sunrise to 8 hours after sunrise on Memorial Day, Juneteenth National Independence Day, July 4, Labor Day, and the day immediately preceding each of those holidays.
Gear Restrictions. A person may not catch crabs in the coastal bays of the Atlantic Ocean and their tidal tributaries by scrape.
Landing Provision. Crabs caught in the waters of Worcester County may be landed out of the State.

section.heading: Commercial Harvest of Crabs from Finfish Gear.

para.text: Notwithstanding Regulations .01—.07 of this chapter, an individual licensed to harvest both crabs and finfish for commercial purposes may catch crabs from pound nets.
The harvest and possession of crabs from a pound net is:
Prohibited on any day during which a licensee is otherwise prohibited from harvesting crabs as provided in Regulation .14 of this chapter;
Restricted to the seasons and times provided in Regulations .11 and .12 of this chapter;
Restricted by the size limits provided in Regulation .14 of this chapter;
Restricted to a maximum of 2 bushels or 1 lug of male crabs per licensee per day; and
Restricted to the daily maximum number of female crabs allowed by the individual's license type.
Notwithstanding COMAR 08.02.25.04, a licensee may only harvest or possess crabs from a pound net or combination of pound nets registered in the licensee's name.
Recreational.

Except for crab pots from private property, dipnets, or handlines, a person may not set any crabbing gear or catch crabs for recreational purposes on Wednesdays in the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries.
When a State or federal holiday falls on a Wednesday or Thursday, recreational crabbing is permitted on the Wednesday of that week.
An individual may not offer to sell or sell crabs that were caught for recreational purposes.
An individual may not knowingly buy or offer to buy crabs which were caught for recreational purposes.

An individual licensed to provide services as a fishing guide or to fish recreationally in the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries may possess any number of soft crabs or male peeler crabs for the purposes of fishing.
An individual licensed to catch crabs for commercial purposes:
May catch crabs for recreational purposes with recreational crabbing gear without paying the fee for recreational crabbing set forth in Regulation .09 of this chapter; and
Has the same restrictions as an individual with a recreational crabbing license when engaged in recreational crabbing activities.
Commercial — General.
A person licensed to catch crabs for sale may not set or retrieve gear or catch crabs for commercial purposes in the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries on Sundays and Mondays unless the person:
Declares intent under §C of this regulation;
Is granted an alternate day off under §D of this regulation;
Is operating as a licensee's authorized user on the vessel designated in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland; or
Is assisting as an unlicensed crew member on another licensee's vessel.
A person who is granted an alternate day off under §D of this regulation may not set or retrieve gear or catch crabs for commercial purposes on the alternate day off.

The vessel of a person licensed to catch crabs for sale may not be used to set or retrieve gear or catch crabs for commercial purposes on the day or days on which the vessel's owner may not set or retrieve gear or catch crabs for commercial purposes.

A person licensed to catch crabs for commercial purposes, who declares under §C(1) of this regulation, may set or retrieve gear or catch crabs for commercial purposes on a Sunday or Monday of a particular week if:
A State or federal holiday falls on the Sunday or Monday, or the immediately preceding Saturday; or
The Sunday or Monday precedes a State or federal holiday that falls on a Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, or Friday of the particular week.
Mature female hard crabs shall be kept in separate bushels, lugs, or barrels from male hard crabs or peeler crabs.
Mature female hard crabs on board a vessel shall be stored in the same type of containers of similar dimensions.
Male hard crabs on board a vessel shall be stored in the same type of containers of similar dimensions.
Except as specified in §F(2) of this regulation, an individual licensed to catch crabs for commercial purposes may not catch or possess in the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries more than:
Six mature female hard crabs per container smaller than a barrel of male crabs; or
13 mature female hard crabs per barrel of male crabs.

Beginning in 2010, an individual with a limited crab harvester (LCC) license will be considered as limited crab harvester frozen license status, as specified in §F(2)(b) of this regulation, if that license is not designated as a:
Limited crab harvester active license; or
Limited crab harvester male only license.
The commercial female crab daily catch limit shall be determined by the license type based on the abundance target for spawning age crabs recommended by the Chesapeake Bay Stock Assessment Committee.

Except as provided in §B(11) of this regulation, an individual licensed to catch crabs for commercial purposes may not harvest or possess more mature female hard crabs daily than the catch limit specified by the individual's license type.

Except as provided in §B(11) of this regulation, more than two licensees' daily catch limits from 1 day may not be harvested from, carried on, or possessed on a vessel while the licensees are on board.
An individual may possess and transport crabs harvested from the waters of the Potomac River or Virginia if:
The individual is not engaged in harvesting crabs in Maryland waters while the crabs harvested in the waters of the Potomac River or Virginia are on board the vessel; and
The individual is in possession of a Virginia commercial crab harvester license or Potomac River Fisheries Commission commercial license.
A float used for holding or shedding peelers shall have a base that is a minimum of 16 square feet.
An individual commercially harvesting crabs aboard a vessel may only have crabs that are commercially harvested on board.
Closed Day Declaration of Intent.

A person licensed to catch crabs for sale and who wishes to set or retrieve gear or catch crabs on one of the required days off in §B(1) of this regulation shall declare that person's intent to set or retrieve gear or catch crabs in the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries for commercial purposes on one of the required days off as specified in §B(1) of this regulation.

Display of Declaration. The letters for the abbreviation of the day off shall be identified and displayed on the vessel and shall be painted or firmly attached to the port side near the stern of the vessel as follows:
The letters shall be positioned in such a manner as to be clearly visible to persons in passing boats;
The letters shall be plain vertical block characters of not less than 3 inches in height and shall contrast with the color of the background;
The letters "SUN" shall be displayed as the abbreviation for Sundays; and
The letters "MON" shall be displayed as the abbreviation for Monday.

A person licensed to catch crabs for sale who declares a day off under §C(1) of this regulation shall declare a Sunday or Monday day off only at the time of license renewal or issuance on forms provided by the Department.
Alternate Closed Day.

A person licensed to catch crabs for sale may apply to the Department for an alternate to the closed days specified in §B(1) of this regulation. The Department may grant a licensee's request for an alternate closed day if the licensee demonstrates the:
Imposition of substantial hardship on the licensee's exercise of religion by observing one of the closed days specified in §B(1) of this regulation; and
Absence of substantial hardship on the licensee's exercise of religion by observing the alternate closed day requested in the application.
An alternate closed day shall be displayed on the vessel in the manner set forth in §C(2) of this regulation using the first three letters of the day of the week.
A licensee who is granted an alternate closed day may set gear and catch crabs on the closed days specified in §B(1) of this regulation.

A person licensed to catch crabs for sale who declares a day off under §D(1) of this regulation shall declare an alternate day off only at the time of license renewal or issuance on forms provided by the Department.
Notwithstanding Natural Resources Article, §4-809, Annotated Code of Maryland, a person may not:
Catch or possess more than 6 hard crabs per container smaller than a barrel or 13 hard crabs per barrel which measure less than the minimum size specified in these regulations;
Possess hard crabs imported from another State which:
Measure less than 5 inches across the shell from tip to tip of the spike;
Do not comply with the tolerance limits of the jurisdiction of origin;
Are not accompanied by a bill of sale or bill of lading from the jurisdiction of origin; and
Were not caught in full compliance with the laws of the jurisdiction of origin;

From April 1 through July 14, catch or possess a hard crab which measures less than 5 inches across the shell from tip to tip of the spike, from the waters of the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries, except that the minimum size of crabs does not apply to mature female crabs, identified by the apron;

After July 14, catch or possess a hard crab which measures less than 5-1/4 inches across the shell from tip to tip of the spike from the waters of the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries, except that the minimum size of crabs does not apply to mature female crabs, identified by the apron;

Catch or possess a hard crab which measures less than 5 inches across the shell from tip to tip of the spike from the waters of Worcester County, except that the minimum size of crabs does not apply to mature female crabs, identified by the apron;
Except as provided in §E(7) of this regulation, catch or possess more than 10 peeler crabs per bushel or more than 20 per float which are:
Less than 3-1/4 inches across the shell from tip to tip of the spike during the period from April 1 through July 14; and
Less than 3-1/2 inches across the shell from tip to tip of the spike during the period from July 15 through December 15;

Catch or possess more than 10 female peeler crabs per bushel or more than 20 per float which are less than 3-1/2 inches across the shell from tip to tip of the spike in the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries during the period from April 1, 2015 through December 15, 2015; or
Catch or possess more than one soft crab per 2 dozen soft crabs which is less than 3-1/2 inches across the shell from tip to tip of the spike.
Limited Crab Harvester.
Latent Effort Limited Crab Harvester License.

A limited crab harvester (LCC) authorization of a tidal fish license that has no reported crab harvest between January 1, 2004 and December 15, 2008 on reports submitted to the Department by January 30, 2009, shall be determined to be a latent effort limited crab harvester license, except for those licenses specified in §F(1)(b) of this regulation.
Exceptions to Latent Effort Designation. The following are exceptions to the latent effort designation:
An LCC authorization received through the apprenticeship program;
An LCC authorization received through a permanent license transfer between August 1, 2006 and July 8, 2009;
An LCC authorization assigned to an individual who provides appropriate documentation of active military service during the period January 1, 2004 and January 30, 2009;
An LCC assigned to an individual who completed a successful female bushel limit hardship appeal in 2008; and
An LCC assigned to an individual who currently resides and has resided for at least 5 years on an island in the State that is at least 3 miles from the mainland.
Latent Effort Limited Crab Harvester Status.

An individual with a license that has been determined to be a latent effort license as described in §F(1) of this regulation is required to have declared their LCC license as a limited crab harvester — male only as described in §F(2)(b) of this regulation.
An individual with a limited crab harvester license — male only status:
Shall only harvest male crabs beginning on April 1, 2010;
May not harvest females at any time regardless of the blue crab population target level being achieved for 3 consecutive years;
Shall renew the license annually in accordance with the schedule and fees designated for a LCC authorization in Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland; and

May apply to the Department for a permanent or temporary transfer of the license through a family, business, or beneficiary transfer as described in Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland.
The latent effort license status may not be modified after declaration even if the license has been transferred to a new owner.
Conditions for using an LCC male only authorization as one of the required authorizations to upgrade to an unlimited tidal fish authorization are described in COMAR 08.02.01.05I.

Notwithstanding Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland, any LCC which was previously frozen due to latent license status as described in §F(1) of this regulation will not be required to pay the authorization fee for the 2012 commercial crabbing season.
Public Notice.

The Secretary may establish or modify catch limits or modify seasons for blue crabs in order to implement the Chesapeake Bay Blue Crab Fishery Management Plan by issuing a public notice on the Department's website.
The public notice shall state its effective hour and date and shall be published on the Department's website at least 48 hours in advance of the effective hour and date.

The Secretary shall make a reasonable effort to disseminate a public notice issued under this section through various other media so that an affected person has a reasonable opportunity to be informed.
A violation of the restrictions set by the Secretary in accordance with this section is a violation of this regulation.
This regulation applies to any trip to catch crabs offered by a tidal fish licensee to an individual or individuals for any form of compensation.
Any individual receiving compensation from customers for any trip to catch crabs shall be in possession of the appropriate federal licenses.

An individual who, in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland, is licensed as a fishing guide, is licensed as a master fishing guide or operates a vessel for a master fishing guide and possesses a valid commercial crabbing authorization:
May carry customers during a commercial crabbing trip;
Shall follow all commercial crabbing rules;
May not count customers as crew members;
May sell their catch to a seafood dealer or, if licensed as a seafood dealer in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland, to a customer;
Shall report their catch in accordance with COMAR 08.02.13.06; and
Shall be penalized for any violation of statute or regulation in accordance with COMAR 08.02.13.03
Crabbing Charters.

Definition. In this chapter, "crabbing charter" means any guided trip for the purpose of catching crabs recreationally, offered by an individual who, in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland, is licensed as a fishing guide or master fishing guide, or operates a vessel for a master fishing guide.
Crabbing Charter Decal.
Prior to operating a crabbing charter, a fishing guide shall obtain a crabbing charter decal.
Except as provided in §D(2)(c) of this regulation, a decal issued for a crabbing charter:
Shall be permanently affixed and displayed on either side of the forward half of the vessel for which issued;
Is not transferable;
Shall, when displayed, exempt all persons aboard from the requirement of possessing an individual license to crab recreationally; and
Is valid for the current commercial license year.

Exemption for Crabbing Charter Decals. If the crabbing charter decal is not permanently affixed to the vessel, all persons aboard are exempt from the requirement of possessing an individual license to crab recreationally only if:
The individual who purchased the crabbing charter decal is present on the vessel;
The individual who purchased the crabbing charter decal is in possession of the proof of purchase issued by the Department; and
The crabbing charter decal was purchased within the previous 10 calendar days.
A crabbing charter:

May only be offered by an individual licensed as a fishing guide or a master fishing guide, or who operates a vessel for a master fishing guide in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland;
Shall have at least one customer on board;
May not harvest female hard crabs or female peelers from the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries; and
Shall comply with the recreational season, times, size limits, and gear restrictions established in this chapter for a licensed recreational crabber.
Crabs caught on a crabbing charter may not be sold.
Catch Limit. A crabbing charter with one or more customers on board may not catch more than two bushels of:
Male hard crabs and two dozen soft crabs or male peeler crabs from the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries; or
Crabs from the Atlantic Ocean and its coastal bays.
Reporting. Crabs harvested on a crabbing charter shall be reported on forms provided by the Department and in the time specified by the Department.
Any violation of statute or regulation shall be penalized in accordance with COMAR 08.02.13.08.
A person may not use patent tongs to catch oysters in any of the waters listed in this section.
Tidal waters of the following counties, other than those waters included as part of the Chesapeake Bay, Tangier Sound, and Pocomoke Sound as defined by COMAR 08.02.01.06B:
Wicomico County;
Queen Anne's County, except as provided in §B(5) of this regulation;
Talbot County;
Dorchester County; and
Kent County, except as provided in §§B(1)-(4) of this regulation.
Patuxent River, except as provided in §B(6) of this regulation.
Tributaries of the Potomac River.

South River in Anne Arundel County north and west of a straight line drawn between Thomas Point defined by Lat. 38°54.440' N, Long. 76°27.610' W and Saunders Point defined by Lat. 38°53.190' N, Long. 76°29.440' W.

Chesapeake Bay. All of the waters of the Chesapeake Bay enclosed by a line beginning at a point on the shore at Richland Point defined by Lat. 38°14.846' N, Long. 76°10.332' W; then running 315° True to a point on the shore at the south end of Barren Island, defined by Lat. 38°19.460' N, Long. 76°15.430' W; then running 112° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°18.424' N, Long. 76°13.400' W; then running southeasterly along the shore to a point near the north end of the Narrows Ferry Bridge, defined by Lat. 38°17.917' N, Long. 76°12.389' W; then running 155° True to a point near the south end of the Narrows Ferry Bridge, defined by Lat. 38°17.676' N, Long. 76°12.250' W; then running southeasterly along the shore to the point of beginning.
Exceptions. A person may catch oysters by patent tong in the areas listed in this section.

Natural Oyster Bar 5-2: All of the waters enclosed by a line beginning at a point defined by Lat. 39°6.272' N, Long. 76°17.175' W; then running 335° True to a point defined by Lat. 39°6.765' N, Long. 76°17.464' W; then running 63° True to a point defined by Lat. 39°6.861' N, Long. 76°17.222' W; then running 143° True to a point defined by Lat. 39°6.575' N, Long. 76°16.944' W; then running 211° True to the point of beginning.

Natural Oyster Bar 2-9: All of the waters enclosed by a line beginning at a point defined by Lat. 39°7.507' N, Long. 76°18.981' W; then running 0° True to a point defined by Lat. 39°8.857' N, Long. 76°18.981' W; then running 38° True to a point defined by Lat. 39°11.002' N, Long. 76°16.858' W; then running 62° True to a point defined by Lat. 39°11.665' N, Long. 76°15.225' W; then running southwesterly along shore excluding all creeks and coves less than 300 feet in width to a point defined by Lat. 39°10.830' N, Long. 76°16.017' W; then running 240° True to a point defined by Lat. 39°10.508' N, Long. 76°16.732' W; then running 195° True to a point defined by Lat. 39°8.416' N, Long. 76°17.469' W; then running 168° True to a point defined by Lat. 39°7.602' N, Long. 76°17.245' W; then running 259° True to a point defined by Lat. 39°7.507' N, Long. 76°17.858' W; then running 270° True to the point of beginning.

Natural Oyster Bar 2-10: All of the waters enclosed by a line beginning at a point defined by Lat. 39°7.508' N, Long. 76°15.842' W; then running 349° True to a point defined by Lat. 39°7.736' N, Long. 76°15.899' W; then running 85° True to a point defined by Lat. 39°7.793' N, Long. 76°14.979' W; then running 180° True to a point defined by Lat. 39°7.503' N, Long. 76°14.982' W; then running 270° True to the point of beginning.

Natural Oyster Bar 5-1: All of the waters enclosed by a line beginning at a point defined by Lat. 39°7.349' N, Long. 76°18.981' W; then running 0° True to a point defined by Lat. 39°7.507' N, Long. 76°18.981' W; then running 90° True to a point defined by Lat. 39°7.507' N, Long. 76°17.858' W; then running 260° True to the point of beginning.

All of the waters of Eastern Bay south and west of a line beginning at a point defined by Lat. 38°49.904' N, Long. 76°20.384' W; then running 48° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°50.871' N, Long. 76°19.031' W; then running 115° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°50.746' N, Long. 76°18.686' W; then running 233° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°50.574' N, Long. 76°18.978' W; then running 201° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°48.693' N, Long. 76°19.884' W; then running 90° True to a point on shore, defined by Lat. 38°48.686' N, Long. 76°18.54' W; then running southerly along the shore to Lowes Point defined by Lat. 38°46.416' N, Long. 76°20.02' W; then running 323° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°47.861' N, Long. 76°21.394' W; then running 210° True to a point on Poplar Island defined by Lat. 38°46.553' N, Long. 76°22.342' W.

Patuxent River. All of the waters of the Patuxent River enclosed by a line beginning at a point on the shore at Hog Point defined by Lat. 38°18.586' N, Long. 76°23.993' W; then running westerly along the shore to a point on the shore at Fishing Point defined by Lat. 38°18.285' N, Long. 76°25.355' W; then running 345° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°18.525' N, Long. 76°25.434' W; then running 251° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°18.271' N, Long. 76°26.356' W; then running 196° True to a point on the shore, defined by Lat. 38°17.503' N, Long. 76°26.640' W; then running northwesterly along the shore to a point on shore at Sotterly Wharf, defined by Lat. 38°22.728' N, Long. 76°32.003' W; then running 77° True to a point near St Leonard's Creek Beacon, defined by Lat. 38°23.065' N, Long. 76°30.177' W; then running 77° True to a point on the shore, defined by Lat. 38°23.128' N, Long. 76°29.826' W; then running southeasterly along the shore to a point defined by Lat. 38°20.631' N, Long. 76°28.241' W; then running 282° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°20.638' N, Long. 76°28.287' W; then running 213° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°20.008' N, Long. 76°28.815' W; then running 132° True to a point on the shore, defined by Lat. 38°19.983' N, Long. 76°28.780' W; then running southeasterly along the shore to a point at the south entrance of Solomon's Harbor, defined by Lat. 38°19.263' N, Long. 76°27.103' W; then running 7° True to a point at the north entrance of Solomon's Harbor, defined by Lat. 38°19.370' N, Long. 76°27.087' W; then running approximately 307° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°22.552' N, Long. 76°31.580' W; then running approximately 28° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°22.612' N, Long. 76°31.540' W; then running approximately 127° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°22.540' N, Long. 76°31.420' W; then running approximately 208° True to the point of beginning.

The recreational season, daily catch limits, days of the week, and times for catching oysters shall be established, and may be modified, through a public notice issued in accordance with Regulation .11 of this chapter.
The Department shall issue a public notice that establishes the parameters described in §A of this regulation for the recreational oyster fishery not later than July 1 of each year.

Prohibition. Except as specified in this regulation and in any public notice issued in accordance with Regulation .11 of this chapter, it is illegal for a person to catch oysters for recreational purposes.
Lawful Methods. A person may catch oysters for recreational purposes only by hand, rake, shaft tong, or diving with or without scuba equipment.
A person may not take oysters for recreational purposes while aboard a vessel where any other person is engaged in commercial oystering.
Season, Days, and Catch Limits.

The season for catching oysters and the days of the week that an individual may catch oysters for commercial purposes shall be established for each gear type, and may be modified, through a public notice issued in accordance with Regulation .11 of this chapter.
The daily commercial catch limits shall be established for each gear type, and may be modified, through a public notice issued in accordance with Regulation .11 of this chapter.
The Department shall issue a public notice that establishes the parameters described in §A(1) and (2) of this regulation for the commercial oyster fishery not later than July 1 of each year.

Lawful Methods. A person may catch oysters for commercial purposes only by shaft tong, patent tong, diving apparatus, dredge boat, dredge boat propelled by means of an auxiliary yawl boat, or power dredge.
Times for Catching.
During an open season in November and December, a person may catch oysters for commercial purposes only from:
Sunrise until sunset when using shaft tong, patent tong, diving apparatus, dredge boat, or dredge boat propelled by means of an auxiliary yawl boat; and
Sunrise until 3 p.m. when using a power dredge.
Except as described in §C(1) of this regulation, during an open season a person may catch oysters for commercial purposes only from:
Sunrise until 3 p.m. when using shaft tong, patent tong, dredge boat, diving apparatus, or power dredge; and
Sunrise until sunset when using a dredge boat propelled by means of an auxiliary yawl boat.
An individual who harvests oysters for commercial purposes shall deliver oysters:
To a person who is licensed and certified to sell shellfish by the Maryland Department of Health in accordance with COMAR 10.15.04 and 10.15.07; and
Not later than 9 p.m. on the same day of harvest.
A person may not land or possess oysters on a vessel more than 2 hours after sunset or anytime before sunrise.
An individual shall notify the Natural Resources Police when there is an emergency which would prevent compliance with the times specified in §§C and D of this regulation.
Oysters may only be sold in accordance with COMAR 08.02.08.02.

In addition to the requirements of this chapter, a commercial licensee shall harvest oysters in accordance with the National Shellfish Sanitation Program Model Ordinance that is incorporated by reference by the Maryland Department of Health in COMAR 10.15.07.01A.
Containers.
Oysters harvested from waters of the State shall be stored prior to leaving the bar from which they were harvested in a:
Metal oyster tub that does not exceed the following inside dimensions:
18 inches top diameter;
16-1/2 inches bottom diameter; and
12 inches height;
Rectangular shaped container that does not exceed the following inside dimensions:
12-5/8 inches width across the top;
12 inches width across the bottom;
20 inches in length; and
11-1/4 inches height;
Round container that does not exceed the following inside dimensions:
16-1/2 inches top diameter;
13-1/2 inches bottom diameter; and
14-1/4 inches height; or

Container with dimensions approved in writing by the Department which shall have a volume that is comparable to the containers described in §A(1)(a)—(c) of this regulation, and, upon request, the Department's letter approving the container shall be displayed to any Natural Resources Police officer.
A container described in §A(1) of this regulation shall be:
Made of a rigid, open mesh;
Made of smooth, impervious, corrosion-resistant, and non-toxic materials which will not readily disintegrate or crack;
Constructed so that it may be easily cleaned and kept in good repair; and
Constructed to allow either one side or one end to be opened to unload or inspect the oysters.
Oysters stored in accordance with §A(1)(a) and (b) of this regulation may not extend beyond the top of the container.
Oysters stored in accordance with §A of this regulation shall remain in the original container until a tag is no longer required on the container in accordance with §D(1)(d) of this regulation.
Oysters on board a skipjack harvested in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-1013, Annotated Code of Maryland, from:
Only one bar are exempt from §A(1)—(3) of this regulation; or
More than one bar may have oysters from one bar not in containers and all other oysters from different bars shall follow the container requirements of §A(1)—(4) of this regulation.
Tagging of Individual Containers.

Except as provided in §B(3) of this regulation, an individual storing oysters in accordance with §A(1)—(3) of this regulation shall complete and affix a Department-issued tag to each container of oysters prior to leaving the bar from which the oysters were harvested.

Except as provided in §B(3) of this regulation, an individual storing oysters in accordance with §A(5) of this regulation shall complete one Department-issued tag for the group of oysters not in containers and affix a Department-issued tag to each container of oysters prior to leaving the bar from which the oysters were harvested.
An individual storing oysters in accordance with §A(1)—(3) or (5) of this regulation may use a tag not supplied by the Department if:
The individual:
Is licensed and certified to sell shellfish by the Maryland Department of Health in accordance with COMAR 10.15.04 and 10.15.07; and
Follows the tagging requirements of the National Shellfish Sanitation Program Model Ordinance, incorporated by reference by the Maryland Department of Health in COMAR 10.15.07.01; or
Each tag the individual uses contains the statement "Wild Shellfish", the state in which the harvest occurred, and, in the order specified, the following information:
The harvester's license number as assigned by the Department;
The date of harvest, including the year;
The bar name;
The name of the region or the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration code for the area in which the harvest occurred;
The type and quantity of shellfish; and
The statement "THIS TAG IS REQUIRED TO BE ATTACHED UNTIL CONTAINER IS EMPTY OR IS RETAGGED AND THEREAFTER KEPT ON FILE FOR 90 DAYS" in bold capitalized type.
Bulk Tagging.
Definitions.
In this regulation, the following terms have the meaning indicated.
"Bulk tag" means a tag that provides the necessary information as required by the National Shellfish Sanitation Program Model Ordinance for a single lot of oysters.
"Single lot" means oysters coming from a single oyster bar, harvested during a single trip on a single day by a single harvester.

Except as provided in §C(3) of this regulation, an individual storing oysters in accordance with §A(1)—(3) of this regulation may complete and affix a Department-issued bulk tag to a single container of oysters prior to leaving the bar from which the oysters were harvested.
An individual storing oysters in accordance with §A(1)—(3) or (5) of this regulation may use a bulk tag not supplied by the Department if:
The individual:
Is licensed and certified to sell shellfish by the Maryland Department of Health in accordance with COMAR 10.15.04 and 10.15.07; and
Follows the tagging requirements of the National Shellfish Sanitation Program Model Ordinance, incorporated by reference by the Maryland Department of Health in COMAR 10.15.07.01; or
Each tag the individual uses contains the statement "Wild Shellfish", the state in which the harvest occurred, and, in the order specified, the following information:
The harvester's license number as assigned by the Department;
The date of harvest, including the year;
The bar name;
The name of the region or the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration code for the area in which the harvest occurred;
The type of shellfish;
The statement "THIS TAG IS REQUIRED TO BE ATTACHED UNTIL CONTAINER IS EMPTY OR IS RETAGGED AND THEREAFTER KEPT ON FILE FOR 90 DAYS" in bold capitalized type;
The following statement in bold capitalized letters: "ALL SHELLFISH CONTAINERS IN THIS LOT HAVE THE SAME HARVEST DATE AND ARE FROM A SINGLE AREA OF HARVEST"; and
The number of individual containers in the lot.
If one licensee is present on the vessel, only one bulk tag may be used.
If a bulk tag is used, the vessel may only harvest from one bar on that day.
Tagging Provisions for Both Tagging of Individual Containers and Bulk Tags.
Tags:
Shall be durable and waterproof;
Shall be at least 5-1/2 x 2-3/4 inches in size;
Shall be completed legibly in indelible ink;

Shall stay affixed to the container until the container is in the possession of a person who is licensed and certified to sell shellfish by the Maryland Department of Health in accordance with COMAR 10.15.04 and 10.15.07; and
May not be reused.

In addition to the tagging requirements of this regulation, a person who is licensed and certified to sell shellfish by the Maryland Department of Health in accordance with COMAR 10.15.04 and 10.15.07 shall follow the tagging requirements of the National Shellfish Sanitation Program Model Ordinance, incorporated by reference by the Maryland Department of Health in COMAR 10.15.07.01.
An individual shall only possess one type of tag, wild shellfish or farm-raised shellfish, while harvesting oysters.
Only one type of tag, individual or bulk, may be present on a vessel while harvesting oysters.
An individual may not use a farm-raised shellfish tag to tag wild shellfish.
An individual may not use a wild shellfish tag to tag farm-raised shellfish.
If a tidal fish licensee obtains tags from the Department, the licensee shall be assessed an annual surcharge for the costs incurred by the Department for the tags.
Exemptions.
Oysters harvested for recreational purposes and not for sale are exempt from the requirements of §§A — D of this regulation.
Oysters harvested from a lease and stored and tagged in accordance with COMAR 08.02.23 are exempt from the requirements of §§A — D of this regulation.

section.heading: Use of Diving Apparatus to Catch Oysters Commercially.

para.text: General Requirements.

When using diving apparatus to catch oysters for commercial purposes, the diver or the diver's attendant shall be authorized to catch oysters for commercial purposes in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland.
Not more than two divers may work from a boat at one time.
Each diver shall have one attendant on the boat.
If there is more than one diver on the boat, a different attendant shall be present for each diver.
A diving flag that is a rigid replica of the International Code Flag "A" not less than 1 meter in height shall be displayed while the diver is in the water.
Distances Required. A person may not conduct a shellfish harvesting operation within 50 feet of a vessel involved in a diving operation.
Power assisted lifting devices including, but not limited to, hydraulic winders or motor driven windlasses may be used subject to the following conditions:
The total length of cable or rope on the winding apparatus may not exceed 100 feet; or

The container used when lifting the oysters from the bottom to the vessel shall be rigged with a self-closing lid that is automatically held in the closed position by the pressure of the retrieval line while the container is being retrieved.

Eligibility for Oyster Committee Members. A licensed oyster harvester who has paid the oyster license surcharge for the current license year or for at least one of the previous two license years is eligible to be a representative on a county oyster committee.
Balloting Procedure.
When an election for a county is to be held, the Department shall publish notice of the election on the Department's website. The notice shall state the ballot procedure.

A licensed oyster harvester may vote only for the oyster committee candidates for the county in which the licensed oyster harvester resides. The elections shall be conducted by the Department and shall be by secret ballot. After the election has been closed, the Department shall tally and announce the results. The persons receiving the most votes shall be elected to the vacancies on the committee, and the Department shall notify those persons of their election by certified mail. If a person elected is unable or unwilling to serve on the committee, the person receiving the highest number of votes who is able or willing to serve shall be elected.

If a vacancy cannot be filled because two or more persons have received an equal number of votes, the representative shall be selected by a process determined by the Department in consultation with the current oyster committee of the county in which the tie occurred.

If a county has less than five licensed oyster harvesters who are eligible to be a committee representative, then all of the eligible licensed oyster harvesters of that county shall constitute the respective committee.
Except as listed in §B of this regulation a person may catch oysters by a dredge boat, as defined in Natural Resources Article, §4-1001(g), Annotated Code of Maryland, only in the following waters:

All of the waters of Hoopers Straits enclosed by a line beginning at a point defined by Lat. 38°11.923' N, Long. 76°5.674' W; then running 309° True to a point defined by the shore of Richland Point defined by Lat. 38°14.846' N, Long. 76°10.332' W; then running easterly along the shore of Lower Hoopers Island to a point defined by Lat. 38°13.968' N, Long. 76°7.871' W; then running 92° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°13.93' N, Long. 76°6.66' W; then running 150° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°13.203' N, Long. 76°6.122' W; then running 165° True to the point of beginning;

then running 106° True to a point on the east side of La Trappe Creek, defined by Lat. 38°37.62' N, Long. 76°6.997' W; then running southerly along the shore to a point at the south end of Howell Point defined by Lat. 38°36.675' N, Long. 76°6.646' W; then running 254° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°36.479' N, Long. 76°7.652' W; then running 308° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°36.557' N, Long. 76°7.780' W; then running 250° True to a point defined by Lat. 38° 36.507' N, Long. 76° 7.92' W; then running 320° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°36.534' N, Long. 76°7.949' W; then running 333° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°36.671' N, Long. 76°8.039' W; then running 349° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°36.846' N, Long. 76°8.08' W; then running 360° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°37.26' N, Long. 76°8.084' W; then running 356° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°37.496' N, Long. 76°8.108' W; then running 345° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°37.81' N, Long. 76°8.212' W; then running 308° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°37.866' N, Long. 76°8.302' W; then running 286° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°37.89' N, Long. 76°8.408' W; then running 272° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°37.898' N, Long. 76°8.684' W; then running 267° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°37.884' N, Long. 76°9.023' W; then running 283° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°37.933' N, Long. 76°9.296' W; then running 302° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°38.095' N, Long. 76°9.631' W; then running 314° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°38.536' N, Long. 76°10.221' W; then running 303° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°38.68' N, Long. 76°10.498' W; then running 288° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°38.789' N, Long. 76°10.919' W; then running 271° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°38.79' N, Long. 76°11.095' W; then running 240° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°38.732' N, Long. 76°11.226' W; then running 251° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°38.576' N, Long. 76°11.793' W; then running 264° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°38.518' N, Long. 76°12.494' W; then running 278° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°38.562' N, Long. 76°12.874' W; then running 292° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°38.664' N, Long. 76°13.197' W; then running 218° True to a point on the shore at Todds Point defined by Lat. 38°37.683' N, Long. 76°14.168' W; then running 267° True to a point on the shore at Cooks Point defined by Lat. 38°37.581' N, Long. 76°17.109' W; then running southerly along the shore to a point defined by Lat. 38°37.453' N, Long. 76°17.045' W; then running 120° True to a point on the shore, defined by Lat. 38°37.426' N, Long. 76°16.984' W; then running southerly and westerly along the shore of Trippe Bay and Brannock Bay to a point at Hills Point defined by Lat. 38°34.358' N, Long. 76°18.292' W; then running 107° True to the point of beginning, excluding the area defined as Cook Point Sanctuary in Regulation .15A of this chapter;
All the waters of Somerset County except as provided in §B(1)-(5) of this regulation.

Talbot County. All of the waters bayward of a line beginning at Kent Point, defined by Lat. 38°50.180' N, Long. 76°22.100' W; then running approximately 102° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°49.904' N, Long. 76°20.384' W; then running approximately 48° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°50.871' N, Long. 76°19.031' W; then running approximately 115° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°50.564' N, Long. 76°18.203' W; then running approximately 163° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°49.702' N, Long. 76°17.865' W; then running southwesterly along the shore to a point defined by Lat. 38°46.416' N, Long. 76°20.020' W; then running approximately 323° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°47.861' N, Long. 76°21.394' W; then running approximately 210° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°46.553' N, Long. 76°22.342' W.

Wicomico River. All of the waters of the Wicomico River easterly of a straight line drawn from a point defined by Lat. 38°10.767' N, Long. 75°57.004' W; then running 343° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°12.311' N, Long. 75°57.587' W.

Tangier Sound. All of the waters east of Smith Island south and west of a line drawn in an easterly course from Terrapin Sands Point on the west side of Tangier Sound, defined by Lat. 38°0.247' N, Long. 75°58.181' W; then running 94° True to the channel, to a point defined by Lat. 38° 0.008' N, Long. 75° 54.977' W; and then running 200° True following the channel in a southerly direction to a point defined by Lat. 37°57.845' N, Long. 75°55.770' W; then running 190° following the channel to the Virginia Line, to a point defined by Lat. 37°54.453' N, Long. 75°56.413' W.
Chesapeake Bay. All areas described in Natural Resources Article, §4-1012(a), Annotated Code of Maryland.

section.heading: Areas Reserved for Hand Tonging, Exceptions.
section.text: Except in areas established as oyster sanctuaries in Regulation .15A of this chapter or power dredge areas in Regulation .12B of this chapter, oysters may be taken only by hand tongs in the following areas, except that scooping, dredging, or scraping by hand may be permitted by the Department in certain areas reserved for hand tonging when watermen are denied access to oyster taking because of icing conditions.

para.text: Wicomico River, Charles and St. Mary's Counties: All the waters north of a line beginning at the southern tip of Cobb Island, defined by Lat. 38°15.307' N, Long. 76°50.532' W; then running 46° True to a point defined by Lat. 38° 16.193'N, Long. 76° 49.359' W, then running 22° True to a point defined by, Lat. 38° 16.272' N, Long. 76° 49.318' W, then running 18° True to a point defined by, Lat. 38° 16.645' N, Long. 76° 49.164' W, then running 41° True to a point defined by, Lat. 38° 16.943' N, Long. 76° 48.839' W, then running 104° True to a point at or near the shore southeast of Bushwood Wharf defined by, Lat. 38° 16.800'N, Long. 76° 48.128' W.

section.heading: Dredging with an Auxiliary Yawl Boat.

para.text: A dredge boat may be propelled by means of an auxiliary yawl boat carried on the dredge boat to catch oysters in areas where dredge boats are permitted, except in:

The waters upstream of a line in the Choptank River extending from a point at or near Martin Point defined by Lat. 38°37.695' N, Long. 76°7.323' W; then running approximately 212° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°36.791' N, Long. 76°8.067' W;

All of the waters enclosed by a line beginning at or near Kent Point, defined by Lat. 38°50.180' N, Long. 76°22.100' W; then running approximately 183° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°50.036' N, Long. 76°22.108' W; then running approximately 269° True to a point at or near Bloody Point Lighthouse defined by Lat. 38°50.027' N, Long. 76°23.511' W; then running approximately 354° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°51.958' N, Long. 76°23.547' W; then running approximately 4° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°56.762' N, Long. 76°22.807' W; then running approximately 19° True to a point south of the William Preston Lane Jr. Memorial Bridge defined by Lat. 38°59.311' N, Long. 76°21.908' W; then running approximately 102° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°58.911' N, Long. 76°20.087' W; then running southerly along the shore to the point of beginning; or
Areas established as oyster sanctuaries in Regulation .15A of this chapter.

A dredge boat may be propelled in accordance with §A of this regulation for not more than 2 of the days of the week, specified by public notice, that a person may catch oysters for commercial purposes during the season for dredging oysters.
Notice shall be provided to the Department in advance of each day a dredge boat is propelled in accordance with §A of this regulation.
Definitions.
In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
Bushel means an amount of oysters that would fill a container that meets the requirements of Regulation .04A of this chapter.
"Marketable oyster" means an oyster that measures at least 3 inches in length from hinge to bill.
Oyster Harvest Area.
"Oyster harvest area" means submerged ground where an individual may catch oysters.

"Oyster harvest area" does not include an area leased for aquaculture, restricted by the Maryland Department of the Environment, or designated as a submerged aquatic vegetation protection zone, harvest reserve area, or sanctuary.
"Spat" means an oyster that measures less than 1 inch in length from hinge to bill.
"Undersized oyster" means an oyster that measures at least 1 inch in length from hinge to bill and less than 3 inches in length from hinge to bill.
This chapter does not apply in areas leased for shellfish cultivation under Natural Resources Article, Title 4, Subtitle 11A, Annotated Code of Maryland.
Oyster Culling.

A person who catches oysters shall cull the oysters on the natural bar from which they were caught and return every shell to the bar. Any oysters whose shell measures less than 3 inches in length, from hinge to bill, shall be included in the culling and replaced upon the bar from which caught.

Except as provided in §C(4) and (5) of this regulation, any oyster whose shell measures less than 3 inches in length, from hinge to bill, shall be included in the culling and replaced upon the bar from which caught.
A person may not possess more than 5 percent shells and oysters less than the allowable size specified in §C(2) of this regulation.
A person may possess marketable oysters that have undersized oysters attached to them that cannot be separated without destroying the undersized oyster.
A person may possess marketable oysters that have spat attached to them.
Fees for Moving Oyster Seed.

Subject to the other conditions and terms agreed to each year, the rates to be paid by the Department to any person for the moving of oyster seed shall be adjusted yearly in coordination with the hiring of the captains to move the seed.
A captain hired to move seed shall be notified of the rates by certified mail.
Fees for Purchasing, Hauling, and Planting Fresh Oyster Shell.

Subject to other conditions and terms agreed to each year, the rate to be paid by the Department to any person for the hauling and planting of fresh oyster shell shall be established by public notice in accordance with §G of this regulation, based on current fair market value.
The rate to be paid to purchase fresh oyster shell shall be established by public notice in accordance with §G of this regulation, based on current fair market value.
A licensed commercial oyster harvester may not have more than one type of oyster harvest gear on board a vessel with oysters on board.
General.

Notwithstanding Natural Resources Article, §§4-1004, 4-1008.1, 4-1009, 4-1013, and 4-1015.1, Annotated Code of Maryland, in order to implement the Maryland Chesapeake Bay Oyster Management Plan, the Secretary may issue a public notice to:
Establish or modify the season, daily catch limits, days of the week, or times for catching oysters for recreational or commercial purposes;
Open or close an oyster harvest area for the harvesting or conservation of oysters; or
Establish or modify the rates to be paid for the purchase, hauling, and planting of fresh oyster shell.
A public notice issued to implement §G(1)(b) of this regulation shall state:
The specific area;
The specific period of time that the area is opened or closed;
Daily bushel limits; and
The days of the week a person may catch oysters in the area.
A public notice shall state its effective hour and date and shall be published on the Department's website at least 48 hours in advance of the effective hour and date.

The Secretary shall make a reasonable effort to disseminate a public notice issued under §G of this regulation through various other media so that an affected individual has a reasonable opportunity to be informed.
A violation of the restrictions set by the Secretary in accordance with §G of this regulation is a violation of this regulation.
General.
Notwithstanding Natural Resources Article, §4-1012(b), Annotated Code of Maryland, a power dredge may only be used in the following areas:
Leased areas;
Power Dredge Zones established in §B of this regulation;
Power Dredge Study Areas established in §C of this regulation; and
Portions of the Wild Grounds Study Area established in §D(1) of this regulation that have been opened in accordance with §E of this regulation.
A person may not use or possess a power dredge bar that is more than 42 inches in length measuring from the outside teeth or that exceeds a weight of 200 pounds.

then running southerly along the shore to a point on the shore at Holland Point defined by Lat. 38°41.879' N, Long. 76°13.611' W; then running 186° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°41.838' N, Long. 76°13.617' W; then running 92° True to a point on the shore at Lucy Point defined by Lat. 38°41.825' N, Long. 76°13.178' W; then running southeasterly to a point on the shore of Ferry Neck, defined by Lat. 38°40.354' N, Long. 76°12.083' W; then running 144° True to a point on the shore at Benoni Point defined by Lat. 38°40.249' N, Long. 76°11.969' W; then running 96° True to a point on the shore at the north side of Boone Creek, defined by Lat. 38°40.090' N, Long. 76°10.138' W; then running 118° True to a point on the shore at the south side of Boone Creek, defined by Lat. 38°40.011' N, Long. 76°9.954' W; then running then running southeasterly along the shore to a point on the shore at the north side of Island Creek, defined by Lat. 38°39.697' N, Long. 76°9.699' W; then running 120° True to a point on the shore at the south side of Island Creek, defined by Lat. 38°39.517' N, Long. 76°9.300' W; then running southeasterly along the shore to the point of beginning.
Power Dredge Study Areas. An individual may catch oysters only by power dredge in the areas listed in §C(1)-(3) of this regulation.
Queen Anne's County Power Dredge Study Areas:

All of the waters of Eastern Bay enclosed by a line beginning at a point defined by Lat. 38°53.805' N, Long. 76°15.450' W; then running 274° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°53.831' N, Long. 76°15.920' W; then running 313° True to a point defined by Lat. 38° 54.060' N, Long. 76° 16.230' W; then running 53° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°54.482' N, Long. 76°15.511' W; then running 91° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°54.476' N, Long. 76°15.059' W; then running 199° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°54.130' N, Long. 76°15.213' W; then running 210° True to the point of beginning; and

All of the waters of Eastern Bay enclosed by a line beginning at a point defined by Lat. 38°52.672' N, Long. 76°18.659' W; then running 304° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°52.995' N, Long. 76°19.265' W; then running 36° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°53.465' N, Long. 76°18.825' W; then running 122° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°53.160' N, Long. 76°18.211' W; then running 216° True to the point of beginning.

Kent County Power Dredge Study Area. All of the waters of the Chesapeake Bay enclosed by a line beginning at a point defined by Lat. 39°7.690' N, Long. 76°18.868' W; then running 5° True to a point defined by Lat. 39°8.482' N, Long. 76°18.772' W; then running 111° True to a point defined by Lat. 39°8.258' N, Long. 76°18.038' W; then running 111° True to a point defined by Lat. 39°8.114' N, Long. 76°17.546' W; then running 170° True to a point defined by Lat. 39°7.603' N, Long. 76°17.432' W; then running 272° True to a point defined by Lat. 39°7.623' N, Long. 76°18.167' W; then running 277° True to the point of beginning.

Dorchester County Power Dredge Study Area. All of the waters of Holland Straits enclosed by a line beginning at a point defined by Lat. 38°6.359' N, Long. 76°3.752' W, then running 273° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°6.385' N, Long. 76°4.481' W, then running 2° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°6.840' N, Long. 76°4.463' W, then running 95° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°6.790' N, Long. 76°3.749' W, then running 180° True to the point of beginning.
Wild Grounds Study Area.

The study area consists of all of the waters of Eastern Bay enclosed by a line beginning at a point defined by Lat. 38°53.160' N, Long. 76°18.211' W; then running 302° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°53.465' N, Long. 76°18.825' W; then running 36° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°53.633' N, Long. 76°18.668' W; then running 124° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°53.320' N, Long. 76°18.063' W; then running 216° True to the point of beginning.
A commercial licensee may not harvest oysters with a power dredge in this area unless authorized by public notice in accordance with §E of this regulation.
Public Notice.
In order to evaluate the potential effects of power dredging, the Department may, by public notice:
Open or close portions of the areas defined in §§C(2) and D(1) of this regulation to the harvest of oysters; or
Specify gear that may be used in portions of the area defined in §D(1) of this regulation.
If it is determined necessary to maintain surface shell, the Department may by public notice establish the following:
Portions of the areas defined in §§C(2) and D(1) of this regulation in which maintenance is necessary;
Allowable gears for maintenance;
A requirement to receive prior written permission by the Department to perform maintenance on the area;
Number of licensees who may perform maintenance on the area; and
Dates and times during which the maintenance may be performed.
The public notice shall state its effective hour and date and shall be published on the Fisheries Service website at least 48 hours in advance of the effective hour and date.

The Secretary shall make a reasonable effort to disseminate a public notice issued under this section through various other media so that an affected individual has a reasonable opportunity to be informed.
A violation of the restrictions set by the Secretary in accordance with this section is a violation of this regulation.

Oyster Sanctuaries of the Chesapeake Bay and Its Tidal Tributaries (September 2010) designates oyster sanctuaries in the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries and is hereby incorporated by reference.
Harvest from a Sanctuary.
A person may not harvest wild oysters from a sanctuary established in §A of this regulation.

Except as provided in §B(3) of this regulation, a person may not harvest clams from a sanctuary designated in Section I of "Oyster Sanctuaries of the Chesapeake Bay and Its Tidal Tributaries (September 2010)" that is incorporated by reference in §A of this regulation.
A person may harvest clams from the Chester ORA Zone A sanctuary.
Aquaculture in Sanctuaries.
Except as provided in §C(2) of this regulation, a shellfish lease may not be located within 150 feet of a Yates Bar located in an oyster sanctuary established in §A of this regulation.

Until termination in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-11A-10, Annotated Code of Maryland or surrender in accordance with COMAR 08.02.23.03J, leased areas and all areas within 150 feet of the leased areas existing at the time of the enactment of Ch. 173, Acts of 2009 shall not be considered part of the sanctuaries as established in §A of this regulation.

A leaseholder under Natural Resources Article, §4-11A, Annotated Code of Maryland, or permit registrant under COMAR 08.02.23.04 shall notify the Department as specified on the Shellfish Aquaculture Harvester Permit 48 hours in advance of using a power dredge in areas described in §A or C(2) of this regulation.
No more than 10 percent of each oyster sanctuary established in §A of this regulation shall be leased for shellfish aquaculture.
St. Mary's River Oyster Sanctuary.
The Department shall, based on the results of the Maryland Geological Survey's 2010 sonar survey, post on its website a map of the areas of restorable bottom in the St. Mary's River Oyster Sanctuary.

A lease may only be issued in the St. Mary's River Oyster Sanctuary if the results of a biological survey approved by the Department indicate the average oyster density is less than 15 oysters per square meter in:
The restorable bottom portion of the proposed lease area; and
The remaining bottom in the proposed lease area.
No more than 25 percent of the total restorable bottom in the St. Mary's River Oyster Sanctuary shall be leased for shellfish aquaculture purposes.

section.heading: Recording the Catching and Disposal of Oysters - Repealed.

para.text: Public Shellfish Fishery Areas of the Chesapeake Bay and Its Tidal Tributaries (June 2023) designates public shellfish fishery areas in the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries and is hereby incorporated by reference.
Declassification.

A person may petition the Department to declassify a portion of a public shellfish fishery area by submitting a lease application as described in COMAR 08.02.23.03A or B and Natural Resources Article, §4-11A-09, Annotated Code of Maryland.
The declassification of a public shellfish fishery area may be approved:

If the results of a biological survey conducted by the Department or a designated agent show that the average density of oysters per square meter is equal to or below the maximum threshold of one oyster that is 1 inch or greater per square meter;
After commercial harvest activity and other quantitative data is considered by the Department;
If the lease application meets the requirements of COMAR 08.02.23.03; and
If the lease application is approved in accordance with Natural Resources Article, Title 4, Subtitle 11A, Annotated Code of Maryland.

container.heading: Fish
container.text: Authority: Natural Resources Article, §§4-2A-03, 4-215, 4-219, 4-221, 4-710, 4-713, and 4-736, Annotated Code of Maryland

para.text: Except as provided in §B of this regulation, a person may not set or fish gill nets, including but not limited to anchor gill nets, staked gill nets, and drift gill nets, in the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries.
A person may set and fish:
During the period between March 16 through December 31, attended drift gill nets with a stretched mesh size of 2-1/2 to 3-1/2 inches;
During the period between January 1 through March 15, attended drift gill nets with a stretched mesh of 3-1/8 to 3-1/2 inches;
Gill nets as permitted in COMAR 08.02.15; or
Gill nets made with monofilament, multifilament, or multi-strand materials.
Within 1,200 feet of any pier that supports either span of the William Preston Lane Jr. Memorial Bay Bridge, a person may not:
Fish with a treble hook that is not an intrinsic part of a floating fish lure; or
Set or fish any type of gill net during the period May 1 through October 31.

During the period June 1 through October 31, a person may not set or fish any type of gill net in the Chesapeake Bay, excluding tributaries, in the area south of a line drawn from Howell Point to Taylor Island Point in the Upper Bay and north of a line from Kent Point to Curtis Point in the mouth of West River.

A person may not use eels as bait while fishing with hook and line in the tidal waters of the Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries, except for a recreational, charter, or commercial hook and line fisherman authorized to participate in and fish during summer and fall striped bass seasons established in COMAR 08.02.15.
During the period March 1 through June 30, a person may not set or fish any type of gill net:
In the striped bass spawning reaches listed in COMAR 08.02.15.03C;
In the Susquehanna Flats upstream of a line from Sandy Point to Turkey Point;
In the Susquehanna and Northeast Rivers; and
