North by a line beginning at a point at Tenth Point at the mouth of Big Annemessex River defined by Lat. 38°02.303' N, Long. 75°51.610' W; then running 334° True to a point at Porpoise Point defined by Lat. 38°03.648' N, Long. 75°52.422' W; then running along shore to a point at Hazard Point defined by Lat. 38°04.571' N, Long. 75° 52.694' W; then running 307° True to a point at South Point on Little Deal Island defined by Lat. 38°06.710' N, Long. 75°56.460' W; then running 238° True to a point at Mussel Hole Point defined by Lat. 38°04.670' N, Long. 76°00.400' W; then running 194° True to a point on the shore on the northerly tip of Smith Island defined by Lat. 38°02.367' N, Long. 76°01.050' W; and

Pocomoke Sound that are southwesterly of a straight line drawn from Maryland-Virginia boundary marker "D" defined by Lat. 37°56.473' N, Long. 75° 45.705' W; then running 342° True to a point at the most easterly point of the sound at the mouth of Gunby Creek defined by Lat. 37°58.410' N, Long. 75°46.498' W, except as provided in §C of this regulation.

Exception. Hard-shell clams may not be taken with a dredge in the waters of Apes Hole Creek westerly of a line drawn from a point at Cedar Gut defined by Lat. 37°57.448' N, Long. 75°48.752' W; then running 215° True to a point at Long Point defined by Lat. 37°56.854' N, Long. 75° 49.283 W.
An individual may not catch hard-shell clams for commercial purposes on Sunday.
An individual may not possess more than 10 percent of hard-shell clams per container with a transverse dimension of less than 1 inch.
Times for Harvesting, Landing, and Delivering.
From May 1 through September 30, an individual harvesting hard-shell clams for commercial purposes:
Shall land hard-shell clams not later than 3 p.m. on the same day of harvest; and
Shall deliver hard-shell clams:
To a person who is licensed and certified to sell shellfish by the Maryland Department of Health in accordance with COMAR 10.15.04 and 10.15.07; and
Not later than 4 p.m. on the same day of harvest.
From October 1 through April 30, an individual harvesting hard-shell clams for commercial purposes:
Shall land hard-shell clams not later than 1 hour after sunset on the same day of harvest; and
Shall deliver hard-shell clams:
To a person who is licensed and certified to sell shellfish by the Maryland Department of Health in accordance with COMAR 10.15.04 and 10.15.07; and
Not later than 9 p.m. on the same day of harvest.
An individual shall notify the Natural Resources Police when there is an emergency which would prevent compliance with the times specified in this section.

In addition to the requirements of this chapter, a commercial licensee who harvests hard-shell clams shall harvest hard-shell clams in accordance with the National Shellfish Sanitation Program Model Ordinance that is incorporated by reference by the Maryland Department of Health in COMAR 10.15.07.01A.
Definition.
In this regulation, the following term has the meaning indicated.
Term Defined. "Growing area" means the location, defined by the specific NOAA code for the area in which the harvest occurred.
Containers. Hard-shell clams harvested for commercial purposes shall:
Be stored prior to leaving the growing area from which they were harvested in a container of any size or dimension; and
Remain in the original container until a tag is no longer required on the container in accordance with §C(3)(d) of this regulation.
Tagging.
An individual shall complete and affix a Department-issued tag to each container of hard-shell clams prior to leaving the growing area from which they were harvested.
An individual may use a tag not supplied by the Department if:
The individual:
Is licensed and certified to sell shellfish by the Maryland Department of Health in accordance with COMAR 10.15.04 and 10.15.07; and
Follows the tagging requirements of the National Shellfish Sanitation Program Model Ordinance, incorporated by reference by the Maryland Department of Health in COMAR 10.15.07.01; and
Each tag the individual uses contains the statement "Wild Shellfish", the state in which the harvest occurred, and, in the order specified, the following information:
The harvester's license number as assigned by the Department;
The date of harvest, including the year;
The name of the river, region, or the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration code for the area in which the harvest occurred;
The type and quantity of shellfish; and
The statement "THIS TAG IS REQUIRED TO BE ATTACHED UNTIL CONTAINER IS EMPTY OR IS RETAGGED AND THEREAFTER KEPT ON FILE FOR 90 DAYS" in bold capitalized type.
Tags:
Shall be durable and waterproof;
Shall be at least 5-½ x 2-¾ inches in size;
Shall be completed legibly in indelible ink;

Shall stay affixed to the container until the container is in the possession of a person who is licensed and certified to sell shellfish by the Maryland Department of Health in accordance with COMAR 10.15.04 and 10.15.07; and
May not be reused.

In addition to the tagging requirements of this regulation, a person who is licensed and certified to sell shellfish by the Maryland Department of Health in accordance with COMAR 10.15.04 and 10.15.07 shall follow the tagging requirements of the National Shellfish Sanitation Program Model Ordinance, incorporated by reference by the Maryland Department of Health in COMAR 10.15.07.01.
An individual shall only possess one type of tag, wild shellfish or farm-raised shellfish, while harvesting hard-shell clams.
An individual may not use a:
Farm-raised shellfish tag to tag wild shellfish; or
Wild shellfish tag to tag farm-raised shellfish.
If a tidal fish licensee obtains tags from the Department, the licensee shall be assessed an annual surcharge for the costs incurred by the Department for the tags.
Exemptions.
Hard-shell clams harvested recreationally for the person's own use and consumption are exempt from the requirements of §B of this regulation.
Hard-shell clams harvested from a lease and stored and tagged in accordance with COMAR 08.02.23.04 are exempt from the requirements of §§B and C of this regulation.
Size Limit.
Except as provided in Regulation .03B of this chapter, a person may not possess hard-shell clams harvested from State waters with a transverse dimension of less than 1 inch.
Gear. The use of hand-held gear is permitted in the Atlantic Ocean and Coastal Bays.
Prohibited Areas and Exception. An individual may not harvest hard-shell clams within 150 feet of a:
Natural oyster bar;
Leased area;
Public shellfish fishery area established in COMAR 08.02.04.17A; or
Sanctuary designated in Section I of "Oyster Sanctuaries of the Chesapeake Bay and Its Tidal Tributaries (September 2010)" that is incorporated by reference in COMAR 08.02.04.15A.
Subject to §C of this regulation, an individual may catch hard-shell clams only from waters approved for shellfish harvest by the Maryland Department of the Environment.
Definition. In this regulation, the term "shellfish" includes live oysters, seed oysters, oyster shells, live hard-shell clams, live soft-shell clams, and clam shells.

Permit Required. A person may not import or possess within the State shellfish taken from waters outside the waters of the State for planting in the waters of the State, unless he first obtains a permit from the Department. The Department shall issue a permit if presented with proof satisfactory to the Department that the shellfish will not be harmful to Maryland shellfish.

Zebra Mussel. Except as permitted by the Secretary of Natural Resources, a person may not import into the State or possess any living life stage or reproductive products of mussels of the genus Dreissena.
Definitions.
Notwithstanding Natural Resources Article, §4-1007, Annotated Code of Maryland, in this subtitle, the following term has the meaning indicated.

Term Defined. "Buying station" means a location where a person buys, processes, packs, or otherwise deals in oysters, soft-shell clams, or hard-shell clams for resale and the person purchasing oysters, soft-shell clams, or hard-shell clams for resale:
Possesses a valid seafood dealer authorization in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland; and
Is licensed and certified by the Maryland Department of Health in accordance with COMAR 10.15.07.
A person may only sell oysters, soft-shell clams of the species Mya arenaria, or hard-shell clams at a:
Buying station; or
Location other than a buying station if:
The person selling the oysters or clams is:
Licensed and authorized to sell the person's own catch in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland; and
Licensed and certified by the Maryland Department of Health in accordance with COMAR 10.15.07; and
The oysters or clams are sold or served to ultimate consumers, and not for resale.
In this regulation, the following term has the meaning indicated.
Term Defined. "Shellfish" means:
All clams of the scientific Order Myoida;
All clams of the scientific Order Veneroida;
All crabs of the scientific Order Decapoda;
All lobsters of the scientific Order Decapoda;
All mussels of the scientific Order Mytiloida;
All octopuses of the scientific Order Octopoda;
All oysters of the scientific Order Ostreoida;
All scallops of the scientific Order Ostreoida;
All sea urchins of the scientific Class Echinoidea;
All shrimp of the scientific Order Decapoda;
All squids of the scientific Order Teuthoidea;
All starfish of the scientific Subclass Asteroidea; and
All whelks of the scientific Order Neogastropoda.
Except as otherwise provided in law or regulation, a person may not buy, sell, ship, transport, land, or otherwise deal in shellfish unless the person is licensed by the Department.
Prohibition of Catching, Possession, or Sale of Bay Scallops; Exceptions.
A person may not catch, offer for sale, purchase, or possess any bay scallop (Argopecten irradians), or any parts of bay scallop caught in Maryland waters except as permitted in this regulation.
Exceptions.
A person may catch bay scallops in cooperation with a scientific investigation of the Department and cooperating persons having a valid scientific collecting permit.
The incidental catching of bay scallops by gear set for other species of shellfish is not considered a violation of this regulation if the bay scallops are returned to the water.

Possession or Sale of Bay Scallop Lawfully Taken in Another Jurisdiction. The provisions of §A of this regulation do not prohibit the entry into the State, or possession, transportation, exportation, processing, sale, offer for sale, or shipment of bay scallops which were caught in waters not under Maryland jurisdiction, if the person engaging in the activity demonstrates by a bill of sale that the bay scallops were lawfully taken and lawfully removed from another jurisdiction.
Registration.

A tidal fish licensee who possesses a clam harvester or unlimited tidal fish license under Natural Resources Article, §4-701(d)(ii), Annotated Code of Maryland, shall declare an intent to harvest clams in order to participate in the clam season.
Declaration Schedule. A tidal fish licensee may submit an application of declaration during license renewal as described in Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland.
The individual shall declare separately for each of the following species:
Soft-shell clams:
Mya arenaria; and
Razor clams (Tagelus plebeius); and
Hard-shell clams (Mercenaria mercenaria).
Reporting. Tidal fish licensees who declare an intent to harvest clams under this regulation shall report in accordance with COMAR 08.02.13.06 on forms provided by the Department.
Closure Areas.
The Department shall provide the publication as described in Natural Resources Article, §4-1006.2, Annotated Code of Maryland, to each individual declaring an intent to harvest clams.
An individual receiving the publication as described in §D(2)(a) of this regulation shall certify to the Department on the form the Department prescribes that the person received the publication.
Definitions.
In this regulation the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Term Defined. "Federally tagged lobster trap" means a trap that:
Meets the requirements described in Regulation .10E and F of this chapter; and
Has a tag that was issued by the National Marine Fisheries Service.
Recreational.
An individual may not possess any Jonah crab that is egg-bearing or from which eggs have been intentionally removed.
There is no season or size limit for the recreational fishery.
The daily possession limit is 50 Jonah crabs per person per day.
Commercial Fishery.

A person shall be licensed in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland, and permitted in accordance with this regulation in order to catch, possess, or land Jonah crabs for commercial purposes.
A person may not catch, land, possess, sell, offer to sell, or transport any Jonah crab:
Which is egg-bearing or from which eggs have been intentionally removed; or
Measuring less than 4-3/4 inches in width, measured at the widest part of the carapace (body shell).
A person may not remove the claws of a Jonah crab:
Which is egg-bearing or from which eggs have been intentionally removed; or
Measuring less than 4-3/4 inches in width, measured at the widest part of the carapace (body shell).
A person who removes the claws of a Jonah crab at sea may harvest:
Up to 5 gallons of claws of any size per trip; or
More than 5 gallons of claws per trip, if all claws harvested are a minimum of 2-3/4 inches in length, measured on the bottom of the claw, from the joint to the lower tip of the claw.
Maryland Jonah Crab Landing Permits.

An individual is eligible to declare for a permit to catch and land Jonah crabs in Maryland if they are properly licensed in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland.
A landing permit is valid for the current commercial license year.
Landing permits may not be transferred.
Catch Limits.
An individual who is not in possession of a Maryland Jonah crab landing permit may not land Jonah crabs in Maryland.
An individual may land an unlimited number of Jonah crab claws and whole Jonah crabs per vessel per trip if the individual:
Harvests Jonah crabs from a federally tagged lobster trap;
Is in possession of a valid federal lobster permit issued by the National Marine Fisheries Service; and
Is in possession of a valid Maryland Jonah crab landing permit.
An individual may harvest Jonah crabs from gear other than a federally tagged lobster trap only if the:
Individual is in possession of a valid Maryland Jonah crab landing permit;
Individual harvests fish species in addition to Jonah crabs during the same trip; and
Total weight, in pounds, of the other fish species harvested is greater than that of the Jonah crabs, at all times.
An individual who harvests Jonah crabs from fishing gear other than a federally tagged lobster trap may not land more than:
1,000 whole Jonah crabs per vessel per trip; or
2,000 Jonah crab claws per vessel per trip, regardless of whether or not the claws are attached to the Jonah crab.

Jonah crabs harvested for commercial purposes from Maryland waters of the Atlantic Ocean or from the waters of the Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) and landed in Maryland shall be sold to a dealer with a federal permit.
Reporting and Penalties.
An individual shall record the harvest of Jonah crabs in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-206, Annotated Code of Maryland.
A dealer shall transmit information weekly, or as required, on each Jonah crab transaction through the Department-approved reporting system.
In addition to any other penalty, failure to comply with this regulation may result in the suspension of the current permit or the denial of a subsequent permit.

Prior to suspending a permit or denying an application for a permit under this regulation, the Department shall give the licensee notice of its intended action and an opportunity to appear at a hearing conducted in accordance with the contested case procedures set forth in State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland, and COMAR 08.01.04.
General.

The Secretary may establish or modify catch limits or seasons for Jonah crabs in order to implement the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission Interstate Fishery Management Plan for Jonah Crabs, by issuing a public notice on the Department's website.
The public notice shall state its effective hour and date and shall be published on the Department's website at least 48 hours in advance of the effective hour and date.
The Secretary shall make a reasonable effort to disseminate the public notice through various other media so that an affected person has reasonable opportunity to be informed.
A violation of the restrictions set by the Secretary in accordance with this section is a violation of this regulation.
Maryland Waters. A person may not catch, attempt to catch, or possess any surf clams harvested from Maryland waters which extend from the Maryland shore to 3 miles offshore.
Offshore Waters.
A person may not possess or land surf clams harvested from offshore waters, which extend from 3-200 miles offshore in violation of the:
Catch limit established in 50 CFR 648; or
Size specifications established in 50 CFR 648.
A person may not catch, possess, or land surf clams when the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration closes the fishery in accordance with 50 CFR 648.
Recreational Fishery.
An individual may use any gear authorized in COMAR 08.02.25.03 to catch shrimp for recreational purposes.
There is no closed season, size limit, or catch or possession limit for the recreational fishery.
An individual catching or attempting to catch shrimp for recreational purposes must be licensed or registered in accordance with COMAR 08.02.01.07.
Commercial Fishery.

A person shall be licensed in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland, and permitted in accordance with this regulation in order to catch, possess, or land shrimp for commercial purposes.
Maryland Shrimp Permit.
An individual is eligible to declare for a permit to catch and land shrimp in Maryland if they are properly licensed in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland.
A shrimp permit:
Is valid for the commercial license year; and
May not be transferred.

A person licensed in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland, and permitted in accordance with this regulation, may use any of the gear listed under COMAR 08.02.25.01 to catch shrimp, as long as that gear would otherwise be allowed to harvest fish under their license and the gear is used in accordance with the rules established under COMAR 08.02 and Natural Resources Article, Title 4, Annotated Code of Maryland.
Pilot Program.
The Department may conduct a pilot project to demonstrate and evaluate new approaches to managing the shrimp fishery.
Notwithstanding Natural Resources Article, Title 4, Annotated Code of Maryland and COMAR 08.02, pilot projects may be conducted to implement and assess conservation and management measures.

The Department may select and designate certain persons licensed under Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland, to participate in a pilot project. A participating licensee shall:
Apply for a pilot program permit on forms provided by the Department;
Have a pilot program permit in order to participate in a pilot program;
Comply with any conditions of the permit; and
Be eliminated from the pilot project at the discretion of the Department.
The Department shall:
Develop pilot projects in cooperation with the commercial fishing industry; and
Provide adequate notice of a pilot program through various media so that an interested individual has reasonable opportunity to be informed.
Reporting and Penalties.
An individual shall record the harvest of shrimp in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-206, Annotated Code of Maryland.
In addition to any other penalty, failure to comply with this regulation may result in the suspension of the current permit or the denial of a subsequent permit.

Prior to suspending a permit or denying an application for a permit under this regulation, the Department shall give the licensee notice of its intended action and an opportunity to appear at a hearing conducted in accordance with the contested case procedures set forth in State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland, and COMAR 08.01.04.
General.

The Secretary may establish or modify catch limits, size limits, or seasons for shrimp or open or close areas for shrimp harvest in order to implement the South Atlantic Fishery Management Council Shrimp Fishery Management Plan for the South Atlantic Region, by issuing a public notice on the Department's website.
The public notice shall state its effective hour and date and shall be published on the Department's website at least 48 hours in advance of the effective hour and date.
The Secretary shall make a reasonable effort to disseminate the public notice through various other media so that an affected person has reasonable opportunity to be informed.
A violation of the restrictions set by the Secretary in accordance with this section is a violation of this regulation.

A person licensed to buy, process, pack, resell, market, or otherwise deal in soft-shell clams, hard-shell clams, or oysters in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland, shall:
Accept soft-shell clams, hard-shell clams, or oysters only:
From a licensed harvester;
On the same day of harvest; and
If tagged as required in accordance with COMAR 08.02.02.04, 08.02.04.04, or 08.02.07.04.
Follow the requirements of the National Shellfish Sanitation Program Model Ordinance that is incorporated by reference in COMAR 10.15.07.01A; and
Implement Vibrio parahaemolyticus control measures in accordance with COMAR 10.15.07.06.
A person who is licensed and certified to sell shellfish by the Maryland Department of Health in accordance with COMAR 10.15.04 and 10.15.07 shall:
Follow the requirements of the National Shellfish Sanitation Program Model Ordinance that is incorporated by reference in COMAR 10.15.07.01A; and
Implement Vibrio parahaemolyticus control measures in accordance with COMAR 10.15.07.06.
Any person possessing a license to deal in soft-shell clams shall maintain and submit to the Department any records the Department may require.

An individual who catches an egg bearing female lobster that measures 3-3/8 inches to 5-1/4 inches in length from the rear end of the eye socket along a line parallel to the center line of body shell (carapace) to the rear of the body shell shall:
Mark the lobster to the right of the center flipper as viewed from the rear of the female lobster when the underside of the lobster is down with a v-shaped notch that:
Is made by means of a sharp bladed instrument;
Is at least 1/4 inch in length;
Is not greater than 1/2 inch in depth; and
Tapers to a sharp point; and
Immediately release the lobster.
A person may not catch, land, possess, sell, offer to sell, or transport any:
Lobster that is egg-bearing or from which eggs have been intentionally removed;
Lobster measuring less than 3-3/8 inches from the rear end of the eye socket along a line parallel to the center line of body shell (carapace) to the rear of the body shell;
Female or male lobster measuring greater than 5-1/4 inches from the rear end of the eye socket along a line parallel to the center line of body shell (carapace) to the rear of the body shell;
Lobster which has an outer shell which has been speared;
Female lobster bearing a V-shaped notch which is:

A straight-sided triangular cut with or without setal hairs, at least 1/8 inch in depth and tapering to a sharp point in the flipper next to the right of the center flipper as viewed from the rear of the female lobster; or
Mutilated in a manner which could hide, obscure, or obliterate such a mark; or
Lobster from February 1 through March 31.
An individual shall land lobsters whole and may not remove any meat, body appendages, or tail from any lobster before landing.
An individual using gear other than lobster traps may not land more than 100 lobsters per day for a 24-hour period, or 500 lobsters per trip for a 5-day or longer period.
A lobster trap:
Shall have a minimum of:
One rectangular escape vent located in the parlor section of the trap which shall be a minimum of 2 inches by 5-3/4 inches; or
Two circular escape vents located in the parlor section of the trap which shall have a minimum diameter of 2-5/8 inches;
May not exceed a volume of 22,950 cubic inches;
Shall be removed from the water not later than February 14 of each year; and
May not be set prior to March 24 of each year.

A lobster trap not constructed entirely of wood, excluding heading or parlor twine and the escape vent, shall contain a ghost panel to allow for the escape of lobsters after a period of time if the trap has been abandoned or lost according to the following specifications:
The rectangular opening covered by the ghost panel may not be less than 3-3/4 inches by 3-3/4 inches;
The ghost panel shall be located in the outer parlor or parlors of the trap and not the bottom of the trap; and

The ghost panel shall be constructed of or fastened to the trap with wood lath, cotton, hemp sisal, or jute twine not greater than 3/16 inch in diameter, or non-stainless, uncoated ferrous metal not greater than 3/32 inch in diameter.
General Restrictions.
An individual may not operate a hydraulic clam dredge unless they possess a valid tidal fish license to catch clams.
The owner of a hydraulic clam dredge may not permit the operation of the dredge by more than one individual on any one day, including the owner.
Measurement of Rig.
A hydraulic clam dredging rig may not have more than one conveyor or elevator, blade, and water manifold.
The water manifold may not be more than 36 inches in width measuring from the outside jets.
The outside jets on the water manifold shall be set parallel to, or inclined inward toward, the median vertical longitudinal plane of the dredge.
Muffler Required. A hydraulic clam dredge vessel shall have mufflers properly installed on all motors and engines in accordance with COMAR 08.18.03.08.
An individual may not harvest clams by hydraulic dredge in the Chesapeake Bay offshore of Sandy Point State Park in Anne Arundel County within:
800 feet of the shoreline January 1 through March 31;
1,500 feet of the shoreline April 1 through September 30; and
800 feet of the shoreline October 1 through December 31.
Private Bathing Beach.
From May 1 through September 30, an individual may not catch or attempt to catch clams by hydraulic dredge within 300 feet of a private bathing beach.
The private bathing beach shall be marked with a sign which shall:
Be posted and maintained by the owner of the private bathing beach;
Be a minimum of 2 feet high by 3 feet wide with legible black letters measuring a minimum of 4 inches high and 2 inches wide;
State "Private Bathing Beach — No Clam Dredging Within 300 Feet";
Be made of durable material; and
Conform to local ordinances and codes.
Shellfish Buy Ticket.
A shellfish buy ticket shall be:
Provided by the Department;
Completed in accordance with this regulation; and
Returned to the Department in accordance with this regulation.
When soft-shell clams of the species Mya arenaria, hard-shell clams, or oysters are sold to a buying station:
The seller shall provide the information necessary for the buyer to complete a shellfish buy ticket;
The buyer shall complete a shellfish buy ticket for every soft-shell clam of the species Mya arenaria, hard-shell clam, or oyster purchase; and
Both the seller and the buyer shall sign the shellfish buy ticket.
When soft-shell clams of the species Mya arenaria, hard-shell clams, or oysters are sold at a location other than a buying station, the seller shall complete and sign a shellfish buy ticket.

An individual who harvests oysters from a public oyster bar, soft-shell clams of the species Mya arenaria, or hard-shell clams and places them on a lease shall complete and sign a shellfish buy ticket.
The shellfish buy ticket shall be returned to the Department in accordance with §D of this regulation.
A shellfish buy ticket is not required for the sale or purchase of shellfish harvested from a leased area.
Shellfish Tax Report.
A shellfish tax report shall be:
Provided by the Department;
Completed in accordance with this regulation; and
Returned to the Department in accordance with this regulation.
When soft-shell clams of the species Mya arenaria, hard-shell clams, or oysters are sold at a:
Buying station, the buyer shall complete a Shellfish Tax Report; or
Location other than a buying station, the seller shall complete a Shellfish Tax Report.
The shellfish tax report shall be returned to the Department in accordance with §D of this regulation.
Shellfish Export Certificate.
When soft-shell clams of the species Mya arenaria, hard-shell clams, or oysters are shipped out of State, the seller shall complete a shellfish export certificate for each shipment.
The original shellfish export certificate shall accompany the shipment of oysters out of State.
A copy of the shellfish export certificate shall be submitted to the Department in accordance with §D of this regulation.
Requirements for Return of Documents.

Except as provided in §D(3) of this regulation, a person shall return the completed shellfish buy ticket, shellfish tax report, and shellfish export certificate to the Department each week for all soft-shell clams of the species Mya arenaria, hard-shell clams, or oysters purchased or sold during the week ending on the previous Saturday, even if no taxes are due.
All forms, reports, and certificates shall be accompanied by any money due to the State for the respective period of time.
Exceptions.

A person who has indicated on a form provided by the Department that they will not be buying or selling oysters, soft-shell clams of the species Mya arenaria, or hard-shell clams for a particular period of time is exempt from submitting the records required by §§A—C of this regulation for the time period specified on the form.
Individuals whose sales or purchases would require payment of taxes of less than $25 weekly may submit the required documents monthly.
Except as provided in §B of this regulation, a person may not catch, land, or possess a conch measuring less than 6 inches total length from the spiral apex to the outer tip of the opening.
Channeled Whelk. A person may catch, land or possess a channeled whelk measuring less than 6 inches total length if the whelk has a girth that is a minimum of 3-3/8 inches in diameter.

para.text: To assess a reasonable monetary value for aquatic resources in the event of man-caused mortality, the following tables of prices for various species and sizes are established.
Fresh and Brackish Water Food and Sport Fishes.

tr.td: Individual Fish Prices by Size Category(Total Length in Inches)

para.text: Bait and Forage Fishes.

tr.td: (2) Forage fish - all fishes that are not listed elsewhere in this table and that are used as food by predatory fishes. This category includes: minnows, shiners, daces, chubs, silversides, anchovies, blennies, sculpins, gobies.

para.text: Invertebrate Animals Shellfish and Crustaceans.
Non-Fish Vertebrates.

container.heading: Horseshoe Crabs
container.text: Authority: Natural Resources Article, §§4-206, 4-215, and 4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland

para.text: Quota.
The annual total allowable landings of horseshoe crabs for the commercial fishery shall be established and may be modified through a public notice issued in accordance with §G of this regulation.
Any annual overages in the fishery will be deducted from the total fishery allotment for the following year.
Seasons. The season for harvesting horseshoe crabs shall be established and may be modified through a public notice issued in accordance with §G of this regulation.
Time Restrictions. A person may not catch or land horseshoe crabs on Saturday or Sunday.
Catch Limits.
A person that does not possess a valid Maryland horseshoe crab landing permit may not catch, possess, or land more than 25 horseshoe crabs per day.
An individual may not catch or possess female horseshoe crabs.

The catch limit for individuals in possession of a valid horseshoe crab landing permit shall be established and may be modified through a public notice issued in accordance with §G of this regulation.
Horseshoe Crab Landing Permit.

No more than ten horseshoe crab landing permits may be issued by the Department. The number of horseshoe crab landing permits is based on the reported catch and landing records of horseshoe crabs in Maryland during 1996.
The Department may issue a permit to catch and land horseshoe crabs in Maryland to a person who is licensed in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland, and:
Declared or was eligible to declare, in the previous year, an intent to fish for horseshoe crabs in accordance with this section and has not transferred the permit; or
Received a horseshoe crab landing permit through a permanent business transfer in accordance with §E(6) of this regulation.
Declaration.
Between August 1 and April 30, dates inclusive, tidal fish licensees shall declare their intent to fish for horseshoe crabs.

A tidal fish licensee who has not declared by April 30 of the current year, and who has not declared by the April 30 deadline in any of the 3 preceding years, may apply until May 14 of the current year, or the next business day if May 14 occurs on a weekend, to the Director of Fisheries Service, provided the licensee shows good reason why the application should be processed.

An exception to the May 14 deadline will be considered only for an individual who can provide satisfactory documentation of a physical or mental incapacity that prevented that individual from meeting the registration time period established in this subsection.
A permittee shall possess the horseshoe crab landing permit when engaged in permitted activities.
Transfer of a Landing Permit.
The Department may approve the permanent or temporary transfer of a landing permit to a person who applies to the Department requesting the transfer on forms provided by the Department.
At the end of the specified temporary transfer time period the permit automatically returns to the original permittee.
A horseshoe crab landing permit may only be transferred to a person who:
Is licensed in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland; and
Is not currently a permit holder.
Regardless of the number of authorized individuals with Maryland horseshoe crab permits on board any one vessel, no more than two horseshoe crab quotas may be harvested from one vessel per trip.
Reporting and Penalties.

In addition to the requirements of Natural Resources Article, §4-206, Annotated Code of Maryland, an individual in possession of a horseshoe crab landing permit shall record the harvest of horseshoe crabs on the permit daily and submit the completed permit to the Department in the time frame specified on the form.
In addition to any other penalty established in COMAR 08.02.13, failure to comply with this regulation may result in the denial of a subsequent permit.

Prior to suspending a permit under this regulation or denying an application for a permit, the Department shall give the licensee notice of its intended action and an opportunity to appear at a hearing conducted in accordance with the contested case procedures set forth in State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland, and COMAR 08.01.04.
General.
A person authorized to catch and release horseshoe crabs for purposes of scientific research:
Shall return within 48 hours the live horseshoe crabs to the waters from which the horseshoe crabs were taken; and
Is exempt from §§A-E of this regulation.
A person who purchases horseshoe crabs for purposes of scientific research may:
Return the horseshoe crabs to the harvester for use or sale as bait;
Return or sell the horseshoe crabs to a bait dealer; or
Return the horseshoe crabs live to tidal waters.
Horseshoe crabs shall be harvested only from a vessel and may not be harvested from land.

The Secretary may establish or modify catch limits, quotas, and seasons for horseshoe crabs in order to implement the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission Interstate Fishery Management Plan for Horseshoe Crab by issuing a public notice on the Fisheries Service website.
The public notice shall state its effective hour and date and shall be published on the Fisheries Service website at least 48 hours in advance of the effective hour and date.

The Secretary shall make a reasonable effort to disseminate a public notice issued under this section through various other media so that an affected individual has a reasonable opportunity to be informed.
A violation of the restrictions set by the Secretary in accordance with §G of this regulation is a violation of this regulation.

container.heading: Fishing in Nontidal Waters
container.text: Authority: Natural Resources Article, §§4-205, 4-215, 4-215.2, 4-219, 4-221, 4-402, 4-602, 4-603, 4-614, 4-616, 4-745, 5-209, and 10-808, Annotated Code of Maryland

para.text: Basic Statewide Trout Fishing. Except as listed in §§B—I of this regulation, the following shall be in effect for trout fishing in all nontidal waters of the State:
Open season — year around;
Fishing hours —` from 5:30 a.m. to 10 p.m.;
Creel and possession limits (all species of trout) in aggregate — daily: 2, possession: 4;
A trout is part of the daily creel and possession limit if it cannot freely swim away from a person;
Minimum size (all species of trout) — no minimum size restriction.
Put-and-Take Trout Fishing Areas.

Open Season. Except as provided in §I of this regulation, put-and-take trout fishing areas are closed to all fishing from 10 p.m. of the first date to 5:30 a.m. of the last date, during the period listed in the following schedule:
Closure 0 — No closure;
Closure 1 — From the first Sunday after March 4 to the last Saturday in March; and
Closure 2 — From Sunday to Saturday of the last full week of March.
Fishing Hours.
Except as provided in §B(2)(b) and (c) and §I of this regulation, the fishing hours are from 5:30 a.m. to 10 p.m.
There are no time restrictions for fishing in impoundments of 5 acres or more.
In areas designated as Closure 1 or Closure 2 areas in §B(5) of this regulation, the fishing hours on the last Saturday in March are from 6:30 a.m. to 10 p.m.
Creel and Possession Limits.
Brook trout v Daily: 0, Possession: 0.
All other species of trout in aggregate — Daily: 5, Possession: 10.

Public and private ponds in which State-supported fishing rodeos are held may be designated as put-and-take trout fishing areas on the day of the rodeo and are subject to the provisions in §B(1)—(3) of this regulation.
Except as provided in §C(1) of this regulation the following areas are designated as put-and-take trout fishing areas and are subject to the provisions in §B(1)—(3) of this regulation:

tr.td: (i) Evitts Creek mainstem upstream of Interstate 68
(iv) Wills Creek mainstem upstream of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers Flood Control Project at The Narrows above Cumberland

(i) Fishing Creek mainstem upstream of Fishing Creek Reservoir including Steep Creek

Quadrangle, and from Piney Swamp Run downstream to the Allegany County line

(i) Northwest Branch watershed upstream of Maryland Route 410 to Norwood Road
(x) Martin Luther King, Jr. Park Pond
(xi) Patuxent River mainstem from base of Rocky Gorge Reservoir Dam in Laurel downstream to the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad crossing
(xii) South Branch Patapsco River mainstem from West Friendship Road (Howard County side) and Main Street (Carroll County Side) downstream to its confluence with the North Branch Patapsco River
(xiii) Great Seneca Creek from Maryland Route 28 upstream to Maryland Route 355

(i) Beaver Creek from the downstream side of the bridges located on the private farm lane below the Albert Powell State Trout Hatchery downstream to Black Rock Creek; and from Beaver Creek Road downstream to the confluence with Antietam Creek
(ix) Antietam Creek mainstem from upstream boundary of Devil's Backbone Park to the mouth of Beaver Creek
(m) Wicomico County: Beaverdam Creek in Salisbury from Schumaker Dam downstream to the bridge crossing at Memorial Plaza Road

para.text: Catch-and-Return Trout Fishing Areas.
Owens Creek.
Special provisions in effect on this area:
From June 1 through the last day of February, a person may not keep or have any trout in possession while fishing, or fish with any barbed hook; and
A person may not possess or use any natural or live bait, or any device enhanced with a scent and capable of catching fish.
The area subject to the provisions of §C(1)(a) of this regulation is Owens Creek mainstem from Buck Lantz Road downstream to Roddy Road.
North Branch Potomac River.
Special provisions in effect on this area:
Open season — no closed season;
Creel and possession limits, all trout species in aggregate: daily — 0, possession — 0; and
A person may not fish with any barbed hook.

The area subject to the provisions of §C(2)(a) of this regulation is the North Branch Potomac River from the Upper Potomac River Commission Wastewater Treatment Plant discharge at Westernport downstream to the Maryland Route 956 bridge at Pinto.
Areas Limited to Use of Artificial Lures Only.
Special provisions in effect on these areas:
A person may not have any trout in possession while fishing in these areas. All trout which are caught shall be released and returned to the water.
A person may fish only with artificial lures, including artificial flies.
In these areas, a person may not possess or use any natural or live bait, or any device enhanced with a scent and capable of catching fish.
The open season for artificial lure fishing is January 1 through December 31, inclusive.
A person may not fish with any barbed hook.
Areas subject to the provisions of this section are:

Patuxent River, Howard and Montgomery counties. The mainstem of the Patuxent River from the crossing of Maryland Route 97 upstream to the crossing of Maryland Route 27 and Cabin Branch from its confluence with the Patuxent River upstream to Hipsley Mill Road.
Morgan Run, Carroll County. From bridge on London Bridges Road upstream to bridge on Maryland Route 97.
Paint Branch and Tributaries, Montgomery County upstream of Fairland Road.
Gunpowder Falls, Baltimore County. Mainstem, from Prettyboy Reservoir Dam downstream to Bluemount Road.

North Branch Potomac River from an overhead cable and red bank post located approximately 345 yards below the Jennings Randolph Reservoir spillway downstream approximately 1 mile to a red post, located approximately 100 yards above the upstream concrete abutments at Barnum, West Virginia, and from a red post located below a pool known as Blue Hole approximately 1/3 mile upstream of Bench Mark 1110 on the Westernport U.S.G.S. Quadrangle, downstream approximately 4 miles to the confluence of Piney Swamp Run.
Youghiogheny River, Garrett County. Mainstem beginning at a red post approximately 100 yards upstream of the Deep Creek Lake tailrace and extending downstream 4 miles to the Sang Run Bridge.

Little Hunting Creek, Frederick County. Mainstem from a red post located approximately 1/4 mile downstream of Maryland Route 806, upstream to include all waters of Little Hunting Creek within the boundaries of Cunningham Falls State Park.
Areas Limited to Artificial Fly Fishing Only.
Special provisions in effect on these areas:
A person may not have any trout in possession while fishing in these areas. All trout which are caught shall be released and returned to the water.

A person may fish only with artificial flies and streamers constructed in a normal fashion using natural or synthetic materials, or both, which may include feathers, fur, hair, tinsel, thread, fiber, plastic, cork, wire, and rubber, on a single hook with the components wound on or about the hook. A person may not use molded replicas of insects, earthworms, fish eggs, fish, or any invertebrate or vertebrate, either singly or in combination with the other materials, or other lures commonly described as spinners, spoons, or plugs made of metal, plastic, wood, rubber, or a similar substance or a combination of these.

A person may fish only with conventional fly fishing tackle, including fly rods, fly reels, and fly line with a leader or monofilament line attached. Any method of angling when the fly is cast directly from the reel is prohibited. The use of centerpin, spinning, spincast, and casting reels is prohibited.
In these areas, a person may not possess or use any natural or live bait, or any device enhanced with a scent and capable of catching fish.
The open season is January 1 through December 31, inclusive.
A person may not fish with any barbed hook.
Areas subject to provisions of this section are:

Big Hunting Creek, Frederick County. All waters of Big Hunting Creek and its tributaries within Cunningham Falls State Park and Catoctin Mountain Park except Owens Creek, Little Hunting Creek, Cunningham Falls Lake, and Frank Bentz Pond;
Beaver Creek, Washington County. From the confluence with Black Rock Creek downstream approximately 1 mile to a red post located 0.1 mile above Beaver Creek Road; and
Patuxent River, Montgomery and Howard Counties. From red bank posts located on both sides of the river approximately 400 yards below Brighton Dam downstream to Mink Hollow Road.
Trophy Trout Fishing Areas.

Savage River mainstem from the downstream side of the Route 135 bridge upstream for a distance of approximately 2.7 miles to the lower suspension bridge (Allegany Bridge) is a trophy trout fishing area. The following apply:
Open season — no closed season.
Creel limit all trout species in aggregate — daily: 2, possession: 4.
Minimum size: brook trout — 12 inches; brown trout — 18 inches; all other species of trout — no minimum size.
A person may not have in possession any trout smaller than the minimum size limit in effect for this area.
A person may fish only with artificial lures, including artificial flies. Treble hooks are prohibited. Each artificial lure is restricted to a single hook with a single hook point.
In these areas, a person may not possess or use any natural or live bait, or any device enhanced with a scent and capable of catching fish.
Savage River mainstem from the Savage River Reservoir Dam downstream to the lower suspension bridge (Allegany Bridge) is a trophy trout fishing area. The following apply:
Open season — no closed season
Creel limit all trout species in aggregate — daily: 2, possession: 4.
Minimum size: brook trout — 12 inches; brown trout — 18 inches; all other species of trout — no minimum size.
A person may fish only with artificial flies.

In these areas, a person may not possess or use any natural or live bait, or any device enhanced with a scent and capable of catching fish. Section C(4)(a)(ii)—(iv), of this regulation shall apply to this special trout management area.
A person may not have in possession any trout smaller than the minimum size limit in effect for this area.
Areas Limited to Fishing by Persons Younger than 16 Years Old, Persons 65 Years Old or Older, and Blind Persons.
Special provisions in effect on these areas:
Fishing in these areas is limited to persons under 16 years old, persons 65 years old and older, and blind persons;
Section B(1)—(3) of this regulation shall apply to these special trout management areas.
Areas subject to provisions of this section:
Laurel Run (Moscow), Allegany County.
Pangborn Pond, Washington County.
Rising Sun Pond from March 1 through May 15.
Boonsboro Pond, Washington County.
Areas Limited to Fishing by Persons under 16 Years Old and Blind Persons.
Special provisions in effect on these areas.
Fishing in these areas is limited to individuals under 16 years old and blind persons.
Section B(1)—(3) of this regulation shall apply to these special trout management areas.
Areas subject to provisions of this section:
Carroll Creek from a red post located approximately 300 yards upstream of Baughmans Lane downstream to the dam at College Avenue;
Little Tonoloway Creek within Weidmeyer Park in Hancock;
Glades Park Pond on Liberty Street in Oakland;
George's Creek within Town Park in Westernport;
Little Antietam Creek at Keedysville, from Coffman Farms Road downstream to Maryland Route 34; and
Grantsville Parkview Pond off Hershberger Lane.
Delayed Harvest Trout Fishing Areas and Requirements.
Group I Delayed Harvest Trout Fishing Areas and Restrictions.
Group I Fishing Areas.
Catoctin and Little Catoctin Creek (Frederick County) from U.S. Route 40 near its intersection with Maryland Route 17 within Doubs Meadow Park downstream to the lower park boundary near Myersville.
Catoctin Creek (Frederick County) from the southernmost boundary of Catoctin Creek Park upstream to 200 feet north of the Sumantown Road Bridge.
Middle Patuxent River (Howard County) from U.S. Route 29 downstream to Murray Hill Road.

Town Creek mainstem (Allegany County) within Green Ridge State Forest, from a red post located approximately 3/4 mile downstream of the upper ford on lower Town Creek Road, just south of the Wagner Road intersection, downstream to a red post located just upstream of the lower ford on Lower Town Creek Road (Mallory Place), and from a post located approximately 1/2 mile downstream of Maniford Road to a red post located approximately 1-3/4 miles downstream (Bull Ring Ranch).

South Branch Patapsco River from West Friendship Road (Howard County) and Main Street (Carroll County) upstream approximately 1.1 mile to the upper boundary of the Hugg Thomas Wildlife Management Area.
Season, Creel, and Possession Limits for Group I Fishing Areas.
From June 1 through September 30, inclusive, the daily creel limit is five trout and the possession limit is ten trout (all species of trout in aggregate); and

From October 1 through May 31, inclusive, a person may not have any trout in possession while fishing in these areas, and shall immediately release any trout caught to the water from which the trout was taken.
Bait Restrictions for Group I Fishing Areas.
From June 1 through September 30, inclusive, no special bait, lure, or tackle restrictions are in effect.
From October 1 through May 31, inclusive, in these areas, a person may not possess or use any natural or live bait, or any device enhanced with a scent and capable of catching fish.
From October 1 through May 31, inclusive, in these areas, a person may not fish with any barbed hook.
Group II Delayed Harvest Trout Fishing Areas and Restrictions.
Group II Fishing Areas.

Casselman River mainstem (Garrett County) from a boundary marked by two red posts on both stream banks located on the south side of the Interstate 68 eastbound bridge downstream to the Pennsylvania state line.
North Branch Potomac River mainstem (Garrett County) from the lowermost boundary of the Potomac State Forest near Lostland Run to the uppermost boundary of the Potomac State Forest at Wallman.

Youghiogheny River mainstem (Garrett County) below Friendsville from a site located 50 yards downstream of Maple Street (at the confluence of Minnow Run) downstream 1.8 miles to the powerline crossing upstream of the Youghiogheny Reservoir.
Season, Creel, and Possession Limits for Group II Fishing Areas.
From June 16 through September 30, inclusive, the daily creel limit is five trout and the possession limit is ten trout (all species of trout in aggregate).

From October 1 through June 15, inclusive, a person may not have any trout in possession while fishing in these areas, and shall immediately release any trout caught to the water from which the trout was taken.
Bait Restrictions for Group II Fishing Areas.
From June 16 through September 30, inclusive, no special bait, lure, or tackle restrictions are in effect.
From October 1 through June 15, inclusive, in these areas, a person may not possess or use any natural or live bait, or any device enhanced with a scent and capable of catching fish.
From October 1 through June 15, inclusive, in these areas, a person may not fish with any barbed hook.
Special Restrictions for Brook Trout.
Nontidal Waters East of Interstate 81. A person may not have brook trout in possession while fishing in nontidal waters of the State located east of Interstate 81.
Savage River.
Special provisions in effect on this area:
A person may use only artificial flies and lures;
A person may not possess or use any natural or live bait, or any device enhanced with a scent and capable of catching fish; and
A person may not have brook trout in possession while fishing in this area.

The area subject to the provisions of §H(2)(a) of this regulation is the Savage River mainstem and tributaries upstream of the Savage River Reservoir dam, excluding impoundments and Put-and-Take Trout Fishing Areas (Savage River Reservoir, Savage River from Savage River Reservoir upstream to Poplar Lick Run, and New Germany Lake).
Youth Trout Fishing Day.
Youth trout fishing day is the Saturday before the last Saturday in March in areas designated as Closure 1 or Closure 2 in §B of this regulation.
Fishing Hours. The fishing hours on youth trout fishing day are from 6:30 a.m. to 10 p.m.
Fishing in the areas during the date and times described in this section is limited to individuals younger than 16 years old.
Creel and Possession Limits.
Brook trout — Daily: 0, Possession: 0.
All other species of trout in aggregate — Daily: 2, Possession: 2.

Special Restrictions for Beaver Creek. A person may not have any brown trout in possession while fishing in Beaver Creek, from the confluence with Antietam Creek upstream to the Albert Powell State Trout Hatchery.
In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
"Daily creel limit" means the total number of a species of fish that can be in an individual's possession while afield or on the water between 12:01 a.m. and midnight.
"Possession limit" means the total number of a particular species, including the daily creel limit and any previously caught fish, that an individual may possess or control in any location.
Largemouth Bass and Smallmouth Bass Slot Length Limit Fishing Areas.
The following special regulations are in effect in these areas during the open season for largemouth and smallmouth bass:
A person may possess five bass (largemouth and smallmouth bass in aggregate) per day while fishing in these areas;
A person may not possess any largemouth bass or smallmouth bass from 11 inches up to but not including 15 inches total length while fishing in these areas;
A person may possess one largemouth bass or smallmouth bass per day, 15 inches and over, while fishing in these areas.
The areas subject to this provision are:
St. Mary's Lake, Maryland Route 5, St. Mary's County;
Little Seneca Lake, Montgomery County;
Johnson Pond, Wicomico County; and
Leonard Mill Pond, Wicomico County.
Impoundments Limited to Catch-and-Return Fishing.
This section applies to the following areas:
Lake Hashawha in Carroll County;
Upper John Owings Pond in Carroll County; and
Waterworks Park in Anne Arundel County.
While fishing in the areas set forth in §B(1) of this regulation, a person:
Shall immediately return live any fish caught to the water where taken; and
May not keep or possess any fish while fishing in these areas.
Catch-and-Return Bass Areas.
Special provisions in effect for catch-and-return bass areas are that a person:
Who catches a largemouth or smallmouth bass shall immediately release that bass in the water where it was caught; and
May not possess largemouth or smallmouth bass while within the designated catch-and-return areas.
The areas subject to the provisions of this section are the:
Potomac River from Dam No. 2 (Seneca Breaks) upstream to the mouth of the Monocacy River;
Monocacy River from the Potomac River upstream to Buckeystown Dam;
Patapsco River from Interstate 70 downstream to Maryland Route 144 (Frederick Road); and
North Branch of the Potomac River, from the spillway in Cumberland upstream 25 miles to the U.S. Route 220 Bridge at Keyser, West Virginia.
Open Seasons, Creel, Possession, and Size Limits on Game and Fresh Water Fish in Nontidal Waters. Except as otherwise provided in this chapter for specific areas, the following apply Statewide:
Open Seasons.

tr.td: No closed season, except a closed season on Deep Creek Lake and the Youghiogheny River downstream of the Route 42 Bridge, from March 1 through April 15
No closed season, except as provided in Regulation .01 of this chapter.
(c) Catfish, suckers, carp, eel, gudgeon, all species of sunfish, including bluegills, rock bass (commonly known as red eye or goggle-eye), fallfish, crappie, perch (white and yellow)
June 16 through the last day of February.
June 16 through the last day of February.
(h) Muskellunge and hybrids including tiger musky
(k) Striped bass and striped bass hybrids
(l) Fish caught during closed seasons shall be returned to waters of the State immediately after being caught.

para.text: Creel and Possession Limits.

tr.td: 2, except as specified in Regulation .01 of this chapter
4, except as specified in Regulation .01 of this chapter
(b) Largemouth bass and smallmouth bass in aggregate
(f) Muskellunge and hybrids including tiger musky
(k) Striped bass and striped bass hybrids
2, only one of which may be over 30 inches
4, only 1 of which may be over 30 inches
(p) Sunfish species in aggregate, including Bluegills and Rock Bass (commonly known as Red Eye or goggle-eye)

para.text: Minimum Size from Tip of Nose to End of Caudal Fin or Tail.

tr.td: 12 inches, except as provided in Regulation .03A and E of this chapter.
12 inches, except as provided in Regulation .03A of this chapter.
Except as provided in §§A(3)(ii) and A(3)(iii) of this regulation, 15 inches.

In the Potomac River mainstem (northwest quadrant boundary lines of the District of Columbia, approximately 0.5 mile upriver from the Chain Bridge upstream to the spillway in Cumberland), from January 1 through April 15, a minimum size of 15 inches and a maximum size of 20 inches.
In Deep Creek Lake, a minimum size of 15 inches, except that all fish between 18 and 21 inches, inclusive, shall be released.
(f) Muskellunge and hybrids including tiger musky
(g) Striped bass and striped bass hybrids
(o) Sunfish, including bluegills, rock bass (commonly known as red eye or goggle-eye)

para.text: Swimming. Swimming is prohibited in any area controlled by the Inland Fisheries Division except in designated areas.
Ice Fishing in Nontidal Waters.
A person may fish through the ice in any nontidal waters of the State during the lawful open season if an angler's license first is obtained.
A person may not cut a hole through the ice for the purpose of ice fishing that measures more than 10 inches across in any direction.
It will be lawful for any person who is ice fishing to use up to five tip ups or rods (hand held devices) when ice fishing.
All tip ups and rods used by a person engaged in ice fishing shall be under the immediate control of the person.
State Fish Refuges and Fish Hatcheries. A person may not fish in any State fish refuge, fish hatchery, or fish propagation area except persons authorized by the Department.
Importation — Fish.

For the purpose of this regulation, "indigenous" means any fish species that naturally occurs in, or has been artificially introduced into, the waters of the State, and has established self-sustaining populations for at least 10 years.

So that the fish populations in the nontidal waters of the State may be protected from exotic species that might be harmful, a person may not introduce into the nontidal waters, or import or possess for introduction, any live fish not indigenous to the nontidal waters of the State.

Insofar as indigenous fish species of the tidal waters have not been harmful to the nontidal waters, but exotic species pose a threat to nontidal fish populations, a person may not introduce into the tidal waters, or import or possess for introduction, any live fish not indigenous to the tidal waters of the State without first obtaining a permit to do so from the Inland Fisheries Division. This permit shall be granted only if satisfactory proof is presented to the Division that the specific fish intended to be imported will be free of any communicable disease at the time of importation and will not be harmful to the native flora and fauna in the nontidal waters. Application for the permit shall be filed with the Division not less than 60 days before the proposed date of importation.

The provisions of this regulation with respect to importation and possession do not apply to fish for use in laboratories or exhibitions, or for use as pets. Any fish not indigenous to the waters of the State shall be held only in aquaria or other indoor facility from which escape into the waters of the State is impossible.

The introduction of any indigenous fish species except bait fish on a hook for the purpose of angling into the nontidal waters of the State is prohibited without written approval of the Inland Fisheries Division.

Commercial Harvest and Sale of Fish. Except as provided in Natural Resources Article, §4-11A-02, Annotated Code of Maryland, requirements concerning aquaculture operations, a person may not buy, sell, or offer to buy or sell any fish harvested from the nontidal waters of the State.
Vehicles on Inland Fisheries Division Owned or Controlled Lands.
For the purpose of this regulation, "vehicle" means a vehicle or vessel propelled by mechanical power that is capable of travelling on land, snow, or ice.

A person may not operate any vehicle on any lands owned or controlled by the Inland Fisheries Division without written permission of the Division except on those roads, lanes, or areas which are open to automobile traffic or which are specifically marked by the Division.
Camping on Inland Fisheries Division Owned or Controlled Lands.
For the purpose of this regulation, "camping" means erecting tents or other shelters for the purpose of residing temporarily upon the property overnight.
A person may not camp on lands owned or controlled by the Inland Fisheries Division except on designated sites or by written permit, or both.
It is unlawful to fish in a lake or pond owned or controlled by the Inland Fisheries Division before 5:30 a.m. and after 10 p.m.
Bait.

Term Defined. In this regulation, the term "bait fish" means any species of fish which does not otherwise have a catch or possession limit and which is legally permitted to be put on a hook for the purpose of catching fish.
A person may not:
Take or possess more than 35 bait fish in any day from nontidal waters of the State; or
Take bait fish of any area described in Regulation .01B—H of this chapter.
Crayfish.
In the waters of the Middle Potomac River, Upper Potomac River, and Susquehanna River basins, as described by Maryland Integrated Watershed Data and Information System 6-Digit Map, a person may not:
Catch and possess any species of crayfish unless the head is immediately removed behind the eyes upon capture;
Use any species of crayfish as bait unless the head is removed behind the eyes;
Possess any species of crayfish while fishing unless the head is removed behind the eyes; or
Catch and possess an egg-bearing female with eggs attached to the underside of the abdomen.

In addition to §I(2)(a) of this regulation, regulations relating to the importation, transport, purchase, possession, propagation, sale, or release of specific nuisance species of crayfish appear in COMAR 08.02.19.04.
Possession of Fish Whose Physical Condition Has Been Altered.
While at the fishing location, a person may not remove the head and tail of any:
Fish for which there is a minimum size; or
Trout.
The head and tail of any fish for which there is a minimum size or trout shall remain attached in such a manner as to permit identification of fish species and total length.
An individual may not have in possession at a fishing location more than 1 quart of fish which have been cut into pieces.
This provision does not apply to the capture of snakehead fish, under §N of this regulation.

Closing Against Entry. A person or vehicle may not enter, go upon, or remain upon any lands or waters owned or controlled by the Department after the posted hours for closing to public use or during any periods when those lands or waters are closed to public entry, except by written permission of the Department.
Culling of Trout.
In this chapter, "cull" means to exchange or discard a trout in order to possess another trout.
An individual may not cull trout.
A trout that is not immediately released becomes part of the daily creel limit and may not be returned to the water.
A trout is part of the daily creel and possession limit if it cannot freely swim away from a person.
Licenses and Stamps.
A person may not catch or attempt to catch game or freshwater fish without first obtaining an angler's license in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-604, Annotated Code of Maryland.
A person may not catch, attempt to catch or possess trout without first obtaining a trout stamp.
Snakehead Harvest.
An individual may capture and possess a snakehead fish using any legal method if, immediately upon capture, the snakehead is killed.
The capture and possession of snakehead fish is not subject to any season, creel limit, or size limit.
Further restrictions on possession of certain species of snakehead fish may be found in COMAR 08.02.19.06.
Public Notices.

The Secretary may modify catch limits, size limits, and restricted areas, or open, close, or modify a season by publishing notice in a daily newspaper of general circulation at least 48 hours in advance, stating the effective hour and date.
The Secretary shall make a reasonable effort to disseminate public notice through various other media so that an affected person has a reasonable opportunity to be informed.
In addition to any requirements in this chapter, gear may only be used in accordance with the requirements in COMAR 08.02.25.

The Department may issue permits authorizing the establishment and operation of artificial or man-made ponds or lakes owned, leased, or controlled by an individual, if they are constructed so as not to interfere with fishing rights or natural migration of fish if the Department determines that these lakes and ponds do not conflict with any reasonable prior public interest. Fishing in these areas may be permitted for payment of a fee and they may be stocked with fish artificially propagated by commercial hatcheries or purchased from persons licensed to sell fish.

B Any person desiring to operate a fee fishing lake under the Natural Resources Article, §4-11A-20, Annotated Code of Maryland, shall apply first to the Department for and secure a fee fishing lake permit costing $25 a year and expiring on the 31st day of December following date of issue. The applicant, in addition to other information required by the Department, shall state the size of the lake or pond, the location of the lake or pond, and the species of fish to be stocked. The permit shall entitle the holder and the holder's guests to fish for and take fish from the areas so licensed by any means, with the exception of explosives or chemicals. All fish removed under the terms of this permit shall be identified by a metal tag of a type approved by the Department or by a bill of sale when transported by tank. The fish may be taken without regard to seasons, creel, or possession limits.
C The permittee shall submit annual reports not later than the next January 10 following the date of expiration and the report shall accompany the application for renewal of the permittee's license.
All species of Trout and Salmon.
The following apply from 8 a.m. the first Saturday after April 11 through Labor Day:
The minimum size is 7 inches; and
The daily catch limit is 5 (combined species).
The following apply from 12:01 a.m. the day after Labor Day through the last day of February:
The minimum size is 7 inches; and
The daily catch limit is 3 (combined species).
The season is closed from March 1 through 8 a.m. the first Saturday after April 11.
Bass — Largemouth, Smallmouth, and Spotted.
The following apply from January 1 through the day before the second Saturday in April and from November 1 through December 31:
The minimum size is 15 inches; and
The daily catch limit is 4 (combined species).
The season is closed from 12:01 a.m. the second Saturday in April through 12:01 a.m. the second Saturday in June.
The following apply from 12:01 a.m. the second Saturday in June through October 31:
The minimum size is 12 inches; and
The daily catch limit is 6 (combined species).
Muskellunge and Muskellunge Hybrids.
There is no closed season.
The minimum size is 40 inches.
The daily catch limit is 1 (combined species).
Pickerel.
There is no closed season.
The minimum size is 18 inches.
The daily catch limit is 4.
Northern Pike.
There is no closed season.
The minimum size is 24 inches.
The daily catch limit is 2.
Walleye and Walleye Hybrids.
The season is open only from:
January 1 through March 14; and
The first Saturday in May through December 31.
The minimum size is 15 inches.
The daily catch limit is 6.
Sauger.
The season is open only from:
January 1 through March 14; and
The first Saturday in May through December 31.
The minimum size is 12 inches.
The daily catch limit is 6.
American Shad.
There is no closed season.
There is no minimum size.
The daily catch limit is 3.
River Herring (Alewife and Blueback Herring).
There is no closed season.
There is no minimum size.
The daily catch limit is 50 (combined species).
Gizzard Shad.
There is no closed season.
There is no minimum size.
The daily catch limit is 50.
Striped Bass and Striped Bass Hybrids.
There is no closed season.
The minimum size is 20 inches.
The daily catch limit is 2 (combined species).
Sunfish, Yellow Perch, White Perch, Crappies, Catfish, Rock Bass, Suckers, Carp, and White Bass.
There is no closed season.
There is no minimum size.
The daily catch limit is 50 (combined species).
Bait Fish and Fish Bait.
Except as closed in §Q of this regulation:
Bait fish includes:
All forms of the minnow family (Cyprinidae) except carp and goldfish;
Suckers, chubs, fallfish, and lampreys measuring less than 8 inches in length; and
All forms of darters, killifishes, and madtoms (stonecats); and
Fish bait includes the nymphs, larvae, and pupae of all insects spending any part of their life cycle in the water.
There is no closed season.
There is no minimum size.
The daily catch limit is 50 (combined species).
Mud Bugs (Dragonfly Nymphs).
There is no closed season.
There is no minimum size.
There is no daily catch limit.
American Eel.
There is no closed season.
The minimum size is 9 inches.
The daily catch limit is 25.
Crayfish.
There is no closed season.
There is no minimum size.
The daily catch limit is 50.
The head of the crayfish must be immediately removed behind the eyes upon capture unless used as bait in the water from which taken.
There is no open season for:
Species listed as endangered, threatened, or in need of conservation in COMAR 08.03.08;
Any species of mussel;
Any species of clam;
Paddlefish (Polyodon spathula);
Northern brook lamprey (Ichthyomyzon fossor);
Mountain brook lamprey (Ichthyomyzon greeleyi);
Lake sturgeon (Acipenser fulvescens);
Atlantic sturgeon (Acipenser oxyrhynchus);
Spotted gar (Lepisosteus oculatus);
Hickory shad (Alosa mediocris);
Cisco (Coregonus artedi);
Northern redbelly dace (Phoximus eos);
Gravel chub (Erimystax x-punctatus);
River shiner (Notropis blennius);
Ghost shiner (Notropis buchanani);
Blackchin shiner (Notropis heterodon);
Redfin shiner (Lythrurus umbratilis);
Bigmouth buffalo (Ictiobus cyprinellus);
Black bullhead (Amerius melas);
Mountain madtom (Noturus eleutherus);
Tadpole madtom (Noturus gyrinus);
Northern madtom (Noturus stigmosus);
Burbot (Lota lota);
Threespine stickleback (Gasterosteus aculeatus);
Banded sunfish (Enneacanthus obesus);
Warmouth (Lepomis gulosus);
Longear sunfish (Lepomis megalotis);
Iowa darter (Etheostoma exile);
Eastern sand darter (Etheostoma pellucida);
Bigmouth shiner (Notropis dorsalis);
Southern redbelly dace (Phoxinus erythrogaster);
Spotted sucker (Minytrema melanops);
Brindled madtom (Noturus miurus);
Bluebreasted darter (Etheostoma camurum);
Spotted darter (Etheostoma maculatum);
Tippecanoe darter (Etheostoma tippecanoe);
Gilt darter (Percina evides); and
Chesapeake logperch (Percina bimaculata).

section.heading: Special Regulations for Deer Creek and Swan Creek.

para.text: Manner of Fishing. Subject to the provisions of §C of this regulation, a person may catch or attempt to catch fish in Deer Creek and Swan Creek only by hook and line, with the line held in hand, attached to a pole or rod held in hand, or attended in a manner that the fish voluntarily takes bait or lure in its mouth.
Prohibited Bait. A person may not possess or use minnows for bait while fishing in Deer Creek and Swan Creek.

Scientific Collection Permit. A person may collect fish and eggs for scientific purposes in Deer Creek and Swan Creek only if he first obtains a special scientific permit for these waters from the Department. Any scientific permit issued before January 1, 1975, for the collection of fish and eggs is revoked with respect to the collection of fish and eggs in Deer Creek and Swan Creek.

container.heading: Endangered and Threatened Fish Species
container.text: Authority: Natural Resources Article, §4-2A-01 et seq., Annotated Code of Maryland

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.

"Endangered species" means any species whose continued existence as a viable component of the State's fish resources is determined to be in jeopardy, including any species of fish determined to be an "endangered species" pursuant to the Endangered Species Act of 1973, 16 U.S.C. §§1531-1543.
"Species in need of conservation" means any species which:
May become threatened in the foreseeable future;
Has a limited or declining population; and
Has been determined by the Secretary to be in need of conversation measures for its continued ability to sustain itself successfully.

"Threatened species" means any species of fish which appears likely, within the foreseeable future, to become endangered, including any species of fish determined to be a "threatened species" pursuant to the Endangered Species Act of 1973, 16 U.S.C. §§1531-1543.

section.heading: Factors for Endangered or Threatened Determination.

para.text: Determination Pursuant to the Endangered Species Act.
Any species of fish determined to be an endangered species pursuant to the Endangered Species Act shall be considered an endangered species under the provisions of this subtitle.
Any species of fish determined to be a threatened species pursuant to the Endangered Species Act shall be considered a threatened species under the provisions of this subtitle.
The Secretary may determine, in accordance with this regulation, that any threatened species is an endangered species throughout all or any portion of the range of the species within the State.

Determination Pursuant to Other Factors. In addition to the species considered to be endangered or threatened pursuant to the Endangered Species Act, the Secretary, by rule or regulation, shall determine whether any species of fish normally occurring within the State is an endangered or threatened species due to any of the following factors:
The present or threatened destruction, modification, or curtailment of its habitat or range;
Overutilization for commercial, sporting, scientific, educational, or other purposes;
Disease or predation;
The inadequacy of existing regulatory mechanisms; or
Other natural or manmade factors affecting its continued existence within the State.
The following species are listed as in need of conservation:
Striped bass (Morone saxatilis);
American shad (Alosa sapidissima);
Hickory shad (Alosa mediocris);
Yellow perch (Perca flavescens);
American oyster (Crassostrea virginica);
