para.text: Season. The recreational and charter boat spring season is May 1 through May 15 for the areas described in §D of this regulation.
Size Restrictions. The minimum size for striped bass during the spring season is 35 inches.
Harvest and Catch Limit. The daily catch limit for the spring season is one striped bass per individual.
Fishing Areas. An individual may fish for striped bass only in the following areas:
North of the William Preston Lane Jr. Memorial Bridge northern span, with the following boundaries:

Western boundary east of a line beginning at a point at or near the west end of the north span of the William Preston Lane Jr. Memorial Bridge, defined by Lat. 39°00.52'N and Long. 76°24.24'W; then running northerly along the shore to a point at or near Persimmon Point, defined by Lat. 39°03.16'N and Long. 76°26.33'W; then running approximately 34° True to a point at or near Mountain Point, defined by Lat. 39°03.55'N and Long. 76°25.99'W; then running northerly along the shore to a point at or near Bodkin Point, defined by Lat. 39°07.98'N and Long. 76°25.83'W; then running approximately 358° True to a point at or near Buoy "2B" at the mouth of Patapsco River, defined by Lat. 39°10.71'N and Long. 76°25.95'W;

Northern boundary south of a line beginning at a point at or near Buoy "2B" at the mouth of the Patapsco River, defined by Lat. 39°10.71'N and Long. 76°25.95'W; then running approximately 111° True along the Brewerton Channel to a point at or near Buoy "10", defined by Lat. 39°10.35'N and Long. 76°24.74'W; then running approximately 110° True to a point at or near Buoy "8", defined by Lat. 39°10.00'N and Long. 76°23.51'W; then running approximately 112° True to a point at or near Buoy "6", defined by Lat. 39°09.61'N and Long. 76°22.30'W; then running approximately 111° True to a point at or near Buoy "4", defined by Lat. 39°09.25'N and long. 76°21.08'W; then running approximately 111° True to a point at or near Buoy "2BE" at the east end of the Brewerton Channel, defined by Lat. 39°08.92'N and Long. 76°19.98'W; then running approximately 90° True to a point at or near Buoy "12", defined by Lat. 39°08.91'N and Long. 76°19.15'W; then running approximately 91° True to a point at or near Swan Point, defined by Lat. 39°08.89'N and Long. 76°16.69'W; and

Eastern and Southern boundary west of a line beginning at a point at or near Swan Point, defined by Lat. 39°08.89'N and Long. 76°16.69'W; then running approximately 141° True to a point at or near Huntingfield Point, defined by Lat. 39°07.13'N and Long. 76°14.85'W; then running southerly along the shore of Eastern Neck to a point at or near Wilson Point, defined by Lat. 39°03.19'N and Long. 76°13.66'W; then running approximately 216° True to a point at or near the northwest point of Eastern Neck Island, defined by Lat. 39°02.77'N and Long. 76°14.05'W; then running approximately 263° True to a point at or near Love Point, defined by Lat. 39°02.40'N and Long. 76°18.16'W; then running southerly along the shore of Kent Island to a point at or near the east end of the north span of the William Preston Lane Jr. Memorial Bridge, defined by Lat. 38°59.08'N and Long. 76°20.41'W; then running westerly along the north span of the William Preston Lane Jr. Memorial Bridge to a point at or near the west end of the north span of the William Preston Lane Jr. Memorial Bridge, defined by Lat. 39°00.52'N and Long. 76°24.24'W.

Between the William Preston Lane Jr. Memorial Bridge northern span and the Maryland-Virginia state line excluding all bays, sounds, tributaries, creeks, and rivers, except Tangier Sound and Pocomoke Sound.

All of the Maryland waters of the Potomac River, and its tidal tributaries, downstream of a line beginning at a point at or near the east end of the Nice Memorial Bridge (U.S. 301), defined by Lat. 38°21.55'N and Long. 77°00.90'W; then running approximately 80° True to a point at or near the west end of the Nice Memorial Bridge, defined by Lat. 38°21.81'N and Long. 76°59.00'W; and upstream of a line beginning at a point at or near the shore at the north side of the north jetty at Smith Point, defined by Lat. 37°53.40'N and Long. 76°14.23'W; then running approximately 335° True to a point at or near Point Lookout, defined by Lat. 38°02.25'N and Long. 76°19.34'W.
Bait Prohibited. A person may not use eels as bait while participating in the striped bass spring fishery.

section.heading: Recreational and Charter Boat Summer and Fall Fishery in the Chesapeake Bay and Its Tidal Tributaries.

para.text: Early Season.
The recreational and charter boat early summer and fall season for taking striped bass is May 16 through May 31.
Chesapeake Bay and Its Tidal Tributaries.
The areas subject to the provisions of §A(2) of this regulation are:
The areas described in Regulation .08D(1) and (2) of this chapter;

All of the waters of the Chesapeake Bay enclosed by a line beginning at a point at or near North Point, defined by Lat. 39°11.71'N and Long. 76°26.53'W; then running approximately 156° True to a point at or near Buoy "2B" at the mouth of the Patapsco River, defined by Lat. 39°10.71'N and Long. 76°25.95'W; then running approximately 111° True to a point at or near Buoy "10", defined by Lat. 39°10.35'N and Long. 76°24.74'W; then running approximately 110° True to a point at or near Buoy "8", defined by Lat. 39°10.00'N and Long. 76°23.51'W; then running approximately 112° True to a point at or near Buoy "6", defined by Lat. 39°09.61'N and Long. 76°22.30'W; then running approximately 111° True to a point at or near Buoy "4", defined by Lat. 39°09.24'N and Long. 76°21.08'W; then running approximately 111° True to a point at or near Buoy "2BE", defined by Lat. 39°08.92'N and Long. 76°19.98'W; then running approximately 90° True to a point at or near Buoy "12", defined by Lat. 39°08.91'N and Long. 76°19.15'W; then running approximately 91° True to a point at or near Swan Point, defined by Lat. 39°08.88'N and Long. 76°16.69'W, then running northerly along the shore of Kent County to a point at or near the end of Maryland Route 21 at Tolchester, defined by Lat. 39°12.91'N and Long. 76°14.63'W; then running approximately 282° True to a point at or near the south corner of the Hart-Miller Island dike, defined by Lat. 39°14.23'N and Long. 76°22.44'W; then running north and west along the Hart-Miller shoreline to a point at or near the west end of Hart-Miller Island, defined by Lat. 39°14.36'N and Long. 76°23.19'W; then running approximately 206° True to a point at or near the east end of Pleasure Island, defined by Lat. 39°14.23'N and Long. 76°23.27'W; then running southwesterly along the Chesapeake Bay shoreline to a point at or near the West end of Pleasure Island, defined by Lat. 39°13.85'N and Long. 76°23.65'W; then running approximately 245° True to a point at or near the east end of Patapsco River Neck, defined by Lat. 39°13.76'N and Long. 76°23.91'W; then running southwesterly along shore to a point at or near the east entrance of Shallow Creek, defined by Lat. 39°12.25'N and Long. 76°25.95'W; then running approximately 251° True to a point at or near the west entrance of Shallow Creek, defined by Lat. 39°12.19'N and Long. 76°26.20'W; then running southwesterly along shore to the point of beginning, defined by Lat. 39°11.72'N and Long. 76°26.53'W;

Chester River: All of the waters of Chester River and its tributaries upstream of a line beginning at a point at or near Love Point, defined by Lat. 39°02.40'N and Long. 76°18.16'W; then running approximately 83° True to a point at or near the northwesterly point of Eastern Neck Island, defined by Lat. 39°02.77'N and Long. 76°14.05'W; and downstream of a line beginning at a point at or near Hail Point, defined by Lat. 39°00.76'N and Long. 76°12.00'W; then running approximately 216° True to a point at or near Long Point, defined by Lat. 38°58.81'N and Long. 76°13.80'W; then running approximately 271° True to a point at or near Ferry Point, defined by Lat. 38°58.82'N and Long. 76°14.60'W;

Choptank River: All of the waters of the Choptank River and its tributaries upstream of a line beginning at a point at or near Cook Point, defined by Lat. 38°37.73'N and Long. 76°17.35'W; then running approximately 317° True to a point at or near Blackwalnut Point, defined by Lat. 38°40.24'N and Long. 76°20.37'W; and downstream of a line beginning at a point at or near Holland Point at the west entrance of Irish Creek, defined by Lat. 38°41.88'N and Long. 76°13.61'W; then running approximately 174° True to a point at or near a point of land at the west entrance of Chapel Creek, defined by Lat. 38°36.59'N and Long. 76°12.91'W; and

Patuxent River: All of the waters of the Patuxent River and its tributaries upstream of a line beginning at a point at or near Drum Point, defined by Lat. 38°19.14'N and Long. 76°25.27'W; then running approximately 119° True to a point at or near Hog Point, defined by Lat. 38°18.59'N and Long. 76°23.99'W; and downstream of a line beginning at a point at or near Point Patience, defined by Lat. 38°19.73'N and Long. 76°29.04'W; then running approximately 236° True to a point at or near the west point of land at the entrance of Little Kingston Creek, defined by Lat. 38°19.40'N and Long. 76°29.67'W.
Catch Restrictions.
A person may not catch or possess more than one striped bass per day.
A person may not catch or possess striped bass less than 19 inches in total length.
Susquehanna Flats and Northeast River.
The areas subject to the provisions of §A(3) of this regulation are:

Susquehanna Flats, upstream of a line from a point at or near Sandy Point, defined by Lat. 39°26.96'N and Long. 76°03.63'W; then running in an easterly direction to a point at or near Turkey Point, defined by Lat. 39°27.13'N and Long. 76°00.70'W and the Susquehanna River downstream from a line connecting a point at or near the Susquehanna State Park boat ramp in Lapidum, defined by Lat. 39°35.86'N and Long. 76°07.67'W; then running in a northeasterly direction to a point at or near Twin Rocks, defined by Lat. 39°36.17'N and Long. 76°07.56'W; then running in a northeasterly direction to a point at or near Tomes Wharf in Port Deposit, defined by Lat. 39°36.23'N and Long. 76°06.99'W; and
Northeast River.
Catch Restrictions.
A person may not catch or possess more than one striped bass per day.
A person may not use eels as bait.
A person may catch and possess one striped bass between 19 and 26 inches, inclusive, total length.
Summer and Fall Season.
Except for the closure specified in Regulation .12I(7) of this chapter, the recreational and charter boat summer and fall season for taking striped bass is June 1 through December 10.
The areas subject to the provisions of §B(1) of this regulation are the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries except for the tributaries of the Potomac River.
Catch Restrictions.
A person may not catch or possess more than one striped bass per day.
A person may not catch or possess striped bass less than 19 inches in total length.
General Restriction. When fishing in any area described in this regulation, all striped bass in a person's possession shall meet the size and possession limits set forth in regulation for that area.

section.heading: Recreational and Charter Boat Summer and Fall Fishery for Maryland Tributaries of the Potomac River.

para.text: Season. Except for the closure specified in Regulation .12I(7) of this chapter, the recreational and charter boat summer and fall season in the:
Areas described in Regulation .08D(3) of this regulation is May 16 through May 31; and
Maryland tributaries of the Potomac River downstream of Woodrow Wilson Bridge (I-95) is June 1 through December 10.
Catch Limit. A person may not catch or possess more than one striped bass per day.
Size Limit. A person may not catch or possess striped bass less than 19 inches in total length.
General Restriction. When fishing in any area described in this regulation, all striped bass in a person's possession shall meet the size and possession limits set forth in regulation for that area.

section.heading: Atlantic Coast Recreational and Charter Boat Fishery.

para.text: Minimum Size. A person may catch or possess striped bass in the Atlantic Ocean, its coastal bays, and their tributaries between 28 inches and 38 inches, inclusive, total length, or 44 inches or larger, total length.
Catch Limit. A person may not take or possess more than two striped bass per day.
A person may not use a gaff or similar device to remove striped bass from the water. A person who catches striped bass shall remove it from the water only by hand or dip net.
Possession of Striped Bass.
For purposes of this section, "cull" means that after a person has a striped bass in possession, the person discards or exchanges that striped bass to possess another striped bass.
During a recreational striped bass season:
Between 12 a.m. midnight and 5 a.m., a person may not possess striped bass while fishing on the tidal waters of the Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries; and
An individual may not cull striped bass.
Filleting Striped Bass.
Except as provided in §C(2) of this regulation, a person may only land striped bass dockside as a whole fish.
A licensed charter boat captain or mate may fillet striped bass taken on a vessel displaying a current commercial charter boat decal under the following conditions:
A striped bass carcass may not be mutilated to the extent that the total length or species of fish cannot be determined;
All striped bass carcasses:

Shall be retained, unmixed with any other material, in a separate container readily available for inspection until the vessel has docked and all passengers from that trip have left the vessel and the dock area; and
Are included in the possession limit; and
All striped bass carcasses from any previous trip shall be disposed of before any person begins to fish on a subsequent trip.
Except in ponds, lakes, reservoirs, or impoundments or as authorized by the Secretary, a person may not:
Conduct a fishing tournament or contest; or
Offer or give a reward or incentive to a recreational or fishing guide led angler for catching striped bass.
In addition to the requirements of this chapter, a person who fishes for striped bass shall be licensed in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701 or 4-745, Annotated Code of Maryland.
Mycobacteriosis Tagging Study.

A person licensed by the Department to fish in Maryland waters may catch and possess all striped bass captured with an attached fluorescent green tag that shows the toll-free number 866-845-3379 and either VIMS Gloucester Pt. VA or MD DNR Oxford, provided that person possessing the tagged striped bass immediately:
Places the striped bass on ice or in a cool shaded area;
Calls the toll-free number on the green tag; and
Provides the striped bass to a representative of the Department of Natural Resources.
Striped bass tagged with the specified fluorescent green tag may be caught using legal fishing gear and possessed:
In excess of the daily catch limit;
Outside of the striped bass season;
Above or below the size limits; and
In those areas and times in which capture and possession are otherwise prohibited.
Restrictions for Charter Boats.
During a chartered fishing trip, the captain or mate may not land or possess striped bass for personal consumption.
A fishing guide licensee may not make more than two charter trips daily to fish for striped bass.
Season Limitations.

In order to implement the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission Interstate Fishery Management Plan for Striped Bass, the Secretary may modify or close a season or catch limit, set a monthly catch limit, modify a size limit, or require specific vessel trip information by issuing a public notice on the Fisheries Service website that shall state its effective hour and date at least 48 hours in advance of the effective hour and date.
The Secretary shall make a reasonable effort to disseminate a public notice issued under this section through various other media so that an affected person has reasonable opportunity to be informed.
A violation of the restrictions set by the Secretary in accordance with §H of this regulation is a violation of this regulation.
Seasonal Restrictions for the Recreational and Charter Boat Fishery.
Definition.
In this section, the following term has the meaning indicated.
Term Defined. "Target" means to catch or attempt to catch.

Except as provided in §I(3) of this regulation, a person may not target striped bass or striped bass hybrids in the striped bass spawning rivers and areas listed in Regulation .03B of this chapter during the period March 1 through March 31.

During the period March 1 through March 31, inclusive, a person authorized in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-745, Annotated Code of Maryland, to recreationally angle for finfish may hook striped bass and shall immediately release the striped bass unharmed to the water from which the striped bass was taken in the following areas:

Susquehanna Flats, upstream of a line from a point at or near Sandy Point, defined by Lat. 39°26.96' N and Long. 76°03.63' W; then running in an easterly direction to a point at or near Turkey Point, defined by Lat. 39°27.13' N and Long. 76°00.70' W and the Susquehanna River downstream from a line connecting a point at or near the Susquehanna State Park boat ramp in Lapidum, defined by Lat. 39°35.86' N and Long. 76°07.67' W; then running in a northeasterly direction to a point at or near Twin Rocks, defined by Lat. 39°36.17' N and Long. 76°07.56' W; then running in a northeasterly direction to a point at or near Tomes Wharf in Port Deposit, defined by Lat. 39°36.23' N and Long. 76°06.99' W;
Northeast River; and

The area of the Chester River on the north side of Kent Narrows and bounded on the southern side by the southernmost edge of the old Route 50 bridge and, on the northern side, by a line beginning at a point (east tip of Ferry Point) defined by Lat. 38°58.820'N and Long. 76°14.627'W; then running approximately 92° True to a point (northwest tip of Long Point) defined by Lat. 38°58.798'N and Long. 76°13.825'W.
During the period April 1 through April 30, a person may not target striped bass or striped bass hybrids in the Chesapeake Bay or its tidal tributaries.

During the period May 1 through May 31, except as provided in Regulations .08 and .09 of this chapter and §I(6) of this regulation, a person may not target striped bass or striped bass hybrids in the striped bass spawning rivers and areas listed in Regulation .03B of this chapter.

During the period May 1 through May 31, a person authorized in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-745, Annotated Code of Maryland, to recreationally angle for finfish may hook striped bass and shall immediately release the striped bass unharmed to the water from which the striped bass was taken in that area of the Chester River on the north side of Kent Narrows and bounded on the southern side by the southernmost edge of the old Route 50 bridge and, on the northern side, by a line beginning at a point (east tip of Ferry Point) defined by Lat. 38°58.820'N and Long. 76°14.627'W; then running approximately 92° True to a point (northwest tip of Long Point) defined by Lat. 38°58.798'N and Long. 76°13.825'W.
During the period July 16 through July 31, a person may not target striped bass or striped bass hybrids in the Chesapeake Bay or its tidal tributaries.

container.heading: Oyster Recovery Areas
container.text: Authority: Natural Resources Article §§4-2A-03 and 4-215, Annotated Code of Maryland

section.heading: Scope.
section.text: This chapter applies to oyster recovery areas and the types of activities which can be conducted in these areas.

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
"Certified seed" or "certified oyster" means seed oysters having zero prevalence and intensity of MSX and dermo at the time of planting, as determined by current technology.
"Oyster recovery areas (ORA)" means the geographic areas in the Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries designated for management actions.
"Zones" means geographic areas within oyster recovery areas where specific management actions may occur and which are designated as Zones A, B, or C.

section.heading: Oyster Recovery Areas.
section.text: The following tributaries of the Chesapeake Bay are designated as oyster recovery areas for specific management actions:

para.text: Chester River;
Choptank River;
Severn River;
Magothy River;
Nanticoke River; and
Patuxent River.
The following geographic areas in §B-G of this regulation designate zones within each ORA for specific management actions.
Chester River.
Zone A is upstream from a line which runs from Lat. 39°06'31.6", Long. 76°07'06.8" southeast from Deep Point across the river to Lat. 39°06'11.5", Long. 76°06'48.8" east of Spaniard Point.

Zone B is upstream from a line connecting Spaniard Point at Lat. 39°05'33.2", Long. 76°08'43.8" with the other side of the river in a northwest direction to Lat. 39°06'16.0", Long. 76°09'37.1" up to the boundary of Zone A.
Zone C is downstream from the lower boundary of Zone B to the mouth of the river defined by a line from Love Point to the northwest tip of Eastern Neck Island.
Choptank River.
Zone A is upstream from just south of Jamaica Point at Lat. 38°36'38.6", Long. 75°59'09.8" across to the southern edge of the mouth of the Warwick River at Lat. 38°36'19.8", Long. 75°58'36.0".
Zone B is downstream approximately 4,000 yards from the boundary of Zone A to Lat. 38°34'36.6", Long. 76°00'23.5" across the river to Lat. 38°35'20.3", Long. 76°01'15.0".
Zone C is downstream from the lower boundary of Zone B to the mouth of the Choptank River.
Severn River.
Zone A is downstream from the Route 50 bridge and upstream from the Maryland Department of Environment's restricted line.
Zone B is upstream from the Route 50 bridge.
Magothy River.
Zone B encompasses all of the area upstream of a line from Chest Neck Point, Lat. 39°04'17.55", Long. 76°30'08.29" to South Ferry Point, Lat. 39°04'42.56", Long. 76°29'32.54".
Zone C encompasses the area downstream of a line from Chest Neck Point to South Ferry Point to the mouth of the river.
Nanticoke River.
Zone B is an area upstream of a line from the southern shore of the mouth of Lower Greens Cove, Lat. 38°20'28.34", Long. 75°54'47.60" to Hatcrown Point, Lat. 38°19'44.70", Long. 75°52'56.68".
Zone C is an area downstream of a line from the southern shore of the mouth of Lower Greens Cove to Hatcrown Point.
Patuxent River.
Zone B is upstream of a line from Holland Point, Lat. 38°30'28.71", Long. 76°39'57.57" to the west shore of the river, Lat. 38°30'27.63", Long. 76°40'42.78".
Zone C is downstream of a line from Holland Point to the west shore of the river.
Shellfish Harvest. Except as provided in §C of this regulation, shellfish harvesting is prohibited in an area designated as Zone A listed in Regulation .03 of this chapter.
Seed Certification. Only certified seed shall be planted in areas designated as Zone A and Zone B.
Chester River. Clam harvesting is permitted in an area designated as Zone A listed in Regulation .04B of this chapter.

container.heading: Fish Refuges
container.text: Authority: Natural Resources Article, §§4-405, 4-407, and 4-410, Annotated Code of Maryland

section.heading: Chicamuxen Creek.
section.text: A person may not enter, remain in, or catch or attempt to catch fish in the designated portion of Chicamuxen Creek, north of Linton Point off the Potomac River in Charles County, which encompasses the area northeast of a line running from a point at or near the shore defined by Lat. 038°32'30.7"N., Long. 077°13'59.0"W., then running approximately 184°True to a point at or near the shore defined by Lat. 038°32'13.7"N., Long. 077°14'00.7"W., from March 1 through June 15. This defined portion of Chicamuxen Creek is designated as a State fish refuge during this time period.

container.heading: Fishing Guide Provisions
container.text: Authority: Natural Resources Article, §§4-206, 4-210, 4-210.1, 4-215, 4-701, and 4-745, Annotated Code of Maryland

section.heading: Scope.
section.text: This chapter applies to an individual who is licensed in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-210 or 4-210.1, Annotated Code of Maryland, to accept direct or indirect consideration for providing services as a fishing guide to an individual fishing in the waters of the State. This chapter also applies to an individual under the guidance of the licensee.

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
"Department" means the Department of Natural Resources.
"Licensee" means an individual who holds a valid type NT, type NTT, or type L fishing guide license issued by the Department.
"Nonresident" means an individual who resides in a state other than Maryland on the date of application for or renewal of a fishing guide license.
Resident.
"Resident" means an individual who resides in this State on the date of application for or renewal of a fishing guide license.
"Resident" includes a member of the armed forces of the United States who is:
On active duty; and
Stationed officially in this State.
"Striped bass" means the species Morone saxatilis, also known as rockfish, and all hybrids of striped bass.

"Fishing guide" means an individual who accepts direct or indirect consideration for providing instruction, direction, supervision, or transportation to an individual for the purpose of catching fish by angling.

section.heading: Freshwater Fishing Guide License Type NT.

para.text: A type NT freshwater fishing guide license, as authorized by Natural Resources Article, §4-210.1, Annotated Code of Maryland, authorizes the licensee to provide fishing guide services only in the nontidal waters of the State.
Striped Bass. An angler under the guidance of a licensee with a valid type NT license in nontidal waters of the State may:
Hook striped bass and immediately release the striped bass unharmed to the water from which the striped bass was taken; and
Harvest striped bass from the following areas:
Youghiogheny Reservoir;
Piney Run Reservoir;
Tridelphia Reservoir;
Loch Raven Reservoir;
Prettyboy Reservoir;

para.heading: T.
para.text: Howard Duckett (Rocky Gorge) Reservoir;
Liberty Reservoir; and
Conowingo Reservoir.
Fees. The fees for a type NT license are:
For a resident, $20; and
For a nonresident, $50.
General. Except in Deep Creek Lake, the maximum number of individuals present on a vessel which is operated by a licensee may not exceed four, including the licensee.

section.heading: Freshwater Fishing Guide License Type NTT.

para.text: A type NTT freshwater fishing guide license, as authorized by Natural Resources Article, §4-210.1, Annotated Code of Maryland, authorizes the licensee to provide fishing guide services in nontidal waters and designated tidal waters of the State.
Fishing Area. A type NTT license authorizes the licensee to provide fishing guide services in:
All nontidal waters of the State; and
The following designated areas located in tidal waters of the State:
Chesapeake Bay upstream of a line from Sandy Point on Spesutie Island to Turkey Point;
Elk River upstream of a line from Turkey Point to the State launching ramp at Pearce Creek;
Pond Creek upstream of a line connecting the two unnamed points at the entrance to the creek;
Sassafras River upstream of a line from Grove Point to Howell Point;
Still Pond Creek upstream of a line from Meeks Point to Rocky Point;
Worton Creek upstream of a line from Copeland Point to Handys Point;
Fairlee Creek upstream of a line across the entrance of the creek;
Chester River upstream of a line from Spaniard Point to Nichols Point;
Corsica River, a tributary of the Chester River, upstream of a line from Spaniard Point to Holton Point;
Langford Creek, a tributary of the Chester River, upstream of a line from Nichols Point to Grays Inn Point;
Grays Inn Creek, a tributary of the Chester River, upstream from Grays Inn Point to Little Gum Point;
Choptank River upstream of the Dover Bridge on Route 331;
Blackwater River upstream of a line from the lower point of Snake Island to the southernmost point on the opposite shore;
Transquaking River upstream of a line from Alabaster Point running magnetic north to the opposite shore;
Nanticoke River upstream of a line from Long Point to Runaway Point;
Wicomico River upstream of the Whitehaven ferry crossing;
Pocomoke River upstream of the landing at Rehobeth;
Maryland tributaries of the Potomac River above the Route 301 bridge;
Wicomico River, a tributary of the Potomac River, upstream of a line from Mills Point in a westerly direction to the northernmost point at the entrance to Dolly Boarmans Creek;
Patuxent River upstream of the overhead power lines north of Gods Grace Point;
Swanson Creek, a tributary of the Patuxent River, upstream of a line from Teague Point to Chalk Point;
Patapsco River upstream of the Hanover Street crossing parallel to the Potee Street crossing;
Back River upstream of a line from Cuckhold Point to Rocky Point;
Middle River upstream of a line from Booby Point to Bowley Bar Point;
Seneca Creek upstream of a line from Bowley Bar Point to Lowen Point;
Gunpowder River upstream of a line from Weir Point to Rickett Point; and
Bush River upstream of a line from Abbey Point to Sandy Point.
Striped Bass.
Notwithstanding COMAR 08.02.15.08-.11, an angler under the guidance of a licensee with a valid type NTT license in tidal waters of the State may not possess the species of fish known as striped bass.

Notwithstanding COMAR 08.02.15, an angler under the guidance of a licensee with a valid type NTT license in tidal waters of the State may not catch or attempt to catch striped bass from waters of the State north of a line drawn from Abbey Point to Worton Point, from March 1 through May 31, inclusive.
An angler under the guidance of a licensee with a valid type NTT license in nontidal waters of the State may:
Hook striped bass and immediately release the striped bass unharmed to the water from which the striped bass was taken; and
Harvest striped bass from the areas set forth in Regulation .03 of this chapter.
Fees. The fees for a type NTT license are:
For a resident, $50; and
For a nonresident, $100.
License Allocations.
The number of type NTT licenses issued annually is limited to:
120 for residents; and
30 for nonresidents.
The Department shall maintain separate waiting lists of qualified resident and nonresident individuals in chronological order who have applied for a type NTT license.
A type NTT license that is revoked or voluntarily relinquished to the Department may be reallocated to an individual who meets all qualifications for a type NTT license.
The Department shall issue a type NTT license to the first individual on the appropriate waiting list described in §D(2) of this regulation when a license is available.
General. Except in Deep Creek Lake, the maximum number of individuals present on a vessel which is operated by a licensee may not exceed four, including the licensee.

section.heading: Limited Fishing Guide License Type L.

para.text: A type L limited fishing guide license, as authorized by Natural Resources Article, §4-210, Annotated Code of Maryland, authorizes the licensee to provide fishing guide services in all waters of the State.
Striped Bass.
Notwithstanding COMAR 08.02.15, an angler under the guidance of a licensee with a valid type L license in tidal waters of the State may not catch or possess striped bass in the following areas:
Chesapeake Bay upstream of a line from Sandy Point on Spesutie Island to Turkey Point;
Elk River upstream of a line from Turkey Point to the State launching ramp at Pearce Creek;
Pond Creek upstream of a line connecting the two unnamed points at the entrance to the creek;
Sassafras River upstream of a line from Grove Point to Howell Point;
Still Pond Creek upstream of a line from Meeks Point to Rocky Point;
Worton Creek upstream of a line from Copeland's Point to Handys Point;
Fairlee Creek upstream of a line across the entrance of the creek;
Chester River upstream of a line from Spaniard Point to Nichols Point;
Corsica River, a tributary of the Chester River, upstream of a line from Spaniard Point to Holton Point;
Langford Creek, a tributary of the Chester River, upstream of a line from Nichols Point to Grays Inn Point;
Grays Inn Creek, a tributary of the Chester River, upstream from Grays Inn Point to Little Gum Point;
Choptank River upstream of the Dover Bridge on Route 331;
Blackwater River upstream of a line from the lower point of Snake Island to the southernmost point on the opposite shore;
Transquaking River upstream of a line from Alabaster Point running magnetic north to the opposite shore;
Nanticoke River upstream of a line from Long Point to Runaway Point;
Wicomico River upstream of the Whitehaven ferry crossing;
Pocomoke River upstream of the landing at Rehobeth;
Wicomico River, a tributary of the Potomac River, upstream of a line from Mills Point in a westerly direction to the northernmost point at the entrance to Dolly Boarmans Creek;
Patuxent River upstream of the overhead power lines north of Gods Grace Point;
Swanson Creek, a tributary of the Patuxent River, upstream of a line from Teague Point to Chalk Point;
Patapsco River upstream of the Hanover Street crossing parallel to the Potee Street crossing;
Back River upstream of a line from Cuckhold Point to Rocky Point;
Middle River upstream of a line from Booby Point to Bowley Bar Point;
Seneca Creek upstream of a line from Bowley Bar Point to Lowen Point;
Gunpowder River upstream of a line from Weir Point to Rickett Point;
Bush River upstream of a line from Abbey Point to Sandy Point; and
Maryland tributaries of the Potomac River above the Route 301 bridge.

Notwithstanding COMAR 08.02.15, an angler under the guidance of a licensee with a valid type L license in tidal waters of the State may not catch or attempt to catch striped bass from waters of the State north of a line drawn from Abbey Point to Worton Point, from March 1 through May 31, inclusive.
An angler under the guidance of a licensee with a valid type L license in nontidal waters of the State may:
Hook striped bass and immediately release the striped bass unharmed to the water from which the striped bass was taken; and
Harvest striped bass from the areas set forth in Regulation .03 of this chapter.
Fees. The fees for a type L license are:
For a resident, $50; and
For a nonresident, $100.
General. A type L licensee may guide:
Anglers in no more than three boats or vessels that:
Have one or two occupants per boat; and
Are propelled by human power;
Ten anglers on foot; or
Any number of anglers who are participating in an educational or recreational program sponsored by a State, local, or municipal government and who are fishing from shore or on foot in the water.
Licensee Requirements. In addition to a type NT, NTT, or L license, a licensee shall possess, as applicable, the following when engaged in fishing guide activities:
A valid angler's license in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-604, Annotated Code of Maryland;
A valid Chesapeake Bay and coastal sport fishing license or registration in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-745, Annotated Code of Maryland;
Any necessary stamps issued by the Department; and
A valid license issued by the U. S. Coast Guard.
Safety Requirements. An applicant for a type NT, NTT, or L license shall provide a valid copy of the following documentation:
A cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) certificate; and
An American Red Cross First Aid Certification or equivalent.
Angler Requirements. An individual guided by a licensee shall possess, as applicable:
A valid angler's license in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-604, Annotated Code of Maryland,
A valid Chesapeake Bay and coastal sport fishing license or registration in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-745, Annotated Code of Maryland; and
Any necessary stamps issued by the Department.
Dividing Lines. The dividing lines for tidal and nontidal waters are designated in COMAR 08.02.01.09.
A licensee may not possess fish for personal use while providing fishing guide services.
Term. A type NT, NTT, or L license is valid from the date of issuance through December 31 of each year following the date of issuance.
Renewal. A licensee may renew a type NT, NTT, or L license for an additional 1 year term if the licensee:
Is otherwise entitled to hold the license;
Provides a valid copy of the documents set forth in §B of this regulation; and
Submits to the Department, by December 31:
A renewal application on the form that the Department requires; and
The applicable annual fee.
Reporting.
A licensee shall submit reports as required on forms provided by the Department.

Any person who is licensed to guide fishing parties on tidal waters shall accurately record their catch on a commercial charter boat captain's daily log and submit the log in accordance with COMAR 08.02.13.06.

container.heading: Nuisance and Prohibited Species
container.text: Authority: Natural Resources Article, §§4-205.1 and 4-816, Annotated Code of Maryland

section.heading: Purpose.
section.text: The purpose of this chapter is to control the importation, possession, propagation, transport, purchase, sale, or introduction into State waters of certain nonnative aquatic organisms that if accidentally or deliberately introduced into or further spread in the waters of the State would alter and threaten to harm the ecosystem, the abundance and diversity of native or naturalized aquatic organisms, or the productivity of State waters.

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.

"Aquaculture" means the rearing for commercial purposes of a species of fish or aquatic plant as listed in and described in COMAR 08.02.14 and may include the purchase, sale, possession, capture, production, breeding, transportation, and processing of fish or aquatic plants.
"Aquatic organism" means a living organism that spends part of its life in water.
"Felt sole" means a sole to which felt or any other natural or synthetic porous material capable of absorbing liquid is attached.
"Historically" means commonly accepted to have been in State waters in the year 1500.
"Hybrid" means the offspring of any species of fish of genetically dissimilar parents or stock.
"Introduction into State waters" means the deliberate or accidental release of an aquatic organism into State waters.
"Native" means having historically lived, grown, and reproduced in State waters.
"Naturalized" means documented as having lived, grown, and reproduced in State waters for more than 10 years without known harm to the ecosystem.
"Nonnative " means any species other than native or naturalized.
"Nuisance organism" means a nonnative aquatic organism that will foreseeably alter and threaten to harm the ecosystem or the abundance and diversity of native or naturalized aquatic organisms.

"State waters" means tidal and nontidal waters located within the boundaries of the State, including that portion of the Atlantic Ocean within the boundaries of the State, the Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries, and all ponds, lakes, rivers, streams, public ditches, tax ditches, and public drainage systems within the State.
"Transgenic" means an organism into which genetic material from another organism has been experimentally transferred so that the host acquires the genetic traits of the transferred genes.

"Transport" means to move a nonnative aquatic organism from the waters of one watershed, as named by Maryland Integrated Watershed Data and Information System 6-digit map, and introduce it into the waters of another watershed, as named by Maryland Integrated Watershed Data and Information System 6-digit map.

"Without known harm" means a species has acclimated or adapted to life in Maryland's waters for more than 50 years without diminishing the abundance, diversity, distribution or reproduction of a native species or degrading water quality requirements for a native species.
A term used in this chapter and not defined in this regulation has:
The meaning given to the term in a relevant statute or regulation; or
If not defined in statute or regulation, the meaning attributed in common use.

section.heading: Transgenic.
section.text: A person may not introduce into State waters any transgenic aquatic organism.

para.text: A person may not import, transport, purchase, possess, propagate, sell, or release into State waters the following nonnative aquatic organisms:
Fish species:
Alabama bass (Micropterus hensalli);
Asian horseshoe crabs (Tachypleus tridentatus, Tachypleus gigas, Carcinoscorpius rotundicauda);
Asian swamp eel (Monoterus albus);
Bighead carp (Hypophthalmichthys nobilis);
Black carp (Mylopharynodon piceus);
Candiru (Vandellia cirrhosa);
Chinese mitten crab (Eriocheir sinensis);
Eurasian river ruffe (Gymnocephalus cernuus);
Grass carp (Ctenopharyngodon idella);
Marbled crayfish (marmorkrebs) (Procambarus sp.);
New Zealand Mudsnail (Potamopyrgus anitpodarum);
Quagga mussel (Dreissena bugensis);
Red shiner (Notropis lutrensis, Cyprinella lutrensis);
Round goby (Neogobius melanostomus);
Rudd (Scardinius erythrophthalmus);
Rusty crayfish (Orconectes rusticus);
Silver carp (Hypophthalmichthys molitrix);
Spotted bass (Micropterus punctulatus);
Veined rapa whelk (Rapana venosa);
Walking catfish (Clarius batrachus); and
Zebra mussel (Dreissena polymorpha); and
Aquatic plant species:
Giant salvinia (Salvinia molesta); and
Green Caulerpa seaweed (Caulerpa taxifolia).
A person may not transport the following nonnative aquatic organisms:
Fish species:
Blue catfish (Ictalurus furcatus);
Flathead catfish (Pylodictis olivaris);
Green crab (Carcinus manenas);
Japanese shore crab (Hemigrapsus sanguineus);
Mimic shiner (Notropis volucellus);
Red swamp crayfish (Procambarus clarkii);
Southern white river crayfish (Procambarus zonangulus); and
Virile crayfish (Orconectes virilis); and
Aquatic plant species:
Brazilian elodea (Egeria densa);
Hydrilla (Hydrilla verticillata);
Parrot feather (Myriophyllum aquaticum, Myriophyllum brasiliense); and
Water chestnut (Trapa natans).
A person may not import, transport, purchase, propagate, sell, or release into State waters the following nonnative aquatic organisms:
Australian crayfish of genus Cherax (Cherax);
Chinese mystery snail (Cipangopaludina chinensis, Viviparus malleatus); and
Oriental weatherfish (Misgurnus anguillicaudatus).
Permit.

A person may not import, transport, purchase, possess, propagate, or sell a nonnative aquatic organism listed in §A of this regulation, or transport a nonnative aquatic organism listed in §B of this regulation, or import, transport, purchase, propagate, or sell a nonnative aquatic organism listed in §C of this regulation, unless the person has been issued a permit by the Department, as specified in Natural Resources Article, §4-212 or 4-11A-02, Annotated Code of Maryland.
A permit may be granted only if satisfactory proof is presented to the Department that the organism is free of a communicable disease.
An application for the permit shall be filed with the Department not less than 60 days before the proposed date of importation.

An application for an activity listed in §D(1) of this regulation that is in progress at the time of adoption of this regulation shall be filed within 60 days after the date of adoption of this regulation.
A permitted nonnative aquatic organism may be held only in a secure facility from which escape into State waters is not possible.
A permit is not required if:
The species is being transported to the Department or another destination as the Secretary may direct:
In a sealed container or dead; and
For purposes of species identification or reporting the presence of the species; or

The specimen has been lawfully acquired dead and, in the case of plant species, all seeds are removed or otherwise secured in a sealed container or is in the form of herbaria or other preserved museum specimens.

A person may not place or attempt to place upon or into State waters a watercraft or associated equipment with attached or contained aquatic plants, zebra mussels, or other prohibited species of nonnative organisms.
Water taken from waters infested by prohibited nonnative species may not be diverted, appropriated, or transported on public roads except in the following circumstances:
In an emergency declared by appropriate local or State authorities, such as a fire emergency;
As specified in water appropriation or public waters work permits; or
Under a permit issued by the Secretary.

Except as authorized by 50 CFR Part 16, a person may not import, transport, or introduce into the State any live fish or viable eggs of snakehead fish of the Family Channidae, including but not limited to:
African snakehead (Parachanna obscura);
Bangka snakehead (Channa bankanensis);
Baram snakehead (Channa baramensis);
Barca snakehead (Channa barca);
Black snakehead (Channa melasoma);
Blackfinned snakehead (Channa melanoptera);
Blotched snakehead (Channa maculata);
Bluespotted snakehead (Channa cyanospilos);
Bullseye snakehead (Channa marulius);
Burmese snakehead (Channa burmanica);
Ceylon snakehead (Channa orientalis);
Chel snakehead (Channa amphibeus);
Chevron snakehead (Channa striata);
Chinese snakehead (Channa asiatica);
Congo snakehead (Parachanna insignis);
Dwarf snakehead (Channa gachua);
Emperor snakehead (Channa maruloides);
Giant snakehead (Channa micropeltes);
Golden snakehead (Channa stewartii);
Inle snakehead (Channa harcourtbutleri);
Niger snakehead (Parachanna africana);
Night snakehead (Channa nox);
Northern snakehead (Channa argus);
Ocellated snakehead (Channa pleurophthalmus);
Orangespotted snakehead (Channa aurantimaculata);
Panaw snakehead (Channa panaw);
Rainbow snakehead (Channa bleheri);
Splendid snakehead (Channa lucius); and
Spotted snakehead (Channa punctata).
A person may not sell or breed live snakehead fish of the Family Channidae in the State.
Except as provided in §D of this regulation, a person may not possess the viable eggs or live snakehead fish of the species:
Blotched snakehead (Channa maculata); and
Northern snakehead (Channa argus).
Except as described in §E of this regulation, an individual may only possess a snakehead if, immediately upon capture, the snakehead is killed.
The Department may issue a permit for the possession of a live snakehead fish for scientific purposes to a properly accredited person of known scientific attainment.

section.heading: Felt-Soled Waders.
section.text: An individual may not use footgear with external felt soles in State waters or within five feet of State waters.

container.heading: Bait
container.text: Authority: Natural Resources Article, §§4-219 and 4-602, Annotated Code of Maryland

section.heading: Purpose.
section.text: The purpose of this chapter is to control the use of bait in State waters and implement Natural Resources Article, §4-702, Annotated Code of Maryland, which requires licensure of persons dealing in finfish or shellfish and provides an exception for those persons who catch and sell certain species of finfish or shellfish as bait.

para.text: Bait. For the purpose of this subtitle, "bait" means an attractant to catch fish which includes:
The living or dead, whole body or part of body of an animal; or
A processed product from an animal or vegetative source.
Bait Harvester Permit.

Prior to harvesting the species listed in §C of this regulation, an individual not licensed in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland, shall obtain a bait harvester permit from the Department.

A bait harvester permit shall be issued to an individual who has paid the fee for the permit as described in Natural Resources Article, §4-702, Annotated Code of Maryland to the Department and has met all reporting requirements as required by this regulation.
An individual harvesting bait in accordance with this chapter shall have the Department-issued bait harvester permit in possession while harvesting or transporting bait.
A bait harvester permit may not be transferred.
Bait harvester permits issued by the Department shall be valid beginning on September 1 and expire on August 31 of the following year.

Species. The only species of finfish or shellfish as described at COMAR 08.02.08.03 that may be caught and sold for use as fishing bait by an individual who is not licensed in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland, are:
Mummichog (Fundulus heteroclitus);
Striped killifish (Fundulus majalis);
Banded killifish (Fundulus diaphanous);
Spottail shiner (Notropis hudsonius);
Golden shiner (Notemigonus crysoleucas);
Rough silverside (Membras martinica);
Silverside (Menidia species);
Anchovy (Anchoa species);
Silvery minnow (Hybognathus nuchalis);
Mole crab (Emerita species); and
Grass shrimp (Palaemonetes species).
Methods.

An individual who is not licensed in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland, may use only the following methods and gear as defined in COMAR 08.02.25.01, to catch bait finfish or shellfish from the tidal waters of the State:
Cast net;
Dip net;
Seine;
Hook and line; and
Trap.
A cast net shall be thrown by hand and have a radius not greater than 10 feet.
A dip net shall be operated by hand.
A seine:
May not be emptied on the shore or beach or in any water less than sufficient depth to enable the unwanted fish to return to the waters alive;
Shall have mesh no greater than 1/4 inch; and
May not exceed 50 feet in width and 5 feet in height.
A trap shall:
Be clearly labeled with the permittee's DNRid number; and
Be emptied at least once every 24-hour period.
Seasons and Limits.
Season. There is no closed season.

Daily Catch and Possession Limits. The daily catch and possession limit of bait finfish or shellfish for an individual who is not licensed in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland, is as follows:
Mummichog (Fundulus heteroclitus): 10 gallons;
Striped killifish (Fundulus majalis): 10 gallons;
Banded killifish (Fundulus diaphanous): 10 gallons;
Spottail shiner (Notropis hudsonius): 600 individuals;
Golden shiner (Notemigonus crysoleucas): 600 individuals;
Rough silverside (Membras martinica): 600 individuals;
Anchovy (Anchoa species): 600 individuals;
Silvery minnow (Hybognathus nuchalis): 600 individuals;
Mole crab (Emerita species): 5 gallons; and
Grass shrimp (Palaemonetes species): 5 gallons.
Reporting. A person permitted by the Department to harvest bait shall:
Record their catch on the bait harvester report;
Submit the bait harvester report as required by the Department; and
Make available daily information and harvest report cards for immediate inspection on request of a Department representative.
Penalties.
In addition to any other penalty established in COMAR 08.02.13, failure to comply with this regulation may result in the denial of a subsequent permit.

Prior to suspending a permit under this regulation or denying an application for a permit, the Department shall give the licensee notice of its intended action and an opportunity to appear at a hearing conducted in accordance with the contested case procedures set forth in State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland, and COMAR 08.01.04
The species listed in this regulation may not be used as bait in State waters.
Prohibited species:
Largemouth bass;
Muskellunge;
Northern pike;
Pickerel;
Smallmouth bass;
Striped bass;
Striped bass hybrids;
Tiger muskellunge;
Brook trout;
Brown trout; and
Walleye.

container.heading: Yellow Perch
container.text: Authority: Natural Resources Article, §§1-104, 4-206, 4-215, 4-215.2, 4-602, and 4-701; State Government Article, §10-206; Annotated Code of Maryland

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
"Harvest" means to take, kill, trap, gather, catch, or in any manner reduce any fish to personal possession or to attempt to engage in this conduct.
"Landing" means:
Unloading any fish at a dock, pier, or shore by a commercial fisherman; or
Bringing any fish to a dock, pier, or shore by a recreational fisherman for personal use.
"Tag" means the device or form approved by the Department and affixed to a fish.
"Target harvest" means pounds or numbers of yellow perch allowed by the Department to be harvested in a season.
"Total length" means the distance from the tip of the snout to the end of the longest lobe of the extended tail of a fish.
"Yellow perch" means the species of fish Perca flavescens.
"Yellow perch harvest permit" means a permit issued by the Department which allows a person to commercially harvest yellow perch.
Season. The recreational season is open year round.
Size.
Except as provided in §B(2) of this regulation, the minimum size for yellow perch harvested from waters of the State is 9 inches total length.
There is no minimum size for yellow perch harvested from reservoirs, lakes, ponds, impoundments, and waters upstream of them.
Creel and Possession Limits.
Except as provided in §C(2) of this regulation, the daily catch and possession limit for yellow perch is ten fish per person per day.
There is no daily catch limit for reservoirs, lakes, ponds, impoundments, and waters upstream of them.
Reporting. A recreational angler shall cooperate with Department-approved surveys and catch inspections necessary for harvest and by-catch determination, and biological characterization.
Season.
The commercial season for harvesting yellow perch is January 1 through March 31, inclusive.
Yellow perch legally harvested in another state may be sold or offered for sale in Maryland if accompanied by proof of origin which details the total weight of yellow perch for each container.
Size.
The minimum size for yellow perch is 8-1/2 inches total length.
The maximum size for yellow perch is 11 inches total length.
Daily Catch Limits.
Hook and Line. The daily catch limit for yellow perch harvested by means of hook and line from the tidal waters of the State is ten fish per person per day.
Gear Other than Hook and Line.

A commercial tidal fish licensee permitted in accordance with §E of this regulation to harvest yellow perch commercially may harvest up to 150 pounds of yellow perch per day from the Patuxent River fishing area defined in §D(3) of this regulation.
There is no daily catch limit for the fishing area defined in §D(1) or (2) of this regulation.
The Department shall set an annual commercial target harvest for each fishing area defined in §D of this regulation.
Fishing Areas. A person may fish for yellow perch for commercial purposes only in the following areas:
Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries, excluding the Magothy River and the Chester River, upstream of the William Preston Lane Jr. Memorial Bridge northern span;

Chester River upstream of a line beginning at a point at or near Love Point, defined by Lat. 39°02.40'N and Long. 76°18.16'W; then running approximately 83° True to a point at or near the northwest point of Eastern Neck Island, defined by Lat. 39°02.77'N and Long. 76°14.05'W; and

Patuxent River upstream of a line drawn from a point at or near Hog Point, defined by Lat. 38°18.59'N and Long. 76°23.99'W; then running approximately 299° True to a point at or near Drum Point, defined by Lat. 38°19.14'N and Long. 76°25.27'W; and downstream of a line beginning at a point at or near Jackson Landing defined by Lat. 38°46.46'N and Long. 76°42.70'W; then running approximately 45° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°46.48'N and Long. 76°42.68'W.
Yellow Perch Harvest Permit.
A person catching yellow perch for commercial purposes shall:
Be licensed to fish for commercial purposes in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland;
Obtain a valid yellow perch harvest permit issued by the Department; and
Have the Department issued yellow perch harvest permit in possession while harvesting or transporting yellow perch.
Yellow perch harvest permits issued by the Department shall be valid during the current commercial season for harvesting yellow perch.
Declaration.

During the period August 1 through October 31, unless otherwise directed by public notice, a commercial tidal fish licensee shall declare their intent to fish for yellow perch by paying the fee as established in Natural Resources Article, §4-701(f)(1)(ii), Annotated Code of Maryland.

A commercial tidal fish licensee who has not declared by October 31 of the current year or the close of business the next business day when October 31 occurs on a weekend or holiday, may not catch yellow perch for sale or participate during the subsequent commercial yellow perch season.

An exception to the October 31 deadline may be considered by the Department only for an individual who can provide satisfactory documentation of a physical or mental incapacity that prevented that individual from meeting the declaration time period established in §F(1) of this regulation.
Tags.
The Department shall provide tags to each commercial tidal fish licensee who is authorized to participate in the commercial yellow perch fishery.
The Department may not provide replacement tags for tags that are lost.
Except as provided in §I of this regulation, before landing a yellow perch, an individual shall affix a tag to the yellow perch as directed by the Department.
A commercial tidal fish licensee shall return any unused tags to the Department within 14 days of the end of the permitted season.
Transfers.
Yellow perch harvest permits and tags may not be transferred.

If an individual transfers a tidal fish license during the yellow perch season, the yellow perch harvest permit and tags assigned to that individual shall be returned to the Department within 14 days of the license transfer.
Yellow Perch Live Market.
A commercial tidal fish licensee who sells or offers for sale yellow perch in the live market which were harvested from the tidal waters of the State shall:
Contact the Department at the number stated on the yellow perch harvest permit at least 24 hours prior to loading yellow perch into a container in which it will be transported; and
Keep a bill of lading or other proof of sale and provide a copy of that documentation to the Department within 14 days of the end of the permitted season.
The bill of lading or other proof of sale shall contain the total weight of yellow perch sold and the date of the sale.
Reporting. A commercial tidal fish licensee permitted by the Department to harvest yellow perch shall:
Complete all information on the yellow perch harvest permit card and on the daily commercial fisheries catch log;
Report daily catch, regardless of amount, to the Department by 11:59 p.m. every day through the Department-described process;
Return the daily commercial fisheries catch log to the Department within the time specified by the Department in accordance with COMAR 08.02.13.06;
Return the completed yellow perch harvest permit card to the Department within 14 days of the end of the permitted season;
Make available yellow perch harvest permit cards, tags, and catch logs for immediate inspection on request of a Department representative; and
Cooperate with Department-approved surveys and catch inspections necessary for harvest and by-catch determination, and biological characterization.
Eggs. A person may not catch, attempt to catch, or possess yellow perch eggs from any State waters, except for a person who:
Is working in cooperation with a scientific investigation of the Department;
Is authorized by a scientific collection permit in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-212, Annotated Code of Maryland; or
Catches yellow perch eggs and returns the eggs to the location where they were caught without landing.
Public Notice.
The Secretary may:

Modify catch limits, target harvests, registration process, or reporting requirements by publishing notice on the Fisheries Service website at least 48 hours in advance, stating the effective hour and date; or
Open, close, or modify a commercial season in order to manage the quota by publishing notice on the Fisheries Service website at least 24 hours in advance, stating the effective hour and date.
The Secretary shall make a reasonable effort to disseminate public notice through various other media so that an affected person has reasonable opportunity to be informed.
Penalties.
Failure to comply with the reporting or tagging requirements of this chapter may result in immediate suspension of a yellow perch harvest permit, as follows:
For a first offense, the period of suspension shall be 1 day;
For a second offense, the period of suspension shall be 5 days; and
For the third offense, the period of suspension shall be the remainder of the current season.
In addition to the suspension under §C(1) of this regulation, a licensee with a third offense shall be ineligible to apply for a yellow perch harvest permit for the following season.

Prior to suspending a permit under this chapter, the Department shall give the licensee notice of its intended action and an opportunity to appear at a hearing conducted in accordance with the contested case procedures set forth in State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland, and COMAR 08.01.04.
In addition to any other penalty, failure to submit a report as required by this chapter may result in license revocation under Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland.

container.heading: Sharks
container.text: Authority: Natural Resources Article, §§4-206 and 4-2A-03, Annotated Code of Maryland

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
"Circle hook" means a nonoffset hook with the point turned perpendicularly back to the shank.
"Eviscerate" means to remove the digestive organs of a shark, excluding the head.
"Finning" means removing only the fins of a shark.
"Fork length" means that length measured in a straight line from the tip of the nose of the shark to the center of the fork of the tail of the shark.
"Handline" means a mainline to which not more than two gangions or hooks are attached.
"Landing" means:
The unloading of any fish at a dock or shore by a commercial fisherman; or
The bringing of any fish to a dock, pier, or shore by a recreational fisherman for personal use.
"Large mesh gillnet" means a gillnet having a stretch mesh size equal to or greater than 5 inches.
"Recreational angler" means any fisherman who catches sharks for personal use.
"Shore-angler" means any person engaged in any type of fishing that does not take place on board a vessel.
"Shortline" means a fishing line meeting the requirements of COMAR 08.02.25.06.
"Small mesh gillnet" mean a gillnet having a stretch mesh size smaller than 5 inches.
"Vessel" means every type of watercraft used or capable of being used as a means of transportation on water except for nondisplacement craft and seaplanes.
"Vessel-fishing" means any fishing conducted from a vessel.
Authorized Shark Species. A recreational angler may harvest only the following species:
Smoothhound (Mustelus canis);
Atlantic sharpnose (Rhizoprionodon terraenovae);
Bonnethead (Sphyrna tiburo);
Finetooth (Carcharhinus isodon);
Blacknose (Carcharhinus acronotus);
Tiger (Galeocerdo cuvier);
Blacktip (Carcharhinus limbatus);
Spinner (Carcharhinus brevipinna);
Bull (Carcharhinus leucas);
Lemon (Negaprion brevirostris);
Nurse (Ginglymostoma cirratum);
Shortfin mako (Isurus oxyrinchus);
Porbeagle (Lamna nasus);
Common thresher (Alopias vulpinus);
Oceanic whitetip (Carcharhinus longimanus);
Blue (Prionace glauca);
Scalloped hammerhead (Sphyrna lewini);
Great hammerhead (Sphyrna mokarran); and
Smooth hammerhead (Sphyrna zygaena).

Season Closure. A recreational angler may not harvest, possess, or transport the species listed in §A(6)-(11) and (17)-(19) of this regulation from May 15 through July 15, inclusive, regardless of where the shark was caught.
Size Limits.
There is no minimum fork length for the species listed in §A(1)-(3) of this regulation.
The minimum fork length is 4.5 feet (54 inches) for the species listed in §A(4)-(16) of this regulation.
The minimum fork length is 78 inches for the species listed in §A(17)-(19) of this regulation.
Catch Limits.
There is no catch limit for smoothhound (Mustelus canis) sharks.
Shore-Angler Catch Limits. Each calendar day, a recreational shore-angler may harvest:
Only one shark, regardless of the species, from the species listed in §A(2)-(19) of this regulation;
One additional Atlantic sharpnose (Rhizoprionodon terraenovae); and
One additional Bonnethead (Sphyrna tiburo).
Vessel-Fishing Catch Limits.
A recreational fishing vessel may not harvest more than one shark, per trip, from the list in §A(2)-(19) of this regulation, regardless of the:
Species of shark; and
Number of people on board the vessel.
In addition to the vessel limit described in §D(3)(a) of this regulation, each recreational angler fishing from a vessel may harvest, per trip:
One Atlantic sharpnose (Rhizoprionodon terraenovae); and
One Bonnethead (Sphyrna tiburo).
Gear.
A recreational angler may catch sharks using only active line fishing gear.
Except when fishing with artificial flies or artificial lures, a recreational angler fishing for sharks shall use a circle hook.
A circle hook used to catch a shark shall be corrodible.
A recreational angler fishing for sharks shall have in possession at least one device capable of quickly cutting either the leader or the hook.
Tags and Reporting.
An individual shall obtain tags and catch information forms from a reporting station designated by the Department.
Before removing a landed shark from a boat or removing a boat containing a shark from the water, a person shall:
Affix a tail tag, provided by the reporting station, to the shark; and
Complete a catch information form provided by the reporting station.
Before removing a landed shark from the point of landing if caught on shore, a person shall:
Affix a tail tag, provided by the reporting station, to the shark; and
Complete a catch information form provided by the reporting station.
Upon landing a shark, an individual shall immediately return the catch information form to a reporting station designated by the Department.
General.
A recreational angler may not sell, barter, or trade sharks or shark pieces.

When aboard a vessel, a recreational angler is bound by the more restrictive vessel-fishing possession limits described in §D(3) of this regulation, regardless of the location where the shark was caught.

A shark that is transported by a vessel is considered "boat assisted" and is regulated under the more restrictive vessel-fishing possession limits described in §D(3) of this regulation, regardless of where it was caught.
All sharks harvested by a recreational angler shall have heads, tails, and fins attached naturally to the carcass through landing.
Sharks harvested in accordance with this regulation may be eviscerated as long as the tail is not removed.
An individual shall immediately release a species of shark:
That is not listed in §A of this regulation;
Whose season is closed as described in §B of this regulation; or
That does not meet the minimum size specified in §C of this regulation.
Except for a smoothhound, an individual may not remove from the water a shark that will be released.
For any shark that will be released, an individual may not:
Sit on the shark;
Hold the shark's mouth open;
Put the shark on dry sand;
Put the shark on a boat deck; or
Use a gaff.
Shark Groups.
Prohibited Species. The species of shark in the prohibited group are:
Sand tiger (Carcharias taurus);
Bigeye sandtiger (Odontaspis noronhai);
Whale (Rhincodon typus);
Basking (Cetorhinus maximus);
White (Carcharodon carcharias);
Dusky (Carcharhinus obscurus);
Bignose (Carcharhinus altimus);
Galapagos (Carcharhinus galapagensis);
Night (Carcharhinus signatus);
Reef (Carcharhinus perezii);
Narrowtooth (Carcharhinus brachyurus);
Caribbean sharpnose (Rhizoprionodon porosus);
Smalltail (Carcharhinus porosus);
Atlantic angel (Squatina dumeril);
Longfin mako (Isurus paucus);
Bigeye thresher (Alopias superciliosus);
Sharpnose sevengill (Heptranchias perlo);
Bluntnose sixgill (Hexanchus griseus); and
Bigeye sixgill (Hexanchus nakamurai).
Research. The species of shark in the research group is Sandbar (Carcharhinus plumbeus).
Smoothhound. The species of shark in the smoothhound group is Smoothhound (Mustelus canis).
Non-Blacknose Small Coastal. The species of shark in the small coastal group are:
Atlantic sharpnose (Rhizoprionodon terraenovae);
Finetooth (Carcharhinus isodon); and
Bonnethead (Sphyrna tiburo).
Blacknose. The species of shark in the blacknose group is Blacknose (Carcharhinus acronotus).
Aggregated Large Coastal. The species of shark in the aggregated large coastal group are:
Silky (Carcharhinus falciformis);
Tiger (Galeocerdo cuvier);
Blacktip (Carcharhinus limbatus);
Spinner (Carcharhinus brevipinna);
Bull (Carcharhinus leucas);
Lemon (Negaprion brevirostris); and
Nurse (Ginglymostoma cirratum).
Hammerhead. The species of shark in the hammerhead group are:
Scalloped hammerhead (Sphyrna lewini);
Great hammerhead (Sphyrna mokarran); and
Smooth hammerhead (Sphyrna zygaena).
Pelagic. The species of shark in the pelagic group are:
Shortfin mako (Isurus oxyrinchus);
Porbeagle (Lamna nasus);
Common thresher (Alopias vulpinus);
Oceanic whitetip (Carcharhinus longimanus); and
Blue (Prionace glauca).
Season.
Closure. During the period of May 15July 15, inclusive, an individual may not:
Harvest the species listed in §A(6) and (7) of this regulation from State waters; or
Transport the species listed in §A(6) and (7) of this regulation in State waters, unless the shark was harvested from federal waters provided:
The vessel does not engage in fishing within the closed area while possessing the species listed in §A(6) and (7) of this regulation;
The sharks possessed were not caught in the closed area; and
All fishing gear is stowed as described in §D(4) of this regulation and not available for immediate use.

A person may not harvest, possess, or land sharks for commercial purposes in State waters when the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration closes the fishery in federal waters for any species listed in §A of this regulation.
Catch Limits. An individual who has been issued a federal shark permit issued under 50 CFR §635 may not harvest, possess, or land more sharks than authorized by the individual's federal shark permit.
Gear.
The following gear types are the only gear authorized for use by a commercial tidal fish licensee to catch sharks in State waters:
Rod and reel;
Handline, which shall be:
Retrieved by hand, not by mechanical means; and
Attached to, or in contact with, a vessel;
Small mesh gillnet;
Large mesh gillnet, which shall be:
Shorter than 2.5 kilometers; and
Checked once every 2 hours;
Trawl net;
Shortline;
Pound net; and
Weir.
Methods of Stowing Gear.
On Reel.
The net shall be on a reel, its entire surface covered with canvas or other similar opaque material, and the canvas or other material securely bound.
The towing wires shall be detached from the doors.
A containment rope, codend tripping device, or other mechanism to close off the codend may not be attached to the codend.
Hook Gear.
All anchors and buoys shall be secured.
All hook gear, including jigging machines, shall be covered.
Sink Gillnet Gear.
All nets shall be covered with canvas or other similar material and lashed or otherwise securely fastened to the deck or rail.
All buoys larger than 6 inches (15.24 centimeters) in diameter, high flyers, and anchors shall be disconnected.
General.
Prior to harvesting or landing a shark for commercial purposes, an individual shall be authorized in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland.

A vessel which is used to catch, possess, or land any shark species listed in §A of this regulation for commercial purposes from the waters of the federal Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) of the Atlantic Ocean, which are defined as those ocean waters between 3 and 200 miles offshore, shall be permitted by the National Marine Fisheries Service in accordance with 50 CFR §635.
A federal commercial shark dealer permit is required to buy and sell any shark harvested from State waters.
Except as provided in §E(5) of this regulation, all sharks harvested in accordance with this chapter shall have the tails and fins attached naturally to the carcass through landing.

Smoothhound sharks harvested in accordance with this chapter may have the dorsal, pectoral, and caudal fins removed if smoothhound sharks make up at least 25 percent, by weight, of the total catch on board at the time of landing.
If fins are removed from a smoothhound shark, the total wet weight of the:
Caudal fins may not exceed 4 percent of the total dressed weight of smoothhound shark carcasses landed or found on board a vessel; and
Dorsal and pectoral fins may not exceed 8 percent of the total dressed weight of smoothhound shark carcasses landed or found on board a vessel.
Sharks harvested in accordance with this chapter may be eviscerated and have the heads removed.
Filleting and Finning.
Sharks may not be filleted or cut into pieces at sea.
Finning is prohibited.
Public Notice.

The Secretary may modify size limits, catch limits, gear provisions, shark species lists, and seasons for sharks in order to comply with species management through the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission Interstate Fishery Management Plan for Atlantic Coastal Sharks by issuing a public notice on the Fisheries Service website.
The public notice shall state its effective hour and date and shall be published on the Fisheries Service website at least 48 hours in advance of the effective hour and date.

The Secretary shall make a reasonable effort to disseminate a public notice issued under this section through various other media so that an affected individual has a reasonable opportunity to be informed.
A violation of the restrictions set by the Secretary in accordance with §B of this regulation is a violation of this regulation.
Spiny Dogfish. The provisions of this chapter do not apply to spiny dogfish (Squalus acanthias). Spiny dogfish (Squalus acanthias) may be harvested in accordance with COMAR 08.02.05.24.

section.heading: Purpose.
section.text: This chapter applies to shellfish aquaculture in waters of the State as described in Natural Resources Article, Title 4, Subtitle 11A, Annotated Code of Maryland.

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.

"Aquaculture activities" means those activities which include the purchase, monitoring, bottom preparation, planting, sale, possession, harvest, production, breeding, transportation, and processing of shellfish in State waters on or in an area used for shellfish cultivation.

"Aquaculture Enterprise Zone" means an area of the Chesapeake Bay approved for the leasing of submerged land or the water column by the Department in consultation with the Department of the Environment and the Wetlands Administrator of the State Board of Public Works.
"Aquaculture lease" means a lease of any submerged land or the water column located in an Aquaculture Enterprise Zone for cultivating oysters or other shellfish for commercial purposes.
"Atlantic Coastal Bays" means the waters of the Assawoman, Isle of Wight, Sinepuxent, Newport, and Chincoteague Bays and their tributaries.
"Demonstration lease" means a lease of submerged land for the purpose of demonstrating the ecological benefits of growing shellfish or for research or education.

"Maryland waters" means tidal and nontidal waters located within the boundaries of the State, including that portion of the Atlantic Ocean within the boundaries of the State, the Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries, and all ponds, lakes, rivers, streams, public ditches, and public drainage systems within the State.
"Person" means an individual, receiver, trustee, guardian, personal representative, fiduciary, or representative of any kind and any partnership, firm, association, corporation, or other entity.
"Pole" means a buoy, float, or stake used to mark a leased oyster bottom.

"SAV Protection Zone" means an area of submerged aquatic vegetation with a density greater than 10 percent as mapped in aerial surveys by the Virginia Institute of Marine Sciences in 1 or more of the 3 years preceding the designation of an Aquaculture Enterprise Zone, or an application for an aquaculture, submerged land, or demonstration lease.
"Seed oyster" means an oyster that is no more than 1 inch in size from hinge to bill.
"Submerged land lease" means any land lying beneath the waters of the State leased by the State to any person for cultivating oysters and other shellfish for commercial purposes.
"Water column lease" means a lease of the column of water on or under the surface of the water and above the surface of the submerged land.
"Yates Bar" means any submerged oyster bar, reef, rock, or area represented as an oyster bar on the charts of the oyster survey of 1906 to 1912, not including any amendments.
Aquaculture Activities on Submerged Land.

A person may not engage in aquaculture activities on submerged land in waters of the State, including the areas listed in Regulation .06 of this chapter, unless the land is leased or permitted for shellfish aquaculture purposes.
To obtain a submerged land lease a person shall:
Apply for:
A submerged land lease by submitting an application on a form provided by the Department; and
A shellfish aquaculture harvester permit as described in Regulation .04 of this chapter; and
Submit a non-refundable fee of $300.
Aquaculture Activities in the Water Column.
A person may not engage in aquaculture activities in the water column unless the water column is leased or permitted for shellfish aquaculture purposes.
To obtain a water column lease, a person shall:
Apply for:
A water column lease by submitting an application on a form provided by the Department; and
A shellfish aquaculture harvester permit as described in Regulation .04 of this chapter; and
Submit a non-refundable fee of $300.
Reporting. A leaseholder shall submit to the Department an annual report as required by the Department not later than December 31.
Rent.

Submerged Land Lease. Except as provided in §D(2) of this regulation, the rental rate for a submerged land lease is $3.50 per acre per year and is due in full to the Department by December 31 of the preceding year.
The rental rate for the first year of a lease may be prorated and is due in full to the Department within 30 days of lease approval.
Locations. In addition to restrictions provided in Natural Resources Article, Title 4, Subtitle 11A, Annotated Code of Maryland, a lease may not be located:
In waters classified as restricted by the Maryland Department of the Environment unless the person:
Provides proof to the Department of a viable relay location; or
Has a demonstration lease;
In the Assateague Island National Seashore as described in 16 U.S.C. §459f; or
Within 150 feet of a Yates Bar located in an oyster sanctuary as established in COMAR 08.02.04.15A.
Prohibited Activities.

A leaseholder may not make any alteration which includes adding any type of fill or sediment other than shell to the existing condition of the lease without first obtaining the Department's written consent.
