Shell present in the leased area at the time the lease is issued may not be removed from the leased area without the written permission of the Department.
Marking a Lease. A leaseholder shall:
Place a minimum of four poles at the corners of the lease perimeter;
Mark each pole with an 8-inch by 12-inch marker displaying only the initials or name of the leaseholder and the lease number; and
Maintain and meet any standards for corner marker structures as required by the Department in documents available on its website.
Gear.
All equipment, gear, or manmade material placed on the lease shall be permanently and individually marked with the lease number and name of the leaseholder.
The leaseholder shall be responsible and liable for equipment, gear, or aquaculture-related material:
That has been found adrift or unattended outside the boundaries of the lease area; or
Remaining on the lease after the surrender, default, abandonment, or termination of the lease.
Transfer of Lease.
A leaseholder may apply to transfer a lease by completing forms provided by the Department.

Prior to receiving approval of a transfer, the person receiving a transferred lease shall complete a lease application and a shellfish aquaculture harvester permit application and submit the required forms with the transfer form described in §I(1) of this regulation.
Surrender of a Lease. A lease may be surrendered by providing written notice to the Department.

Except for a demonstration lease holder, a lease holder or a lease transfer applicant shall submit an application, provided by the Department, and obtain a shellfish aquaculture harvester permit prior to engaging in aquaculture activities.
A shellfish aquaculture harvester permit:
Shall be valid for a 1-year term beginning on January 1 and expiring on December 31 each year;
Shall be automatically renewed for a new term upon receipt of all reports required under Regulation .03D of this chapter;
Is not transferable; and
Is an operator card for the purposes of Natural Resources Article, §4-11A-16.1, Annotated Code of Maryland.

Reporting. A person who is permitted by the Department under this regulation shall submit a monthly aquaculture harvest activity report on forms provided by the Department by the 10th day following the end of each month.
Permit Registrants.

Except for an individual under the supervision of a shellfish aquaculture harvester permittee who is present on the leased area, an individual engaged in aquaculture activities within the area described in the permit applicant's lease shall be:
Named as a permittee or permit registrant under the shellfish aquaculture harvester permit; and
In possession of a shellfish aquaculture harvester registration card issued to the individual by the Fisheries Service.
A shellfish aquaculture harvester permittee shall immediately notify the Department of any changes of named permit registrants on a form provided by the Department.
A shellfish aquaculture harvester registration card shall be issued to each shellfish aquaculture harvester permittee and permit registrant.
A shellfish aquaculture harvester permittee shall be responsible for all work and acts performed on the leased area under the permittee's supervision.
Any individual engaged in aquaculture activities on a leased area or transporting shellfish from a lease to a dealer:
Shall harvest, transport, and store shellfish in accordance with the National Shellfish Sanitation Program Model Ordinance that is incorporated by reference in COMAR 10.15.07.01A;
Except as provided in §E(3) of this regulation, may not harvest oysters from a:
Water column lease that are less than 2 inches from hinge to bill; or
Submerged land lease that are less than:
2 inches from hinge to bill from April 1 through September 30; or
3 inches from hinge to bill from October 1 through the following March 31;
Shall have written permission from the Department if in possession of undersized shellfish outside of the leased area;
May possess seed oysters;
May only sell oysters in accordance with COMAR 08.02.08.02;
Shall implement vibrio parahaemolyticus control measures in accordance with COMAR 10.15.07.06;
Shall store oysters in accordance with §G of this regulation; and
Shall tag oysters in accordance with §H of this regulation.
Tolerance Limit.

A shellfish aquaculture harvester permittee or permit registrant may not possess oysters harvested from a lease that include a combined total of more than 5 percent of shells and oysters which measure less than the minimum allowable size specified in §E(2) of this regulation.

In ascertaining this percentage the Department shall select by random sample an amount of oysters from any pile, hold, bin, house, or place as deemed proper, cull the sample, and require any undersized oysters to be returned to the lease area.
All small oysters and cultch that adhere to marketable oysters shall be separated, and the marketable oysters shall be excluded from any measurement of small oysters and cultch.

A person may possess marketable oysters that have undersized oysters or spat less than 1 inch in length from hinge to bill attached to them that cannot be separated without destroying the small oyster.
Containers.
Oysters harvested from a lease shall be placed in a container of any size prior to leaving the lease from which they were harvested.
Oysters shall remain in the original container until a tag is no longer required on the container in accordance with §J(1)(d) of this regulation.
Tagging of Individual Containers.

Except as provided in §H(2) and I of this regulation, an individual storing oysters in accordance with §H of this regulation shall complete and affix a Department-issued tag to each container of oysters prior to leaving the lease from which the oysters were harvested.
An individual storing oysters in accordance with §G of this regulation may use a tag not supplied by the Department if:
The individual:
Is licensed and certified to sell shellfish by the Maryland Department of Health in accordance with COMAR 10.15.04 and 10.15.07; and
Follows the tagging requirements of the National Shellfish Sanitation Program Model Ordinance, incorporated by reference by the Maryland Department of Health in COMAR 10.15.07.01; and
Each tag contains:
The statement "Farm-Raised Shellfish"; and
The lease number.
Department-issued tags shall only be used by the individual to whom the tags were originally issued.
Bulk Tagging.
Definitions.
In this regulation the following terms have the following meanings.
"Bulk tag" means a tag that provides the necessary information as required by the National Shellfish Sanitation Program Model Ordinance for a single lot of oysters.
"Single lot" means oysters coming from a single lease, harvested during a single trip on a single day.

Except as provided in §I(3) of this regulation, an individual storing oysters in accordance with §G of this regulation may complete and affix a Department-issued bulk tag to a single container of oysters prior to leaving the lease from which the oysters were harvested.
An individual storing oysters in accordance with §G of this regulation may use a bulk tag not supplied by the Department if:
The individual:
Is licensed and certified to sell shellfish by the Maryland Department of Health in accordance with COMAR 10.15.04 and 10.15.07; and
Follows the tagging requirements of the National Shellfish Sanitation Program Model Ordinance, incorporated by reference by the Maryland Department of Health in COMAR 10.15.07.01; and
Each tag contains:
The statement "Farm-Raised Shellfish";
The lease number; and
The following statement in bold capitalized letters: "ALL SHELLFISH CONTAINERS IN THIS LOT HAVE THE SAME HARVEST DATE AND ARE FROM THE SAME LEASE"; and
The number of individual containers in the lot.
If a bulk tag is used, the vessel may only harvest from one lease on that trip.
Tagging Provisions for Both Tagging of Individual Containers and Bulk Tags.
Tags:
Shall be durable and waterproof;
Shall be at least 5-1/2 x 2-3/4 inches in size;
Shall be completed legibly in indelible ink;

Shall stay affixed to the container until the container is in the possession of a person who is licensed and certified to sell shellfish by the Maryland Department of Health in accordance with COMAR 10.15.04 and 10.15.07; and
May not be reused.

In addition to the tagging requirements of this regulation, a person who is licensed and certified to sell shellfish by the Maryland Department of Health in accordance with COMAR 10.15.04 and 10.15.07 shall follow the tagging requirements of the National Shellfish Sanitation Program Model Ordinance, incorporated by reference by the Maryland Department of Health in COMAR 10.15.07.01.
An individual shall only possess one type of tag, wild shellfish or farm-raised shellfish, while harvesting oysters.
An individual shall possess only one type of tag, individual or bulk, while harvesting oysters.
An individual may not use a farm-raised shellfish tag to tag wild shellfish.
An individual may not use a wild shellfish tag to tag farm-raised shellfish.
Denial, Suspension, and Revocation.
Denial. The Department may deny issuance of a shellfish aquaculture harvester permit or registration card if the applicant or listed registrant:
Submits an incomplete or untruthful application;
Has commercial fishing privileges that are currently suspended or revoked for shellfish violations;
Had all commercial fishing privileges revoked; or
Held a shellfish aquaculture harvester permit or registration card that was revoked in accordance with §I(2) of this regulation within 3 years of the date of the application.
Suspension or Revocation. A shellfish aquaculture harvester permit or a shellfish aquaculture harvester registration card may be suspended or revoked by the Department if the individual:
Violates:
A provision of this chapter;
A provision of Natural Resources Article, Title 4, Subtitle 11A, Annotated Code of Maryland;
A term or condition of the permit or registration card; or
A term or condition of a Shellfish Lease Agreement;
Receives a conviction for taking shellfish:
From a closed or prohibited area;
With illegal gear;
More than 2 hours after sunset or any time before sunrise;
During the closed season; or
That are under the minimum size limit;
Receives more than one conviction related to the illegal harvest of shellfish within a two year period;
Has commercial fishing privileges that are currently suspended or revoked for shellfish violations; or
Had all commercial fishing privileges revoked.
Appeal.

Except as provided in §I(3)(c) of this regulation, prior to denying issuance of, suspending or revoking a shellfish aquaculture harvester permit or a shellfish aquaculture harvester registration card, the Department shall give the individual notice of its intended action and an opportunity to appear at a hearing conducted in accordance with the contested case procedures set forth in State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland, and COMAR 08.01.04.
If an individual submits a written request for a hearing to the Department within 30 days after the date that the notice required under this paragraph is mailed, the Department shall:
Hold a hearing after providing at least 10 days' notice to the individual; and
Conduct the hearing in accordance with State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland.

The Department may deny an application for, or suspend or revoke a shellfish aquaculture harvester permit or a shellfish aquaculture harvester registration card issued under this chapter without a hearing if the individual:
Does not submit a written request for a hearing to the Department within 30 days after the date that the notice required under this paragraph is mailed;
Fails to appear for a scheduled hearing for which the Department provided notice; or
Is prohibited from holding a permit or registration card as the result of a prior adjudication, settlement agreement, or consent order.
The Department may conduct pilot projects to demonstrate and evaluate new approaches to managing shellfish aquaculture in the State.

The Department may select and designate certain persons named on a Shellfish Aquaculture Harvester Permit or Shellfish Aquaculture Harvester Registration Card to participate in a pilot project. A participating permittee or registrant shall:
Apply for a pilot program permit on forms provided by the
Department;
Have a pilot program permit in order to participate in a pilot
program;
Comply with any conditions of the permit; and
Be eliminated from the pilot project at the discretion of the
Department.
The Department shall:
Develop pilot projects in cooperation with the aquaculture industry; and
Provide adequate notice of a pilot program through various media so that an interested individual has a reasonable opportunity to be informed.

section.heading: Pre-Approved Leasing Areas in the Coastal Bays.

para.text: The following areas are established as pre-approved leasing areas.
A "pre-approved leasing area" means an area of the Atlantic coastal bays approved for leasing of submerged land by the Department.
Areas Defined.

South Point Shoal. All of the waters Chincoteague Bay enclosed by a line beginning at a point at or near Lat. 38°10.860' N, Long. 75°13.379' W; then running 310° True to a point at or near Lat. 38°10.980' N, Long. 75°13.560' W; then running 19° True to a point at or near Lat. 38°12.060' N, Long. 75°13.079' W; then running 112° True to a point at or near Lat. 38°11.768' N, Long. 75°12.145' W; then running 227° True to the point of beginning.

Whale Gizzard Shoal. All of the waters Chincoteague Bay enclosed by a line beginning at a point at or near Lat. 38°5.288' N, Long. 75°15.311' W; then running 271° True to a point at or near Lat. 38°5.303' N, Long. 75°16.148' W;, then running 4° True to a point at or near Lat. 38°5.775' N, Long. 75°16.106' W; then running 76° True to a point at or near Lat. 38°5.932' N, Long. 75°15.288' W; then running 182° True to the point of beginning.
Eligibility. The Department may only issue a demonstration lease to be used exclusively for educational, conservation, or ecological purposes to:
A public high school;
An incorporated college or university within the State;
A 4-H club; or
A nonstock, nonprofit corporation organized under the laws of the State.
Application.
Prior to obtaining a demonstration lease, an eligible group or organization shall complete and submit an application on a form provided by the Department.
The application shall include:
Documentation that the applicant meets the qualifications set forth in Natural Resources Article, §4-11A-11, Annotated Code of Maryland;
The name and contact information of an employee of the applicant group or organization who will be responsible for ensuring that the requirements of this regulation are met;
The purpose of the demonstration lease;
A declaration that the applicant intends to actively use the leased area for demonstration purposes; and
A proposed plan for active use of the demonstration lease which shall include:
The applicant's source and quantity of shellfish or shellfish seed;
The quantity of shellfish or shellfish seed that the applicant expects to plant on the leased area during the initial 3 years of the lease;
A description of the activities that will occur on the leased area; and
A description of the labor, materials, and equipment to be used by the applicant.
Application Review Process.

If an application for a demonstration lease in the Chesapeake Bay or in the Atlantic Coastal Bays meets the requirements of this regulation and Natural Resources Article, §4-11A-11, Annotated Code of Maryland:
The applicant for the lease shall mark the proposed area with a stake; and
The Department shall:
Advertise the application on the website of the Department and once a week for 2 weeks in a newspaper published in the county or counties where the proposed lease is to be located;
Notify the owners of property directly in front of the proposed activity;
Notify each Chair of an Oyster Committee in the county in which the proposed activity is located; and
Notify other interested parties that the Department deems appropriate.

Within 30 days of publication of the last advertisement under §C(1) of this regulation, any person who has a specific right, duty, privilege, or interest that is different from that held by the general public and may be adversely affected by the proposed lease may file a petition with the Department protesting the issuance of the lease.
The protest shall be heard in accordance with the requirements of the Administrative Procedure Act under Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article.
The Department shall hold a public informational meeting on the issuance of a lease on the request of any person.

After termination of the period prescribed in §C(2) of this regulation for filing a petition or after a final decision dismissing a protest, the Department shall survey the proposed leased area and issue a lease to the applicant.
The Department, as it considers necessary to protect the public health, safety, and welfare, may:
Deny a lease application for reasonable cause; or
Include any conditions in a lease.
Fees. There are no application or rental fees for a demonstration lease.

Locations. In addition to restrictions provided in Natural Resources Article, §4-11A-11, Annotated Code of Maryland, a lease may not be located in the Assateague Island National Seashore as described in 16 U.S.C. §459f.
Prohibited Activities.
Alterations, including adding any type of fill or sediment other than shell to the existing condition of the lease, are not permitted without written permission from the Department.
Shell present in the leased area at the time the lease is issued may not be removed from the leased area without the written permission of the Department.
Permanent structures of any kind may not be placed on the leased area without written permission from the Department.
Shellfish may not be harvested from the leased area for commercial or human consumption purposes.
Lease Markers and Equipment. A leaseholder shall:
Place a minimum of four poles at the corners of the lease perimeter;
Mark each pole with an 8-inch by 12-inch marker displaying the name of the leaseholder and the lease number;
Maintain and meet any standards for corner marker structures as described by the Department on its website;
Permanently and individually mark all equipment or manmade material used on the lease with the lease number and name of the leaseholder; and
Be responsible and liable for equipment, gear, or aquaculture-related material that has been found adrift or unattended outside the boundaries of the lease area.
Operators.
The Department shall issue an operator card to the lessee at the time of lease approval.
When one or more individuals are engaged in demonstration activities on the leased area, an individual authorized by the lessee shall be present and in possession of the operator card.
Any individual engaged in demonstration activities on a leased area shall comply with the terms and conditions of the lease agreement for that area.
Reporting. A leaseholder shall submit to the Department an annual report as required by the Department not later than December 31.
Surrender of a Lease. A lease may be surrendered by providing written notice to the Department.
Application.
An individual shall submit an application for a shellfish nursery permit prior to engaging in shellfish nursery activities.
An application shall be submitted on a form provided by the Department.
The fee for a shellfish nursery permit application shall be $100 and shall be nonrefundable.
A shellfish nursery permit:
Shall be valid for a 5-year term beginning on the day of issuance;
May be renewed for a new term upon the Department's receipt of:
All completed reports required under this regulation; and
Confirmation that renewal is desired by the permittee;
May not be transferred; and
Shall be issued for each facility separately.
Reporting. A permittee under this regulation shall submit an annual report of shellfish nursery activities on a form provided by the Department not later than December 31 of the reporting year.
Size Limits. A permittee under this regulation shall only be authorized to culture shellfish seed to a maximum size measuring no greater than 1 inch in length from hinge to bill.
In-Water Structures.
An in-water shellfish nursery structure:
May not be larger than 200 square feet at any one site or physical address;
Shall be moored to an existing permitted wharf or other structure approved by the United States Army Corps of Engineers;
May not be located within a Submerged Aquatic Vegetation Protection Zone;
May not be located within 150 feet of a public shellfish fishery area or a registered pound net site; and
If located within an oyster sanctuary, as defined in COMAR 08.02.04.15, may not be located within 150 feet of a Yates bar.
A shellfish nursery permit for an in-water structure may only be issued to:
The owner of a wharf or other structure constructed on or about the water and approved by the United States Army Corps of Engineers; or
To a person with the permission of the owner of such a wharf or other structure.
Records and Inspection. A shellfish nursery permittee shall:
Maintain quarterly shipping and receiving records for each species cultivated at the facility that estimate:
Stocks on hand; and
The transfer of shellfish seed to or from the facility or leased area;
Keep all shipping and receiving records for a minimum of 3 years; and

Allow the Department to inspect at reasonable hours the shellfish nursery facility and any of the permittee's equipment, records, or product that are part of the permit holder's shellfish nursery operations.

Suspension or Revocation of Permit. The Department may revoke or suspend a permit at any time for noncompliance with the requirements established in Natural Resources Article, §4-11A-23, Annotated Code of Maryland, regulations adopted under this section, or the terms and conditions of the permit.
General.
A shellfish nursery permittee shall:
Obtain all necessary permits and comply with all applicable federal, State and local laws and regulations;
Follow the requirements of the National Shellfish Sanitation Program Model Ordinance that is incorporated by reference in COMAR 10.15.07.01A; and
Notify the Department immediately upon discovery of any disease or mass mortality event affecting the shellfish at the facility that has the potential to contaminate native or naturalized animals.
The shellfish nursery permit shall be:
Displayed at the facility at all times; or
In the possession of the permittee or any other individual engaged in shellfish nursery activities at the facility.

container.heading: Gear
container.text: Authority: Natural Resources Article, §§4-215, 4-221, 4-505, 4-701.1, 4-701.2, 4-711, and 4-713, Annotated Code of Maryland

para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
"Archery equipment" means a vertical bow or a crossbow.
"Bank pole" means a line and hook dangling into a river, stream, or lake that has the other end attached to a pole which is stuck into the ground.
"Bush-bob" means a line and hook dangling into a river, stream, or lake that has the other end attached to an overhead tree or bush limb.
"Cast net" means a circular monofilament or multi-ply net with weights distributed around its edge that is cast or thrown by hand in such a manner that it spreads out on the water and sinks.

"Chumming" means placing fish, parts of fish, or other natural or manmade attractants upon which fish might feed, in the water, not attached to a hook, for the purpose of attracting fish to a particular area so that they might be caught.
"Circle hook" means a non-offset hook with the point turned perpendicularly back to the shank.
"Dip net" means a mesh bag of netting which is suspended from a circular, oval, or a rectangular frame attached to a long handle or rope.
"Eel pot" means an enclosure constructed of wire having:
A square mesh size not less than 1/2 inch; or
If the mesh is smaller than 1/2 inch by 1/2 inch, an escape panel installed in an exterior wall of the retention chamber measuring at least 16 square inches made of 1/2 inch by 1/2 inch mesh.
"Finfish trotline" means a length of rope or line, buoyed at both ends with one or more anchors, which is baited with hooks set at intervals for the purpose of catching finfish.
"Fish pot" means a single, finfish entrapment net device, without associated wings or leads, consisting of:
An enclosure of various shapes covered with mesh webbing of not less than 1-1/2 inch mesh size;
One or more conical entrance funnels; and
One or more unobstructed escape vents, in the holding chamber, of at least 2-1/2 inches in diameter, if circular, or 2-1/2 inches mesh size if square.
"Fyke net" means a stationary finfish entrapment net device, without a pound or crib, consisting of:
A series of hoops covered by mesh webbing of #12, or larger, twine of not less than 1-1/2 inch mesh size;
No more than one set of wings;
A leader or hedging not longer than 250 feet consisting of #12, or larger, twine and with a minimum mesh size of 3 inches;
In nets with a mesh size less than 2-1/2 inches, a cull panel at least 1 foot by 1 foot with unobstructed escape meshes when set with a minimum mesh size of 2-1/2 inches;
A single entrance funnel; and
One or more internal funnel shaped throats.
"Gig" means an implement with a shaft and three-pronged barbed point which is either thrust or thrown by hand.
"Gill net" means a net which:
Is maintained in a vertical position in the water with sinkers, floats, or stakes, or a combination of sinkers, floats, and stakes; and
Captures fish by means of a mesh too small to permit passage of the body of the fish or withdrawal of the head once the posterior margin of the gill covers has passed through the mesh.

"Gill net, anchored" means a gill net that is stationary in the water and secured to the bottom by weights on either end or along the bottom line which prevent the gill net from drifting freely with the tide or current.

"Gill net, attended" means the licensee remains in the boat within 2 miles of the gill net while it is in waters of the Chesapeake Bay, or within 1 mile when the gill net is in waters of the Atlantic Ocean, its coastal bays and their tributaries, or a tributary of the Chesapeake Bay.

"Gill net, drift" means a gill net not secured to or anchored to the bottom, designed to drift with the natural or prevailing tidal current, including a gill net rigged with up to 20 pounds of weight at each end, in addition to that weight required to achieve negative buoyancy.
"Gill net, stake" means a gill net hung from or supported by stakes which are set in a row and driven into the bottom.
"Hand" means a method of fishing whereby an individual uses their own hand to physically capture the fish.
"Handline" means a fishing line attended primarily by hand.
"Haul seine" means an encircling type of net with wings, brail lines and poles, and a bunt or pocket, and with the following characteristics:
Made of at least #12 twine;
Wings not greater than 15 feet in width at the attachment with the brail poles or brail line;
A width or depth not exceeding 22 feet at the bunt or back; and
A width of the bunt or back not greater than 100 feet.
"Hook and line" means a line free of mechanical devices except for reels attached to a pole or rod or held in hand and attended in a manner that the fish is caught by the hook.
"Hook unit" means a lure with multiple hooks.
"Hoop net" means a single finfish entrapment net device consisting of:
An enclosure formed by a series of hoops covered by mesh webbing of #12, or larger, twine, of not less than 1-1/2 inch mesh size;
One or more internal funnel-shaped throats;
A single entrance funnel;
No wings and leader; and
In nets with a mesh size less than 2-1/2 inches, a cull panel at least 1 foot by 1 foot with unobstructed escape meshes when set having a minimum mesh size of 2-1/2 inches.
"J hook" means a hook having a point parallel to the hook shank.
"Jug" means a method of fishing that uses lines suspended from floating containers or devices.

"Landing net" means a mesh bag which is suspended from a circular, oval, or rectangular frame attached to a short handle which is operated by hand to capture a fish which is being caught by other means.
"Live-lining" means using a live finfish on a hook for the purpose of catching other fish with:
Hook and line;
Rod and reel; or
Handlines.
"Lure" means an artificial bait used for catching fish.
"Net" means a mesh webbing panel or multiple panels, whether continuous or discontinuous, which may be joined in various configurations for the capture of fish.
"Noodling" means a method of catching fish using one's hands or feet while in the water.
"Number 12 twine" means tightly twisted or braided nylon fibers, which are between 0.043 and 0.048 inches in diameter when compressed.
"Offset hook" means a hook with the point and barb not in the same plane with the shank.
"Pound net" means a fixed finfish entrapment net device consisting of:
One or more pounds or cribs each measuring at least 16 feet long by 16 feet wide at the surface of the water with a netting floor and open top;
Mesh webbing with a twine size of #12 or larger;
At least one heart leading into the crib;
A leader or hedging consisting of #12 twine or larger and with a minimum mesh size of 3 inches; and
No other type of fishing device, netting, or wire within the pound or crib.
"Rod" means a pole, cane, or stick to which a line can be attached directly.
"Rod and reel" means a pole with a line and usually a line winding mechanism, attached at the bottom of the pole, and is turned by a crank so that the line is wound around a barrel.
"Seine" means an encircling type of net with mesh.
"Slat basket" means a wooden box that funnels fish down into a holding area that is usually baited.
"Snagging" means actively fishing with a hook that intentionally foul-hooks the fish outside the mouth.
"Spear" means a shaft with one sharp point and/or a barb for capturing a fish by piercing its body.
"Spear gun" means any type of device used for propelling a spear under water by any means other than manual in order to catch fish.

"Stinger hook" means any hook which trails another hook or hook unit, either by direct physical attachment to the lead hook or hook unit, or by a connective device such as a line, swivel or chain, and is part of the same bait or lure.
"Tip up" means a device used in ice fishing in which a signal flag is raised when a fish takes the bait.
"Trap" means a single, bait finfish entrapment device, without associated wings or leads, and consisting of:
An enclosure of various shapes covered with mesh of not greater than 1/2-inch square mesh size for tidal waters and 1/4-inch square mesh for nontidal waters;
One or more entrances with an opening not more than 2 inches in diameter in tidal waters or not more than 1 inch in diameter in nontidal waters; and
No dimension greater than 24 inches in any direction.
"Trip" means the duration which begins with departure of the fishing vessel from a shore-based location and which terminates with return to a shore-based location.
"Trolling" means the method of angling during which fish are attracted to a lure or bait being trailed from a boat which is moving forward or backward by mechanical, manual, or wind power.
Recreational Gear.
An individual may only use the gear specified in this regulation to catch fish for recreational purposes from nontidal waters.

An individual shall comply with all seasons, creel limits, size limits, and other species-specific regulations as specified under this subtitle and Natural Resources Article, Title 4, Annotated Code of Maryland.
Traps.
An individual may not take or attempt to take fish with a trap in any trout management area described in COMAR 08.02.11.01C, D, G, and H.
An individual may not use more than one trap.
A trap shall be:
Marked with the individual's
Name and address; or
DNRid number; and
Checked daily.
A trap shall be set:
Within 100 feet of the shore, and:
Attached by a line to the property, pier or dock; or
Marked by a buoy or pole and sign; or
By attaching the trap to a boat that is not docked.
If a trap is set on private property, the trap owner shall obtain the landowner's permission prior to setting the trap.
If a trap is set on public property, the trap shall be set within 100 feet of the owner.
Active Line Fishing Gear.
Individuals catching fish in nontidal waters may only use the following active line fishing gear:
Hook and line;
Rod and reel; and
Handline.
The gear listed in §C(1) of this regulation shall be used in a manner in which the individual is handling the gear or actively in control of the gear.
No more than two hook units per line may be used on the gear listed in §C(1) of this regulation.
Except when ice fishing, a maximum of three or a combination of three of the gear listed in §C(1) of this regulation may be used by an individual fishing in nontidal waters.
When ice fishing, a maximum of five tip ups or rods may be used.
Snagging is not legal in State waters.
Nets.
Individuals catching fish in nontidal waters may only use the following nets:
Seines;
Dip nets; and
Landing nets.
Except for a landing net, a nonresident may not use nets in nontidal waters.
Except for a landing net, nets may not be used in waters described in COMAR 08.02.11.01B-H.
A person may not bait a net.
Seines in nontidal waters:
Shall have mesh no greater than 1/4 inch;
May not exceed 6 feet in width and 4 feet in height;
Shall only be used to catch minnows and other bait fish;
May not be used within 50 yards of the base of any dam or the mouth of any river or tributary; and
Shall only be emptied from shore.
Dip nets:
May be used in areas of the Potomac River, Monocacy River, and Conococheague Creek that lie within Allegany, Carroll, Frederick, and Washington counties to catch the following fish species:
Carp;
Catfish;
Northern snakehead; and
Suckers; and
May not be used in any other area or to catch any other species.
Landing nets in nontidal waters may be used to land a fish which is being caught by other means.
Projectile Gear.
Individuals catching fish in nontidal waters may only use the following projectile gear:
Archery equipment;
Gig;
Spear; and
Spear gun.
Except for a gig, projectile gear shall have a retrieval line attached to it.
A gig may only be propelled by hand.
An individual may use projectile gear to take any fish except for the following species:
All trout species;
Walleye;
Striped bass;
Striped bass hybrids;
Northern pike;
Muskellunge;
Muskellunge hybrids, including tiger musky;
Largemouth and smallmouth bass;
Snapping turtles; and
Any species listed as threatened or endangered under COMAR 08.03.08.
An individual may not take or attempt to take any fish with a projectile gear in any trout management area described in COMAR 08.02.11.01B-H.
An individual may not take or attempt to take any fish with a projectile gear in State-controlled community ponds or lakes.
Additional Restrictions.
Except as provided in §E(7)(b) of this regulation, a person may not shoot projectile gear within 100 yards of any:
Human being;
Private or public swimming area;
International diving flag;
Occupied duck blind; or
Vessel other than the vessel occupied by the individual using the projectile gear.
The distance restriction in §E(7)(a) of this regulation does not apply:
To the use of gigs; or
If the person using the projectile gear receives permission from all affected parties within that area prior to engaging in fishing activities.
Hand Gear. Individuals catching fish in nontidal waters may only use the following hand gear:
Hand; and
Noodling.
Recreational Gear.

Recreational gear for catching clams, crabs, and oysters is regulated elsewhere in Natural Resources Article, Title 4, Annotated Code of Maryland, and COMAR 08.02 and is excluded from this regulation.
An individual may only use the gear specified in this regulation to catch fish for recreational purposes from tidal waters.

An individual using gear in accordance with this chapter shall comply with all seasons, creel limits, size limits, and other species-specific rules as specified under this subtitle and Natural Resources Article, Title 4, Annotated Code of Maryland.
Hook Requirements Chesapeake Bay and Its Tidal Tributaries.
When chumming or live-lining, a person recreationally angling in the Chesapeake Bay or its tidal tributaries shall only use a circle hook.
When fishing for striped bass, a person recreationally angling in the Chesapeake Bay or its tidal tributaries shall only use a circle hook when using fish, crabs, or worms as bait, or processed bait.
During the period March 1 through March 31, a person recreationally angling in the Chesapeake Bay or its tidal tributaries:
May not use stinger hooks;
Shall only use barbless hooks while trolling; and
Except as required by §§B(1) and (2) of this regulation, when using fish, crabs, or worms as bait, or processed bait, shall only use a:
Circle hook; or
"J" hook with a gap of less than or equal to 1/2 inch between the point and the shank.
During the period April 1 through April 30, a person recreationally angling in the Chesapeake Bay or its tidal tributaries:
May not use stinger hooks; and
Except as required by §§B(1) and (2) of this regulation, when using fish, crabs, or worms as bait, or processed bait, shall only use a:
Circle hook; or
"J" hook with a gap of less than or equal to 1/2 inch between the point and the shank.

During the period May 1 through December 31, except as required by §§B(1) and (2) of this regulation, when using fish, crabs, or worms as bait, or processed bait, a person recreationally angling in the Chesapeake Bay or its tidal tributaries shall only use a:
Circle hook; or
"J" hook.

Hook Requirements-Atlantic Ocean, Its Coastal Bays, and Their Tributaries. When fishing for striped bass, a person recreationally angling in the Atlantic Ocean, its coastal bays, or their tributaries shall only use a circle hook when using fish, crabs, or worms as bait, or processed bait.
Traps.
An individual may not use more than one trap.
A trap shall be:
Marked with the individual's DNRid number; and
Checked daily.
A trap shall be set:
Within 100 feet of the shore, and:
Attached by a line to the property, pier or dock; or
Marked by a buoy or pole and sign; or
By attaching the trap to a boat that is not docked.
If a trap is set on private property, the trap owner shall obtain the landowner's permission prior to setting the trap.
If a trap is set on public property, the trap shall be set within 100 feet of the owner.
Active Line Fishing Gear.
Individuals catching fish in tidal waters may only use the following active line fishing gear:
Hook and line;
Rod and reel; and
Handline.
The gear listed in §E(1) of this regulation shall be used in a manner in which the individual is handling the gear or actively in control of the gear.
No more than two hook units per line may be used on the gear listed under §E(1) of this regulation.
Snagging is not legal in State waters.

During the period March 1 through March 31, no more than six lines, regardless of the number of people on board a vessel, may be used for recreationally angling from a boat when trolling in the Chesapeake Bay or its tidal tributaries.
During the period April 1 through April 30, a person recreationally angling in the Chesapeake Bay or its tidal tributaries may not attempt to catch fish by trolling.
Nonactive Line Fishing Gear.
The only nonactive line fishing gear that an individual may use to catch fish in tidal waters is a jug.
An individual may use up to 10 jugs.
Jugs:
Shall have no more than 2 hooks per line and no more than one line per jug;
May only be used in tidal tributaries of the Chesapeake Bay;
May only be used from July 1 through the last day of February;
Shall be marked with the individual's DNRid number;
Shall be attended between the hours of sunset and sunrise; and
May be used to take any fish except for the following species:
Largemouth and smallmouth bass;
Striped bass;
All shark species;
Snapping turtles; or
Any species listed as threatened or endangered under COMAR 08.03.08.
Nets.
Individuals catching fish in tidal waters may only use the following nets:
Cast nets;
Seines;
Dip nets; and
Landing nets.
Cast nets shall have a radius not exceeding 10 feet.
Seines in tidal waters:
Shall have mesh no greater than 1/4 inch;
May not exceed 50 feet in width and 5 feet in height;
Shall only be used to catch minnows and other bait fish;
May not be emptied from a boat; and
May not be emptied on the shore or in water less than 12 inches deep.
An individual may use a landing net to land a fish which is being caught by other means.
A person may not bait a net.
Projectile Gear.
Individuals catching fish in tidal waters may only use the following projectile gear:
Archery equipment;
Gig;
Spear; and
Spear gun.
Except for a gig, projectile gear shall have a retrieval line attached to it.
A gig may only be propelled by hand.
An individual may use projectile gear to take any fish except for the following species:
All trout species;
Walleye;
Striped bass;
Striped bass hybrids;
Northern pike;
Muskellunge;
Muskellunge hybrids, including tiger musky;
Largemouth and smallmouth bass;
Snapping turtles;
All shark species;
American lobster; and
Any species listed as threatened or endangered under COMAR 08.03.08.
Additional Restrictions.
Except as provided in §F(5)(b) of this regulation, a person may not shoot projectile gear within 100 yards of any:
Human being;
Private or public swimming area;
International diving flag;
Occupied duck blind; or
Vessel other than the vessel occupied by the individual using the projectile gear.
The distance restriction in §F(5)(a) of this regulation does not apply:
To the use of gigs; or
If the person using the projectile gear receives permission from all affected parties within that area prior to engaging in fishing activities.
Hand Gear. Individuals catching fish in tidal waters may only use the following hand gear:
Hand; and
Noodling.
An individual is not considered in violation of Natural Resources Article, §4-505, Annotated Code of Maryland, if the individual:
Is designated as an operator or co-user in accordance with this subtitle; or
Harvests fish in accordance with §B of this regulation.
A licensee may harvest fish from gear belonging to another individual and is not considered in violation of Natural Resources Article, §4-505, Annotated Code of Maryland, if:
The licensee has permission of the gear owner or designated co-user;
The gear owner or designated co-user is present at the piece of gear while the harvest occurs;
The licensee has obtained and is in possession of a valid permit necessary for the species being harvested; and
Both licensees are in possession of their tidal fish license.
Archery equipment shall have a retrieval line attached to any projectile.
An individual may use archery equipment to take any fish during an open commercial season except for the following species:
All shark species;
American lobster;
Muskellunge;
Muskellunge hybrids, including tiger musky;
Northern pike;
Snapping turtles;
Striped bass;
Striped bass hybrids;
Walleye; and
Any species listed as threatened or endangered under COMAR 08.03.08.
Additional Restrictions.
Except as provided in §C(2) of this regulation, a person may not shoot archery equipment within 100 yards of any:
Human being;
Private or public swimming area;
International diving flag;
Occupied duck blind; or
Vessel other than the vessel occupied by the individual using archery equipment.

The distance restriction in §C(1) of this regulation does not apply if the person using the archery equipment receives permission from all affected parties within that area prior to engaging in fishing activities.
An individual may not set or fish a finfish trotline within 100 feet of another individual's set trotline.
The length of a finfish trotline is measured along the baited portion of the line.
Except as provided in §H of this regulation, a finfish trotline:
May not exceed 1,200 feet in length;
May not be baited with live bait; and
Shall only be rigged with circle hooks with a minimum size of 5/0.
Float Requirements.
A finfish trotline shall have a float of the same color, size, and shape attached to each end.
Floats that have a round or spherical shape shall be at least 12 inches in diameter.
Floats that do not have a round or spherical shape shall be at least 12 inches long and 7 inches wide.
Floats shall be marked with the owner's commercial license number.
Depth Requirements.
During the period from June 16 through the end of February, a finfish trotline shall be set:
At least 10 feet below the surface of the water, in waters that are at least 10 feet deep at mean low tide; or
On the bottom of the water body in which they are set, in waters that are less than 10 feet deep at mean low tide.
During the period from March 1 through June 15, finfish trotlines shall be set on the bottom of the water body in which they are set.
Area Restrictions. Except as provided in §H of this regulation, a finfish trotline:
Shall only be set in the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries; and
May not be set in the Chesapeake Bay south of the William Preston Lane, Jr. Memorial Bay Bridge, including Pocomoke Sound and Tangier Sound.

An individual shall be appropriately licensed to catch finfish under Natural Resources Article, §4-701 or 4-701.2, Annotated Code of Maryland, and permitted in accordance with this regulation in order to use a finfish trotline.
Shortlines.
Definition.
In this section, the following term has the meaning indicated.
Term Defined. "Shortline" means a type of finfish trotline which meets the requirements of this section.
A shortline may not exceed 1,500 feet in length.
Hook Requirements. In addition to the hook requirements in §C of this regulation:
A shortline may not have more than 50 hooks; and
Any hook used on a shortline shall be corrodible.
A maximum of two shortlines are allowed per vessel.
Any vessel using a shortline shall:

Practice the protocols and possess the federally required release equipment for pelagic and bottom longlines for the safe handling, release, and disentanglement of sea turtles and other nontarget species; and
Have all captains and vessel owners federally certified in using handling and release equipment.
Allowed Area. A shortline may only be used in the Atlantic Ocean.
Definitions.
For purposes of this regulation, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
"Co-user" means an individual who is:
Properly licensed in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland;
Designated in writing to the Department by the registrant; and
Authorized to harvest fish from the specified pound net site.
"Registrant" means the individual who registered the pound net site and owns the pound net.
Pound Net Sites.
An individual may not set a pound net in State waters unless:
The individual has submitted a completed registration form provided by the Department;
The individual is properly licensed in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland;
The site is approved by the Department;
The site is registered in the individual's name; and
The individual has notified the Department of the setting of the net in compliance with §E of this regulation.
An individual may not register more than eight pound net sites with the Department.
The pound net site registrant shall notify the Department in writing to cancel a pound net site registration.

A pound net set at a registered site by the registrant has priority over other commercial finfish gear with regard to any distance requirements set forth in Natural Resources Article, §4-711, Annotated Code of Maryland.
A commercial tidal fish licensee that intends to use a pound net to harvest striped bass shall comply with the additional structural requirements described in COMAR 08.02.15.04.
The Department may approve the permanent transfer of a registered pound net site upon completion of the appropriate transfer application and pound net site registration.
The Department may revoke the registration of a pound net site for cause, including but not limited to, the revocation or lapse of the registrant's commercial tidal fish license.
Co-Users.
A registrant may designate one or more co-users for each pound net site by completing a form provided by the Department.
A registrant may designate or remove a co-user at any time during the year.
A co-user shall display their commercial identification number on the designated pound net.
A co-user is authorized to harvest fish only from the specified pound net site.
Marking of Pound Nets. The registrant shall mark the pound net while the stakes are in the water, regardless of whether the nets are attached, as follows:
The stake at the head of a pound net shall be marked by a light that is functional between sunset and sunrise, which shall be:
Placed on the stake at least 6 feet above normal high water; and
Visible in all directions for at least 1 mile on a clear night; or

The stake of a pound net shall be marked with retro-reflective tape, as specified by the Department, which is placed on the stake at least 6 feet above normal high water in the following areas and manner:
On all State waters, except for Potomac River tributaries:
The stake at each end of the pound net shall be marked with three 4-inch bands of orange retro-reflective tape which do not overlap; and
The stakes between the two end stakes, at intervals not greater than 150 feet apart, shall be marked with a single 4-inch band of white retro-reflective tape; and
On Potomac River tributaries:

The end stake closest to the channel and on the right side of channel when entering from a seaward direction, shall be marked with three 4-inch bands of red retro-reflective tape, which do not overlap, and the opposite end stake shall be marked with three 4-inch bands of green retro-reflective tape which do not overlap;

The end stake closest to the channel and on the left side of the channel when entering from a seaward direction shall be marked with three 4-inch bands of green retro-reflective tape which do not overlap, and the opposite end stake shall be marked with three 4-inch bands of red retro-reflective tape which do not overlap; and
At least three stakes between the two end stakes, at intervals not greater than 150 feet apart, shall be marked with a single 4-inch band of white retro-reflective tape.
Pound Net Activity Notification.
A pound net site may be activated by the registrant for:
A full license year beginning on July 15 immediately prior to the license year; or
The remainder of the license year at any point during the license year.
The registrant shall ensure that written notice is received by the Department at least 7 days prior to setting any pound net.
Notification shall be on a form provided by the Department.
Pound Net Soak Time Limits.
During the time period of January through June, pound nets shall be fished at the interval set by the Department in a public notice, with all entrapped striped bass released.
The Secretary shall publish such notice on the Department's website no later than December 1 of the year preceding the soak time limit provision taking effect.

An individual may use a haul seine in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-713, Annotated Code of Maryland, during the period from 12:01 a.m. Saturday until sunrise on Monday only if the individual notifies the Department in accordance with §B of this regulation at least 24 hours in advance of the activity.
Prior to using a haul seine during the period from 12:01 a.m. Saturday until sunrise on Monday an individual shall:
Call the Natural Resources Communication Center a minimum of 24 hours in advance of the activity; and
Provide the following information to the operator:
Name of the commercial licensee;
Commercial license number;
Name of the vessel;
Date the activity will occur; and
Location of the activity, including the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration fishing area code.
Restricted Areas. From February 1 through March 31, inclusive, a person may not set a fyke net in any of the following areas:

Bohemia River upstream of a line beginning at a point at or near Little Hack Point defined by Lat. 39°27.78'N and Long. 75°52.45'W; then running approximately 70° True to a point at or near the Route 213 bridge defined by Lat. 39°27.87'N and Long. 75°52.19'W;

Bush River upstream of a line beginning at a point at or near the mouth of Church Creek defined by Lat. 39°28.04'N and Long. 76°13.33'W; then running approximately 100° True to a point defined by Lat. 39°28.03'N and Long. 76°13.22'W;

Chester River upstream of a line beginning at a point at or near Indian Point defined by Lat. 39°14.28'N and Long. 75°56.17'W; then running approximately 360° True to a point on the Kent County shore defined by Lat. 39°14.54'N and Long. 75°56.16'W; and then upstream to a line, beginning at a point upstream of the mouth of Red Lion Creek defined by Lat. 39°14.62'N and Long. 75°54.63'W; then running 360° True to a point on the Kent County shore at Lat. 39°14.80'N and Long. 75°54.63';

Chester River upstream of a line beginning at a point at or near Ford's Landing defined by Lat. 39°15.04'N and Long. 75°53.70'W; then running 270° True to a point on the Queen Anne's County shore defined by Lat. 39°15.04'N and Long. 75°53.64'W;
Choptank River upstream of a line beginning at a point defined by Lat. 38°55.82'N and Long. 75°50.00'W; then running approximately 45° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°55.84'N and Long. 75°49.84'W;

Tuckahoe Creek, Choptank River tributary, upstream of a line beginning at a point defined by Lat. 38°52.86'N and Long. 75°57.10'W; then running approximately 90° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°52.86'N and Long. 75°57.07'W;

Elk River upstream of a line beginning at a point at or near Old Frenchtown Wharf defined by Lat. 39°34.56'N and Long. 75°50.55'W; then running approximately 279° True to a point at or near Scotland Point defined by Lat. 39°34.60'N and Long. 75°50.90'W;

Gunpowder River upstream of a line beginning at a point defined by Lat. 39°23.13'N and Long. 76°22.11'W; then running approximately 50° True to a point at or near the base of the Amtrak rail defined by Lat. 39°23.51'N and Long. 76°20.67'W;

Bird River, Gunpowder River tributary, upstream of a line beginning at a point defined by Lat. 39°22.94'N and Long. 76°23.83'W; then running approximately 10° True to a point defined by Lat. 39°22.98'N and Long. 76°23.77'W;

Marshyhope Creek, Nanticoke River tributary, upstream of a line beginning at a point defined by Lat. 38°38.85'N and Long. 75°48.84'W; then running approximately 90° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°38.85'N and Long. 75°48.80'W;

Northeast River upstream of a line beginning at a point defined by Lat. 39°35.25'N and Long. 75°57.72'W; then running approximately 110° True to a point defined by Lat. 39°35.05'N and Long. 75°56.99'W;

Patuxent River upstream of a line beginning at a point at or near Jackson Landing defined by Lat. 38°46.46'N and Long. 76°42.70'W; then running approximately 45° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°46.48'N and Long. 76°42.68'W;

Allen's Fresh, Potomac River tributary, upstream of a line beginning at a point defined by Lat. 38°23.14'N and Long. 76°55.42'W; then running approximately 20° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°23.20'W and Long. 76°55.40'W;

Nanjemoy Creek, Potomac River tributary, upstream of a line beginning at a point defined by Lat. 38°26.63'N and Long. 77°07.19'W; then running approximately 90° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°26.78'N and Long. 77°06.32'W; and

Sassafras River upstream of a line beginning at a point at or near the Route 213 bridge in Georgetown defined by Lat. 39°21.91'N and Long. 75°52.98'W; then running approximately 150° True to a point defined by Lat. 39°21.81'N and Long. 75°52.89'W.
A person shall remove fyke net poles from the water within 30 days after removing the net from the poles.

container.heading: Shell Recycling Tax Credit
container.text: Authority: Tax-General Article, §10-724.1, Annotated Code of Maryland

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
"Aggregation site" means a location where shell donated for recycling is stored or aged prior to being replanted in State waters.
"Bushel" means an amount of oyster shells that will fill a 10-gallon container, or about 500 shells.
Business Entity.
"Business entity" means:
A person conducting or operating a trade or business in Maryland; or
An organization operating in Maryland that is exempt from taxation under §501(c)(3) or (4) of the Internal Revenue Code.
"Business entity" includes a person operating a landfill or solid waste acceptance facility permitted under COMAR 26.04.07.
"Certified recycled shell collector" means:
A business entity certified by the Department under Regulation .06 of this chapter to verify amounts of recycled oyster shell; or
The Department.
"Comptroller" means the Maryland Comptroller of the Treasury, or the Comptroller's designee.
"Corporation" includes an association or joint-stock company.
"Department" means the Maryland Department of Natural Resources.

"Person" includes the State, any county, municipal corporation, or other political subdivision of the State, or any of their units, or an individual, receiver, trustee, guardian, executor, administrator, fiduciary, or private corporation, or any other entity.
Shell Recycler.
"Shell recycler" means a person that donates shell for replanting in Maryland tidal waters.
"Shell recycler" does not include a person that receives compensation for the shell donation.
"Taxable year" means the period for which Maryland taxable income is computed under Tax-General Article, Title 10, Annotated Code of Maryland.
To be eligible for a State income tax credit under this chapter, a shell recycler shall:
Prior to donating shell, complete an online registration as specified by the Department that includes the shell recycler's Tax Identification Number;
Donate shell for recycling to a certified recycled shell collector; and
Receive and maintain electronic invoice records from the Department, indicating for each shell donation:
The name of the certified recycled shell collector;
The date and location of the shell donation; and
The number of bushels of shell donated.
Eligibility of Business Entities.
Only an individual or a corporation may receive a credit against the State income tax for oyster shell recycling.

If a business entity other than a corporation recycles oyster shell in accordance with the eligibility requirements established in §A of this regulation, the amount of credits computed for the pass-through entity shall be allocated among the owners as agreed to in writing by the owners in accordance with Internal Revenue Service rules.
Allowable Credit.

A shell recycler may claim a tax credit against the State income tax in the amount specified in Tax-General Article, §10-724.1, Annotated Code of Maryland, for each bushel of oyster shells recycled during the taxable year.
A shell recycler may not claim a tax credit for bushels of shell that:
Are collected by the shell recycler as a certified recycled shell collector; or
Are replanted in an area leased by the shell recycler for commercial shellfish aquaculture.
Amount Allowed Per Taxable Year. For any taxable year, the maximum credit a person may claim may not exceed the amount specified in Tax-General Article, §10-724.1, Annotated Code of Maryland.
If the credit exceeds the person's liability for the taxable year, the unused amount of the credit may not be carried forward to any other taxable year.

section.heading: Certification of Credit.
section.text: The Department shall certify to an eligible shell recycler the amount of the allowed tax credit approved by the Department for the shell recycler. The Department shall issue the certification by January 30 of the calendar year following the end of the taxable year in which the shells were recycled.

section.heading: Claiming the Credit.
section.text: To claim the credits approved by the Department, an individual or corporation shall:

para.text: File with the Comptroller an income tax return for the taxable year in which the costs were incurred; and
Attach a copy of the Department's certification of the approved credit amount to the tax return.
Certification of a Collector.
A business entity may apply to the Department to be a certified recycled shell collector.
An application shall:
Be submitted on a form provided by the Department; and
Include the applicant's:
Name, address, and contact information;
Planned shell aggregation site; and
Planned method of storing and aging the shell.
Upon receipt and review of an application for certification under this regulation, the Department may:
Approve the application and issue the applicant a certificate designating the applicant a certified recycled shell collector; or
Deny an application for reasonable cause.
A certification issued to a recycled shell collector:
Shall be valid for 1 year beginning on the day of issuance; and
May be renewed for a new term upon the Department's receipt of a renewal application submitted as specified by the Department.
A certified recycled shell collector shall:

Collect and process oyster shell from shell recyclers in accordance with the terms and conditions set out in the certification issued under §A of this regulation, and all applicable federal, State and local laws and regulations;

For each shell donation collected, submit an electronic report as specified by the Department verifying the location, date, and amount of the shell donation within 48 hours of collecting the donation;
Allow the Department, or the Department's designee, to inspect at reasonable hours the certified recycled shell collector's shell aggregation site and collected recycled shell; and
Notify the Department immediately of any changes to the certified recycled shell collector's aggregation site or contact information.
Penalties.
The Department may suspend or revoke a certification issued to a recycled shell collector for failure to comply with this chapter or the terms and conditions of the certification.

Within 15 days of receipt of the Department's notice of a denial, suspension, or revocation of a certification issued under §A of this regulation, the recycled shell collector may appeal the decision in writing to the Director of the Maryland Fisheries Service.
